questions.text:
Match the following:

 


	
		
			
			1) Food adulteration
			
			a) Claviceps in wheat
		
		
			2) Food additivity
			b) Saccharin in health drinks
		
		
			3) Food fortification
			c) Vanaspati in ghee
		
		
			4) Food toxication
			d) Iodine in salt
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1-c, 2-b, 3-d, 4-a


 

Explanation:

Definition  Example

Food adulteration is the act of adding or removing any substance to and from natural food sources, which alters the nature and composition of the latter. E.g., adding dried papaya seeds with black pepper, animal fat with butter, etc.

Vanaspati in ghee

Food additivity is the process of mixing substances into food to improve its taste, colour, and texture and increase its shelf life.

Saccharin in health drinks

Food fortification incorporates micronutrients into food substances to improve nutritional deficiencies, especially in endemic areas. Examples include iron-fortified rice and adding iodine with salt.

 

Iodine in salt
Food toxication is the process in which potential health effects occur as a result of consuming foods that contain toxic substances either present naturally, accidental contamination or deliberate adulteration, e.g., Claviceps in wheat causing ergotism

Claviceps in wheat

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with vertical diplopia that worsens when looking down, especially while walking downstairs. Examination reveals weakness in intorsion, depression, and abduction of the affected eye. Which muscle and cranial nerve are most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Superior Oblique; Trochlear nerve (CN IV)

 

Explanation:

  • The superior oblique muscle, innervated by the trochlear nerve (CN IV), is responsible for intorsion, depression, and abduction of the eye.
  • Dysfunction of this muscle causes vertical diplopia, particularly noticeable when looking down, such as when walking downstairs.

questions.text: Examine the image of a sarcomere below. Which band is indicated by the X ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A band

Explanation:

  • A band: The dark band, anisotropic to polarized light. It contains the entire length of the myosin filaments. The ends of the actin filaments also overlap with the myosin filaments in this band.
  • I band: The light band, isotropic to polarized light. It contains only actin filaments.(Option B ruled out)
  • Z disk: A structure composed of filamentous proteins (alpha-actinin) that bisects the I band. Actin filaments attach to the Z disk and extend from it in both directions to interdigitate with myosin filaments. Z disks also pass from myofibril to myofibril, attaching them together across the muscle fiber.(Option C ruled out)
  • H zone: Located at the center of the A band, this zone contains only myosin filaments and appears lighter than the rest of the A band.(Option D ruled out)
  • M line: A structure that runs down the center of the H zone, providing structural support for the myosin filaments.

Correct Answer: C) 1-d, 2-a, 3-b, 4-c

 

Explanation:

Tonopen

  • It is an applanation tonometer
  • Tonometer of choice in children

Rebound tonometer

questions.text:
A patient is brought to the emergency after a fall from a tree. He developed shortness of breath and chest pain, is tachypneic, and has distended neck veins on examination. His chest X-ray shows as follows:



Which of the following is the correct finding here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Collapsed lung

The above clinical symptoms and the chest X-ray lead to the diagnosis of a right pneumothorax, which causes the lung to collapse and squished towards the hilum, ipsilateral depression of the hemidiaphragm, and contralateral deviation of the mediastinum.

 

Pathophysiology:

  • The pressure gradient in the thorax changes with pneumothorax. Normally, the pleural space is negative compared to atmospheric pressure.
  • If air enters the pleural space through communication with the alveoli, it alters the pressure gradient, leading to lung collapse.

 

Radiographic appearance of pneumothorax:

  • Pneumothorax appears as a radiolucent area (black).
  • Pneumothorax pushes the adjacent lung towards the hilum.
  • A sharp radiopaque line separates the pneumothorax from the lung parenchyma.
  • A closed pneumothorax is easily detectable in an expiratory X-ray, as there is a decrease in lung volume. However, the volume of the pneumothorax is not affected by respiration.

Tension Pneumothorax

  • Significant contralateral deviation of the mediastinum (vs Option A)
  • Collapsed lung
  • Depression of ipsilateral hemidiaphragm (vs Option B)

White-out lung (Option D) refers to when there is complete opacification of an entire hemithorax. This is seen in conditions like pneumonia of the entire lung, a large mass in the lung or chest wall, large pleural effusion, etc., which increase the opacity of the lung.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with jaundice and fatigue, recently diagnosed with hepatitis B infection. Further investigation reveals abnormal liver function tests, indicating hepatic injury. Which of the following statements regarding the mechanisms of hypersensitivity involved in this case is true?

choices.text: CD8+ T cells differentiate into Th1 and Th17 cells upon antigen exposure
CD4+ T cells differentiate into Th2 cells upon exposure to antigen
Cytotoxic T-lymphocytes (CTLs) directly kill virus-infected cells via the Fas-Fas ligand pathway
Perforin-granzyme-dependent killing is a mechanism employed by CD4+ T cells

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cytotoxic T-lymphocytes (CTLs) directly kill virus-infected cells via the Fas- Fas ligand pathway.

Explanation:

The type of hypersensitivity involved in hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection is Type IV.

Mechanisms of Type IV hypersensitivity

Description

Examples

Cytokine-mediated inflammation
(mediated by CD4+ T cells)

CD4+ T cells recognise protein antigens presented by APCs and differentiate into Th1 and Th17 cells (Options A and B ruled out).

Th1 cells secrete cytokines like IFN-γ, activating macrophages to cause tissue damage and fibrosis. Th17 cells produce IL-17 to recruit neutrophils, promoting inflammation.
  • Tuberculin test (a classic example of delayed-type hypersensitivity)
  • Granulomas
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • IBD
  • Psoriasis

T cell-mediated cytotoxicity (mediated by CD8+ T cells)


 

Cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) directly kill antigen-bearing target cells, including tumour cells, virus-infected cells, and allogeneic tissue, during graft rejection. CTLs use perforin-granzyme-dependent killing (Option D ruled out) and Fas-Fas ligand-dependent killing mechanisms to induce apoptosis in target cells. (Option C)
  • Type 1 DM
  • Hepatic injury in HBV infection
  • Graft vs host disease

questions.text: A 30-year-old man visits his doctor expressing frustration with his sexual performance. He reports that he ejaculates within 30 seconds of vaginal penetration, which has caused distress in his relationship. Which of the following treatments is not typically used for premature ejaculation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Sildenafil

Explanation:

  • Sildenafil is used to treat erectile dysfunction, not premature ejaculation.
  • It works by increasing blood flow to the penis but does not address the timing of ejaculation.

Premature Ejaculation (PME)

  • A pattern of persistent or recurrent ejaculation with minimal sexual stimulation before or immediately after vaginal penetration.
  • DSM-5- Ejaculation occurs within <1 minute following vaginal penetration
  • The cause of PME is usually psychogenic.

questions.text: A 68-year-old patient is recovering from pneumonia and has been on mechanical ventilation for the past week. The medical team is preparing to assess the patient for readiness to wean off the ventilator. Which of the following criteria should the medical team confirm before initiating the weaning process?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Tidal volume (VT) > 5 mL/kg

Explanation:

A tidal volume greater than 5 mL/kg supports the decision to initiate weaning, indicating adequate respiratory function.

Discontinuing mechanical ventilation involves two phases: Readiness testing and Weaning.

  • Readiness Testing:
    • Assess if the underlying cause for ventilation is controlled or reversed.
    • Manage complicating factors such as bronchospasm, heart failure, infection, malnutrition, increased CO₂ production, acid-base imbalances, anemia, altered mental status, and sleep deprivation.
    • Weaning is considered when the patient meets the following criteria:
      • pH > 7.25,
      • Adequate oxygenation (FiO₂ < 0.5, PaO₂ saturation > 90%),
      • Hemodynamic stability, and no signs of myocardial ischemia.
      • Adequate cough reflex present.
  • Weaning or Liberation:
    • Key measurements for weaning criteria:
      • Inspiratory pressure: < –25 cm H₂O
      • Tidal volume (VT): > 5 mL/kg
      • Vital capacity: > 10 mL/kg (Option A)
      • Minute ventilation: < 10 L/min (Option B)
      • Rapid shallow breathing index (RSBI): < 100 (with < 105 indicating potential for extubation). (Option D)
    • Weaning methods:
      • SIMV: Gradually decrease mechanical breaths and pressure support to 5–8 cm H₂O while maintaining acceptable arterial CO₂ tension and respiratory rate.
      • PSV: Gradually reduce pressure support to maintain a VT of 4–6 mL/kg and respiratory rate < 30.
      • T-Piece/CPAP: Observe spontaneous breathing; use sequential trials if needed. CPAP (5 cm H₂O) may prevent atelectasis during prolonged T-piece trials by maintaining functional residual capacity (FRC).

Match the enzyme class with its corresponding example:

 


	
		
			
			Enzyme Class

Explanation:

 

Class

Function

Examples

Oxidoreductases

Catalyze oxidation-reduction reactions

Lactate dehydrogenase, glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase

Transfer functional groups

Hexokinase, aminotransferase

questions.text: A 7 Y/O boy presents with a limp and complains of pain in his right hip that has gradually worsened over the past few weeks. The pain is sometimes referred to his knee.There is no history of trauma.On physical examination, there is a limited range of motion, particularly in internal rotation and abduction of the hip.X-ray of the pelvis shows flattening of the femoral head with areas of sclerosis and fragmentation.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Perthes disease

 

Explanation:

Perthes disease, also known as Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease, is an idiopathic avascular necrosis of the femoral head that typically affects children between the ages of 4 and 10.

 

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease

Description
  • Idiopathic osteonecrosis or idiopathic avascular necrosis of the capital femoral epiphysis of the femoral head.

Etiopathogenesis
  • Idiopathic or etiology that would disrupt the blood flow to femoral epiphysis.
  • Coagulopathy and steroid use.
 

Includes 4 phases

  • Necrosis: Disruption of the blood supply leads to infarction of the femoral capital epiphysis.
  • Fragmentation: The body reabsorbs the infarcted bone.
  • Reossification: Osteoblastic activity takes over, and the femoral epiphysis reestablishes.
  • Remodeling: The new femoral head may be enlarged or flattened. It reshapes during growth.

Risk factors
  • Ten percent familial (there is a delayed bone age by about 2 years)
  • HIV (Up to 5% of HIV patients have avascular necrosis of the hip)
  • Factor V Leiden
  • Thrombophilias (increased clotting)
  • Hypofibrinolysis (decreased ability to dissolve clots)
  • Secondhand smoke exposure
  • Low socioeconomic status
  • Birth weight less than 2.5 kg in boys
  • Short stature

Clinical features
  • Limp of acute or insidious onset, usually painless.
  • If pain is present, it is localized to the hip or knee.
  • Decreased internal rotation and abduction of hip.
  • Atrophy of thighs and buttocks.
  • Leg length discrepancy.
  • Antalgic gait in acute cases
  • Trendelenburg gait in chronic cases

Diagnosis
  • Standard anteroposterior pelvis and frog-leg lateral (Lauenstein) views.
  • Bone scan or MRI


 

Early findings:

  • Widening of joint space (epiphyseal cartilage hypertrophy)
  • Changes in the epiphysis.
  • Crescent sign: Subchondral radiolucent zone of the anterolateral epiphysis
 

Late signs:

  • Flattening of the femoral head.
  • Bone scan shows decreased perfusion to the femoral head.

Differential diagnosis
  • Transient synovitis
  • Multiple epiphyseal dysplasia (MED)
  • Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia (SED)
  • Gaucher disease
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Meyer dysplasia

Treatment

Non operative:

  • Indicated for children with bone age less than 6 or lateral pillar A involvement.
  • Activity restriction and protective weight-bearing are recommended until ossification is complete.
 

Operative treatment:

  • Femoral or Pelvic Osteotomy indicated in children older than 8 years.
  • Valgus or Shelf Osteotomies indicated in children with hinge abduction
  • Hip Arthroscopy

Complications
  • Coxa magna: Widening of the femoral head.
  • Coda plans: Flattening of the femoral head.

 

Gaucher disease (Option B): A lysosomal storage disorder that may affect the bones but usually presents with hepatosplenomegaly and other systemic signs.

Meyer's dysplasia (Option C): A benign condition that affects the growing hip joint, but it typically does not present with hip pain or limp like Perthes disease.

Multiple epiphyseal dysplasia (Option D): A hereditary disorder affecting multiple joints, causing pain and early-onset arthritis, but is usually more widespread and affects more than just one hip.

questions.text:
Match the parts of the Papez circuit with their correct functions:


	
		
			
			Part of Papez Circuit
			
			
			Function
			
		
		
			
			1) Cingulate Gyrus
			
			
			A) Conversion of short-term memory to long-term memory
			
		
		
			
			2) Parahippocampal Gyrus
			
			
			B) Controls heart rate, blood pressure, cognitive and emotional processing
			
		
		
			
			3) Hippocampus
			
			
			C) Responsible for controlling recent memories of the brain
			
		
		
			
			4) Mammillary Body and Anterior Nucleus of Thalamus
			
			
			D) Spatial memory, the memory of three-dimensional space
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1 - B, 2 - D, 3 - A, 4 - C

Explanation:
The Papez circuit is a neurocircuitry of the limbic system involved in learning and memory, emotion, and social behavior.

 

It has the following components:

Part of Papez Circuit

Function

Cingulate Gyrus

Controls heart rate, blood pressure, cognitive and emotional processing.

Parahippocampal Gyrus and Entorhinal Cortex

Spatial memory, the memory of three-dimensional space.

Hippocampus

Responsible for the conversion of short-term memory to long-term memory.

Mammillary Body and Anterior Nucleus of Thalamus

Responsible for controlling recent memories of the brain.

questions.text:
Match the following nail sign with its most likely cause

 


	
		
			
			A. Mee’s line
			
			
			1. Chronic renal insufficiency
			
		
		
			
			B. Muehrcke's lines
			
			
			2. Liver cirrhosis
			
		
		
			
			C. Lindsay's nails
			
			
			3. Arsenic poisoning
			
		
		
			
			D. Terry’s nails
			
			
			4. Hypoalbuminemia
questions.solution:
Correct answer: a) A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2


Explanation:

The above conditions are examples of leukonychia

 

Nail sign

Causes

Mees’ lines

 

Also known as transverse leukonychia.

Horizontal, transverse white lines.

Seen in,

  • Arsenic poisoning
  • Chemotherapy

 

Muehrcke’s lines

 

  • Pairs of transverse white bands.
  • Seen in Hypoalbuminemia.

Lindsay's nails

 

Also known as half-and-half nails.

 

See in:

  • Chronic renal failure
  • Uremia

 
 

Terry’s nails

 

The proximal part is white and the distal nail appears normal and red.

 

Seen in:

  • Liver cirrhosis
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Diabetes

Punctate leukonychia

 

Seen in:

  • Trauma
  • Alopecia areata

 

Leukonychia is the whitish discoloration of nails. It can be classified as true leukonychia and false leukonychia.


 

True leukonychia

False leukonychia

Occurs due to defective keratinization of the nail matrix.

Due to abnormal nail bed vasculature.

White lines or patches over the nail that do not disappear with pressure.

Whitish discoloration disappears with pressure.

Lines or patches move distally with nail growth and eventually disappear.

Do not disappear with nail growth.

Examples: Mees’ lines, punctate lines.

Examples: Terry’s nails, Muerhcke’s nails.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old female presents with complaints of palpitations and dizziness after playing lawn tennis. She is having multiple such episodes for the past 2 years. ECG is shown below. Which of the following is not correct about this condition



a. Fibrofatty replacement on cardiac biopsy

b. LV dyskinesia

c. MC gene involved is DSG gene

d. T wave inversion in precordial leads
questions.solution: Disease involves RV wall and not LV. RV outflow tract VT is leading cause of death in this condition. The most common mutation associated with Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Dysplasia (ARVD) is in the PKP2 gene (Plakophilin-2)

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents for a routine eye examination. During gonioscopy, the examination reveals an occludable anterior chamber angle bilaterally. The patient reports no visual symptoms, and intraocular pressure (IOP) measurements are within normal limits. There is no evidence of glaucomatous damage on optic nerve examination. What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Prophylactic peripheral iridotomy

 

Explanation:

  • Primary Angle Closure Suspect (PACS) is characterized by an occludable anterior chamber angle as seen during gonioscopy but without evidence of increased IOP or glaucomatous damage.
  • This indicates a risk for potential future angle closure but does not yet present as acute angle-closure glaucoma.

 

PACS: Primary Angle Closure Suspect

  • Iridotrabecular contact or occludable angle of more than 3 quadrants on gonioscopy
  • No peripheral anterior synechiae
  • Intraocular pressure is normal
  • Eclipse sign of PACS - convex iris lens diaphragm
  • Treatment: Prophylactic Peripheral iridotomy (Option B) is done in both eyes with lens extraction using NdYAG laser

questions.text: Which of the following inhibits Acetyl CoA Carboxylase?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Glucagon

Explanation:

  • Acetyl CoA Carboxylase is inhibited by Glucagon.
  • Glucagon inhibits acetyl CoA carboxylase by keeping the enzyme in the inactive phosphorylated state.
  • Glucagon is secreted when the energy charge is low and AMP levels are high.

 

Acetyl CoA Carboxylase

 

Stimulated by High energy level states

Inhibited by Low energy level states.
  • NADH (Option B ruled out)
  • FADH2
  • ATP (Option C ruled out)
  • Citrate
  • Insulin: enhances the uptake of glucose by adipocytes and increases the activity of pyruvate dehydrogenase, acetyl CoA carboxylase, and glycerol phosphate acyl transferase (Option D ruled out)
  • ADP
  • NAD
  • FAD
  • Glucagon(catabolic hormone) (Option A)
  • Acyl CoA
  • Epinephrine

 

  • The nutritional state of the organism is the main factor regulating the rate of lipogenesis
    • Diets:
      • Carbohydrate-rich diet: Increases lipogenesis
      • Fat-rich diet: Decreases lipogenesis eg. Keto diet

 

  • Other situations where lipogenesis is decreased:
    • Restricted caloric intake
    • Diabetes mellitus

questions.text: A 28 year old multiparous woman at 39 weeks gestation arrives at the labour and delivery unit in active labour. She is confirmed to have a frank breech presentation. Which of the following is NOT a prerequisite for proceeding with assisted breech extraction?

choices.text: The patient is kept hydrated orally

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Patient is kept hydrated orally

Explanation:

This patient has a breech presentation and requires IV access and IV fluids for hydration. She should be kept nil per os (NPO) in case an emergency cesarean delivery is needed.

Prerequisites of assisted breech extraction:

  • Staff Requirements for Breech Extraction:
    • Provider skilled in breech extraction. (Option C)
    • Assistant to help with delivery.
    • Anesthesia personnel for adequate analgesia or anaesthesia.
    • Trained individual in newborn resuscitation.
  • Maternal Preparation:
    • Intravenous access is obtained for potential emergency cesarean section or maternal resuscitation.
  • Labor Monitoring:
    • One-on-one nursing due to increased cord prolapse risk.
    • Continuous electronic monitoring of the fetal heart rate is preferred. (Option A)
  • Fetal requirements:
    • Fetal weight should be <4 kg (Option B)

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents for her routine mammogram, which reveals microcalcifications in the right breast. She has no significant family history of breast cancer and is asymptomatic. A core needle biopsy is performed, and the histopathological image is shown below. Based on histopathology, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ductal Carcinoma in Situ

 

Explanation :

The histopathological image shows features consistent with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), including malignant cells confined within the ductal system without invasion into surrounding tissue. This correlates with the clinical scenario of microcalcifications detected on mammography, a common presentation of DCIS.

The image shows cribriform variant of DCIS: In this duct, multiple small white spaces can be seen, which gives it the cribriform pattern.

he most high-grade DCIS is comedo necrosis DCIS, because it has the highest chance of converting into invasive ductal carcinoma.

Types of DCIS :

 

Comedo
  • It may occasionally produce a vague nodularity but is often detected as clustered or linear and branching areas of calcification.
  • There is necrotic, dirty material inside the duct.
  • Two features define it:
    • Tumor cells with pleomorphic, high-grade nuclei.
    • Areas of central necrosis.

Cribriform
  • It has rounded (cookie cutter–like) spaces, often filled with calcified secretory material.

Micropapillary
  • It produces complex bulbous protrusions without fibrovascular cores.
  • Shows small papillary projections inside the duct.

Papillary
  • It produces true papillae with fibrovascular cores that lack a myoepithelial cell layer and shows proper finger-like papillary projections.

Solid
  • The duct is full of cells and becomes solid.

questions.text:
Match the following sections of the BSA (Bhartiya Sakshya Act) with their corresponding explanations or provisions:


	
		
			
			BSA Section
			
			
			Provision
			
		
		
			
			1. 157
			
			
			a) A magistrate or judge can ask you a question at any point of time
			
		
		
			
			2. 146
			
			
			b) The sequence of examination (Oath-CH-CR-RE)
			
		
		
			
			3. 168
			
			
			c) Leading question
			
		
		
			
			4. 143
			
			
			d) Questions by the party to his/her own witness
questions.solution:

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient is diagnosed with malignant pheochromocytoma after presenting with persistent hypertension and elevated plasma metanephrines. Imaging reveals metastasis to various sites. Which of the following is not a common site for metastasis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Brain

 

Explanation:

Brain is not a common site for metastasis in malignant pheochromocytoma.


 

Malignant Pheochromocytoma

Tumors that have undergone metastasis to Lymph-node (or) Distant site (Biochemically same as Pheochromocytoma)

Survival Rate

5-year survival ranges from 20% to 45%.

Criteria of Malignancy

Malignancy is defined by the development of metastases

Common Sites of Metastasis

Axial skeleton, lymph nodes, liver, lung, and kidney. (Option A,C,D)

Diagnosis

  • MIBG & Gallium Dotate is Best for Diagnosis
  • Biopsy & FNAC are avoided in Malignant Pheochromocytoma
  • Confirmed by the presence of metastases in locations where neuroectodermal tissues are not normally found.
  • This is the primary criterion distinguishing malignant pheochromocytomas from benign ones, as histopathologic features alone are not reliable in predicting malignancy.

Histopathologic Criteria

No histopathologic criteria can accurately predict the clinical course of malignancy.

Primary Treatment

Surgical resection, even if not curative, can offer significant palliative benefits by managing mass effects and reducing catecholamine excess.

Response to Radiotherapy/Chemotherapy

Minimal response to radiotherapy and chemotherapy.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with a history of metastatic lung cancer presents to the emergency department with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, fatigue, and confusion. Blood tests reveal a significantly elevated serum calcium level. The patient is diagnosed with hypercalcemia of malignancy. Which of the following is the drug of choice for treating this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Zoledronic acid

Explanation: 

Zoledronic acid is a bisphosphonate that is considered the drug of choice for the treatment of hypercalcemia of malignancy due to its potent ability to inhibit bone resorption and lower serum calcium levels effectively.

Management of hypercalcemia in malignancy:

Initial Treatment

  • Intravenous hydration with normal saline to increase renal calcium excretion and glomerular filtration rate.
  • Loop diuretics (e.g. furosemide) after initial volume expansion to enhance calciuresis.

Pharmacologic Therapy

  • Calcitonin: Provides a rapid but short-lived reduction in serum calcium levels.
  • Bisphosphonates (e.g. Zoledronic acid, Pamidronate): Potent inhibitors of osteoclast-mediated bone resorption, providing a more sustained reduction in calcium levels.
  • Denosumab: A monoclonal antibody that inhibits osteoclast activity, effective in bisphosphonate-refractory hypercalcemia.
  • Glucocorticoids: Used in calcitriol-mediated hypercalcemia to inhibit vitamin D conversion.

Refractory Hypercalcemia

  • Denosumab can be used as an alternative for refractory or recurrent hypercalcemia despite treatment with bisphosphonates.
  • Hemodialysis may be considered in patients with advanced kidney disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male recipient of a kidney transplant presents with a sudden increase in serum creatinine levels three days post-transplant. Laboratory tests reveal the presence of donor-specific antibodies (DSAs) and linear C4d staining in peritubular capillaries on biopsy. Which of the following statements best describes the condition?

choices.text: It is primarily mediated by T-cell activation.
It is characterized by the presence of pre-existing antibodies against donor antigens.
It is commonly associated with chronic rejection mechanisms.
It usually resolves spontaneously without intervention.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It is characterized by the presence of pre-existing antibodies against donor antigens.

Explanation:

Acute Humoral Rejection (AHR) is diagnosed through the presence of donor-specific antibodies (DSAs) in the serum, along with histological evidence of glomerulitis or peritubular capillaritis observed in biopsy samples. Additionally, linear C4d staining in peritubular capillaries serves as a critical marker for confirming the diagnosis.

 

Acute Humoral Rejection (AHR):

  • Definition
    • Significant complication in organ transplantation, particularly in kidney transplants.
    • Characterized by donor-specific antibodies (DSAs) targeting the vascular endothelium, leading to tissue injury and graft dysfunction.

Mechanisms of AHR:

  • Pathophysiology
    • Binding of DSAs to donor HLA molecules activates the complement system, resulting in:
      • Capillary Injury: Damage to peritubular capillaries is a hallmark of AHR.
      • C4d Deposition: A key diagnostic marker; approximately 30% of acute rejection biopsies show widespread C4d staining.
      • Histological Features: May include neutrophilic infiltration, glomerulitis, and fibrinoid necrosis in severe cases.

Diagnosis:

  • Diagnostic Criteria
    • Combination of clinical presentation, serological testing, and histopathological findings:
      • Histologic Evidence: Glomerulitis or peritubular capillaritis.
      • Antibody Interaction: Linear C4d staining indicates recent antibody interaction with vascular endothelium.
      • Detection of DSAs: Presence of DSAs in serum confirms diagnosis.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Symptoms
    • Patients may experience:
      • Acute Elevation in Creatinine: Noted within days to weeks post-transplant.
      • Fever and Malaise: General systemic inflammation signs.
      • Graft Tenderness: Possible tenderness over the transplant site.

Treatment:

  • Management Approaches
    • Aim to reduce antibody-mediated injury:
      • Plasmapheresis: Removes circulating antibodies.
      • Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IVIG): Modulates immune responses.
      • Rituximab: Targets CD20 on B cells to reduce antibody production.
      • Eculizumab: A complement inhibitor effective in severe AHR cases.

It is primarily mediated by T-cell activation (Option A) is incorrect because AHR is primarily mediated by antibody interactions, not T-cell responses.

 

It is commonly associated with chronic rejection mechanisms (Option C) is incorrect since AHR is an acute process, distinct from chronic rejection.

 

It usually resolves spontaneously without intervention (Option D) is incorrect; AHR typically requires immunosuppressive treatment for resolution.

questions.text: A 58-year-old female presents with diarrhea, weight loss, and itchy lesions around the mouth and vagina. Physical examination reveals a rash as shown in the image below. On evaluation, she has diabetes, and imaging studies indicate a large pancreatic mass. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Glucagonoma

 

Explanation:

  • The above symptoms of weight loss, diarrhea, stomatitis and vulvovaginitis with the characteristic rash suggestive of necrolytic migratory erythema, along with large pancreatic mass points towards the diagnosis of glucagonoma.
Aspect Details
Origin Alpha cells of the pancreas
Common Locations Body and tail of the pancreas
Size 5-10 cm
Prevalence Sporadic; 17% with MEN type II syndrome
Gender More common in females
Malignancy 80% malignant; 80% spread to liver
Symptoms Necrolytic migratory erythema, diabetes, diarrhea, weight loss, stomatitis, anemia, amino acid deficiency, vulvovaginitis
Diagnostic Tests MRI, CT scan, Endosonography, Angiogram, Serum glucagon levels (>50 pmol/L)
Treatment Anemia and deficiency correction, IV amino acids, DVT prevention, Distal pancreatectomy, Whipple’s/total pancreatectomy, Enucleation, Dacarbazine

 

  • Gastrinoma (Option A): Typically associated with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, presenting with recurrent peptic ulcers rather than necrolytic migratory erythema.
  • Insulinoma (Option B): Characterized by hypoglycemia and hyperinsulinemia, not typically associated with necrolytic migratory erythema.
  • VIPoma (Option D): Associated with WDHA syndrome (Watery Diarrhea, Hypokalemia, Achlorhydria) and not with necrolytic migratory erythema.

questions.text: A forensic scientist is analyzing a DNA sample from a crime scene. The DNA is digested with restriction enzymes, separated by gel electrophoresis, and transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane. Labeled DNA probes are then used to detect specific fragments. Which technique is the scientist most likely using?
questions.solution:
RFLP involves DNA digestion with restriction enzymes, gel electrophoresis, transfer to a nitrocellulose membrane, hybridization with labeled probes, and visualization of fragments.

 

Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism (RFLP)

  • Variation in DNA fragment lengths due to differences in DNA sequences when digested with restriction enzymes are used as genetic markers.
  • Applications: Parenthood Disputes, Population Genetics, Genetic Disease Diagnosis, Genetic Mapping, Cloning, Forensic Medicine.

 

 

                          Sequential Steps involved using RFLP technique 
 

1. DNA Digestion

DNA is cut by restriction enzymes at specific sites.
 

2. Electrophoresis

DNA fragments are separated by size using gel electrophoresis.
 

3. Denaturation

To enable probe binding, the separated fragments are denatured
 

4. Southern Blotting

Fragments are transferred from the gel to a nitrocellulose membrane.
 

5. Hybridization

DNA fragments hybridize with labeled DNA probes.
 

6. Visualization

Hybridized fragments are visualized to reveal the presence or absence of restriction sites.


 

Option B: PCR is used to amplify DNA, not to analyze fragment length variations.

Option C: SSCP is used to detect variations in single-stranded DNA based on their conformational differences, not the length of restriction fragments.

Option D: DNA sequencing determines the nucleotide order, not the length variation of fragments after restriction enzyme digestion.

questions.text:
The patient presents to you with the following deformity as shown. Which is the ideal procedure of choice to correct this deformity?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Modified Bunnel’s operation

 

Explanation:

  • The deformity shown in the image is a partial claw hand - seen in ulnar nerve injury.
  • Modified Bunnel’s operation is the procedure of choice for ulnar claw hand.

 

Deformities in ulnar nerve injury:

Partial claw hand:
  • Clawing: Hyperextension of the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion of interphalangeal joints.
  • Clawing is seen in 2 medial fingers only.
  • Seen in pure ulnar nerve injury.
  • Also known as the true claw hand.

Complete claw hand:
  • Clawing of all 4 fingers.
  • Seen in combined median + ulnar nerve palsy

Tardy ulnar nerve palsy:
  • Slow-onset (over years) ulnar nerve palsy.
  • Seen with cubitus valgus deformity seen in lateral epicondyle humerus fracture.

Other deformities:
  • Wasting of hypothenar muscles & intrinsic muscles of the hand.
  • Hollow inter-metacarpal spaces in hand.

 

A) Ulnar clawing; B) Total clawing; C) Wasting of intermetacarpal spaces

 

Ulnar paradox:

  • The higher the lesion, the less severe the deformity.
  • Reason: Long finger flexors are paralyzed and loss of finger flexion makes the deformity less obvious.

 

Treatment of Ulnar claw hand:

Static procedure (removal)
  • Zancolli Lasso procedure

Dynamic procedures (tendon transfer)
  • Modified Bunnel technique
  • Brand’s operation
  • Fowler’s operation

 

Omer’s surgery (Option A) & Boye’s tendon transfer technique (Option B) are done for Radial nerve injury.

Triple arthrodesis (Option D): Done for CTEV & Foot drop.

questions.text:
The following are some steps taken to investigate an epidemic. Arrange the steps in the correct sequence.


	Verification of the diagnosis.
	Define the population at risk.
	Data analysis.
	Confirmation of the existence of an epidemic.
	Evaluation of ecological factors.
	Testing of hypothesis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1, 4, 2, 3, 6, 5

Explanation:

Steps in the investigation of an epidemic:

 

Steps

Salient points

1

Verification of diagnosis
  • Most important step
  • Examination of a sample of cases and verify the diagnosis
  • To avoid a spurious diagnosis based on signs and symptoms.

2

Confirmation of the existence of an epidemic
  • Compare data collected with the previous year's data.
  • Epidemic:
    • Occurrence > 2 S.D.
    • The cases occur at over 80% of the expected frequency.

3

Defining the population at risk
  • Obtain a map of the area affected.
  • A house-to-house survey is done to find the entire population at risk.

4

Rapid search for all cases and their characteristics
  • Medical survey.
  • Epidemiological case sheet.

5

Data analysis
  • Done in terms of Time, Place and person
  • Try to identify the type of epidemic by drawing the epidemic curve.

6

Formulation of hypothesis
  • It contains information about the agent, host, environment, modes of transmission, etc.
  • Formulation of a hypothesis is the work of descriptive epidemiology.

7

Testing of hypothesis
  • First step: Case-control study.
  • Second step: Plan a cohort study to compare the attack rates in exposed vs non-exposed groups.

8

Evaluation of ecological factors
  • Effect of humidity.
  • Effect of sanitary conditions.
  • Effect of water supply.

9

Further investigation of the population at risk
  • Keep looking for any other population that is at risk.

10

Writing the report
  • To provide a strategy at the end.
  • Prevent future occurrences.

The investigation of an epidemic can be stopped when no more cases occur for twice the incubation period of the disease from the occurrence of the last case.

questions.text: A patient with chronic renal failure and resistant oedema was treated with a drug that alleviated the oedema. However, increasing doses were needed over time. Although the drug remained effective, the patient developed involuntary hand twitching and perioral numbness. Which class of drug was given?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Loop diuretics

Explanation :

Involuntary hand twitching, along with perioral numbness, is suggestive of tetany due to hypocalcemia caused by loop diuretics.. High ceiling diuretics (loop diuretics), which are preferred in treating oedema (including resistant oedema and for rapid fluid mobilisation), impair the absorption of calcium ions, thus causing tetany.

  • Loop diuretics like furosemide primarily inhibit the Na⁺-K⁺-2Cl⁻ cotransporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, disrupting the reabsorption of sodium, chloride, and water, which normally generates a positive potential gradient in the tubule's lumen.

  • This abolishes the lumen-positive potential, reducing Ca²⁺ reabsorption and causing hypocalcemia.

Common Adverse Effects of loop diuretics (also seen with Thiazides, except for Calcium):

  • Hyponatremia → Hypotension
  • Hypokalemia → Muscle weakness increases the risk of digoxin toxicity
  • Hypocalcemia → Tetany (Thiazides usually increase calcium levels)
  • Hypomagnesemia → Pseudogout
  • Decrease in H+ ions → Metabolic alkalosis
  • Hyperuricemia → in high doses
  • Hyperglycemia and dyslipidemia
  • Ototoxicity

Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors(Option B): Weak diuretics, hence are not used in the treatment of edema.   

Thiazide Diuretics(Option C): They produce hypercalcemia by preserving calcium.  
Osmotic Diuretics(Option D): Contraindicated in renal failure.

questions.text:
In a rural village, trachoma remains a significant public health concern. A public health officer is tasked with implementing a comprehensive prevention strategy for trachoma. Match each intervention with the appropriate level of prevention:


	
		
			
			1. Primary Prevention
			
			
			a. Coordinates surgical treatment for blindness
			
		
		
			
			2. Secondary Prevention
			
			
			b. Promotes facial cleanliness and sanitation.
			
		
		
			
			3. Tertiary Prevention
			
			
			c. Ensures antibiotics are prescribed only to confirmed cases.
			
		
		
			
			4. Quaternary Prevention
			
			
			d. Conduct regular eye screenings.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c

Explanation:

Levels of Prevention in Trachoma:

Levels of Prevention

Description

Measures

Primary Prevention

Interventions before the onset of the disease to avert its occurrence by addressing the pre-pathogenesis phase.

Promotes facial cleanliness and sanitation to prevent trachoma.

Secondary Prevention

Aim to halt disease progression in its early stages and prevent complications through timely diagnosis (e.g., screening, case-finding) and prompt, appropriate treatment.

Conduct regular eye screenings to detect and treat trachoma early.

Tertiary Prevention

Focuses on minimizing the impact of existing health conditions by reducing impairments and disabilities, alleviating suffering, and promoting adjustment to irreversible states.

Coordinates surgical treatment for those with trachoma-related blindness.

Quaternary Prevention

Promoting evidence-based practices to prevent over diagnosis and offering ethically validated treatment options

Ensures antibiotics are prescribed only to confirmed cases to avoid unnecessary treatment.

questions.text: Based on the image, identify the structures indicated by the arrows

choices.text: Yellow: Sequestrum, White: Cloaca, Red: Involucrum
Yellow: Involucrum, White: Sequestrum, Red: Cloaca
Yellow: Cloaca, White: Involucrum, Red: Sequestrum
Yellow: Sequestrum, White: Involucrum, Red: Cloaca

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Yellow: Sequestrum, White: Involucrum, Red: Cloaca

Explanation:

  • Sequestrum (dead bone) appears radiopaque and is typically isolated within an area of infection, marked by the yellow arrow.
  • Involucrum (new bone formation around the sequestrum) is shown surrounding the area, marked by the white arrow.
  • Cloaca (an opening in the involucrum allowing pus drainage) is indicated by the red arrow.

Sequestrum

Involucrum

Cloaca
  • Definition: A piece of dead bone separated from living bone due to infection.
  • Formation: Occurs in neglected cases of acute osteomyelitis, resulting from tissue destruction.
  • Characteristics: Size varies; can range from small spicules to large necrotic segments of the cortex.
  • Clinical Significance: Remains entombed within the bone, inaccessible for destruction or repair.
  • Definition: New bone formation around the infected zone.
  • Formation: Develops on viable surfaces in the bone and from the deep layers of the stripped periosteum.
  • Characteristics: Initially porotic, becomes thicker to form a casing around the sequestrum and infected tissue.
  • Clinical Significance: Can help enclose and isolate the infection, but may lead to permanent deformity if healing is inadequate.
  • Definition: Perforations in the involucrum that allow discharge of pus and bone debris.
  • Formation: Develops as the infection persists, leading to small openings through which material can escape.
  • Characteristics: Creates a path for the pus to track through sinuses to the skin surface.
  • Clinical Significance: Indicates the chronicity of osteomyelitis, leading to intermittent discharge through sinuses.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male with a history of AIDS presents to the clinic with persistent fever, significant weight loss over the past month, and cough that has worsened over the last two weeks. He resides in a rural area of Southeast Asia, where he frequently encounters bamboo rats. On physical examination, he has cervical lymphadenopathy and hepatomegaly. A sputum sample is collected for microbiological examination. An image is shown below. Which of the following is characteristic of the colony that is likely to grow in culture from this patient’s sputum sample?


{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Green, granular colonies with a distinctive red pigment
Creamy white, smooth colonies and with a yeasty odour

questions.solution:
Answer: B) Green, granular colonies with a distinctive red pigment

 

Explanation:

Given the patient's symptoms, history of exposure to bamboo rats, and immunocompromised status due to AIDS, microscopy showing septate hyphae with branched conidiophores, the likely pathogen is Talaromyces marneffei. This fungus produces green, granular colonies with a distinctive red pigment that diffuses into the agar when cultured on Sabouraud agar, which is a characteristic feature of this organism.

Penicillium marneffei

Characteristics

Currently, the name is changed to Talaromyces marneffei.

Thermally dimorphic fungus

Causes

Talaromycosis (Penicilliosis)

Epidemiology

Common in Southeast Asia, southern China, and northeastern India.

High incidence in AIDS and immunocompromised patients.

Reservoir

Bamboo rat

Route of transmission

Inhalation of fungal spores

No person-to-person transmission

Clinical manifestations

It affects the reticuloendothelial system, causing lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, and splenomegaly.

Lung involvement is common.

Increased risk of dissemination in AIDS and immunocompromised individuals.

Specimens for Diagnosis

Bone marrow, blood, sputum, lymph nodes, skin lesions

Diagnosis

Culture on Sabouraud Agar:

  • Green, granular colonies with a distinctive red pigment that diffuses into the agar.

Microscopy:

  • Septate hyphae with branched conidiophores

showing a brush-like arrangement of spores

 

Additional Tests:

  • Antigen testing (urine/serum) and PCR

Treatment

Amphotericin B (IV for two weeks), followed by Itraconazole.

Others: Voriconazole, Posaconazole.

 

White, cottony, mycelial growth (Option A): It is typically associated with Histoplasma capsulatum. This option is incorrect.

 

Smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies (Option C): It is typically associated with Cryptococcus neoformans. This option is incorrect.

 

Creamy white, smooth colonies and with a yeasty odour (Option D): It is typically associated with Candida albicans. This option is incorrect.

questions.text:
Match the following.

 


	
		
			
			A. 

			
			
			
			1. Scaphocephaly
			
		
		
			
			B. 

			
			
			
			2. Plagiocephaly
			
		
		
			
			C. 

			
			
			
			3. Brachycephaly
			
		
		
			
			D. 

			
			
			
			4. Trigonocephaly
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) A-3, B-1, C-4, D-2

 

Explanation:

 

  • The above images illustrate the different types of craniosynostosis.
  • Craniosynostosis occurs when one or more skull sutures close prematurely, potentially leading to varying impacts on a child's neurodevelopment depending on the number of sutures affected and the severity of complications.

Posterior fontanelle: This smaller fontanelle at the back of the head usually closes within 2 months of birth.

Anterior fontanelle: This larger fontanelle at the top of the head usually closes between 7 and 18 months.

Scaphocephaly or dolichocephaly (premature fusion of the sagittal suture):

  • These patients have a long, narrow-shaped head with a higher anteroposterior diameter.

 

Anterior plagiocephaly (premature fusion of 1 coronal suture):

  • The forehead appears flat on the affected side, Harlequin sign (high supraorbital margins seen in radiographs), frontal bossing on the unaffected side, and nasal deviation towards the normal side.

 

Posterior plagiocephaly (premature fusion of 1 lambdoid suture):

  • Frontal and occipital bossing, ipsilateral ear moved downward, from above the head looks like a trapeze.

 

Trigonocephaly (premature fusion of the metopic suture):

  • The forehead is narrow and pointed; the head has a triangular shape viewed from above, hypotelorism.

 

Brachycephaly (bi-coronal premature fusion):

  • Short skull, forehead, and occiput flattened but the frontal bone is long (vertically) and prominent, hypertelorism, and Harlequin malformation.

questions.text: A patient has a urine concentration of a substance of 10 mg/mL, a urine flow rate of 2 mL/min, and a plasma concentration of that substance of 5 mg/mL. What is the clearance rate of this substance?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) 4 mL/min
 

Explanation:

 

Clearance measures the volume of plasma completely cleared of a substance by the kidneys per minute (mL/min), reflecting renal excretory efficiency. It is essential for evaluating kidney function, including filtration, reabsorption, and secretion processes.

 

To calculate the clearance rate (Cs) of the substance, use the formula:

Clearance Formula: (Cs) = (Us x V) / Ps

Us: Urine concentration of the substance

V: Urine flow rate

Ps: Plasma concentration of the substance

Plugging in the values:

Cs = (10 ×2)/5  = 4 ml /min

So, the clearance rate of the substance is 4 mL/min.

Types of Clearance Measurements:

 

Inulin Clearance
  • Used to measure Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) as it is freely filtered but not reabsorbed or secreted.
  • Not ideal for routine use due to intravenous administration.

Creatinine Clearance
  • Estimates GFR using creatinine, which is primarily filtered by the glomeruli.
  • Slightly inaccurate due to tubular secretion, but practical for clinical settings.

PAH Clearance
  • Estimates Renal Plasma Flow (RPF).
  • PAH is cleared through both glomerular filtration and tubular secretion.
  • Correction for PAH extraction ratio improves accuracy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with hot flashes, night sweats, and irregular menstrual cycles, suggesting a decrease in estrogen levels. Which of the following is a primary source of estrogen in premenopausal women, and which of the following is an effect of estrogen on the body?

choices.text: Adrenal cortex; Maintenance of bone density

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Granulosa cells, proliferation of endometrium

Explanation:

Estrogen is primarily secreted by ovaries in granulosa cells and one of its effects is proliferation of endometrium.
 

 

Estrogen

Progesterone

Source

Granulosa cells (Option C), corpus luteum, and placenta

Corpus luteum, placenta and ovarian follicles

Effects on female genitalia
  • Growth of ovarian follicle
  • Proliferation of endometrium (Option C)
  • Increase the motility of the uterine tubes
  • Increase blood flow in the uterus
  • Increase the amount of uterine muscle and contractility.
  • Antiestrogenic effect on the myometrium, decreasing their excitability
  • Secretory effect on the endometrium

Female Secondary Sex Characteristics
  • Enlargement of breasts
  • Female distribution of fat
  • Wide carrying angle
  • Stimulates the development of lobules and alveoli

Effects on the Central Nervous System
  • Increase libido
  • Increase the proliferation of dendrites on neurons and the number of synaptic knobs
  • Thermogenic and responsible for the rise in basal body temperature during ovulation

Effects on Endocrine Organs
  • Increased secretion of angiotensinogen and thyroid-binding globulin
  • Large doses of progesterone inhibit LH secretion and potentiate the inhibitory effect of estrogens, preventing ovulation.

Other effects
  • Retention of salt and water and gain weight just before menstruation
  • Plasma cholesterol-lowering action
  • Vasodilation by increasing the local production of NO.
  • Maintains bone mineral density
  • Stimulates respiration, and the alveolar PCO2
  • Increases plasma LDL and decreases HDL (Option D)

Adrenal cortex; Maintenance of bone density (Option A) The amount of progestin, androgen, and estrogen produced by the adrenal cortex is a minor fraction of the total amount produced in the body. Hence, not the primary source of estrogen.

 

Hepatocytes; enlargement of breast (Option B) Hepatocytes are not involved in estrogen production. Breast enlargement is an effect of estrogen.

 

Corpus luteum, decreases HDL cholesterol (Option D) Corpus luteum secretes more progesterone than estrogen.

questions.text: A patient is asked to hold a piece of paper between their thumb and index finger. When the examiner attempts to pull the paper away, the patient tries to hold the paper as shown in the image. Based on this observation, which muscle is likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Adductor pollicis

 

Explanation:

In this scenario, the patient flexes the distal phalanx of the thumb to grip the paper when the examiner attempts to pull it away, indicating weakness in the adductor pollicis muscle, which is innervated by the ulnar nerve, thereby confirming a positive Froment's test.

 

Froment’s test:

  • Tests Adductor pollicis supplied by Ulnar nerve.
  • The patient is asked to hold a piece of paper (or a card) between the thumb and index finger of the affected hand & card is pulled out.
  • Positive Result: If the patient flexes the distal phalanx of the thumb while attempting to hold the paper, it indicates weakness of the adductor pollicis muscle due to ulnar nerve dysfunction. This flexion occurs due to flexor pollicis longus innervated by the median nerve.

Flexor pollicis brevis (Option A) primarily flexes the thumb without significantly contributing to grip strength.

Abductor pollicis brevis (Option B) aids in thumb abduction.

Opponents pollicis (Option D) facilitates thumb opposition.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a congenital cause of thrombosis?
questions.solution: PNH is an acquired cause of thrombosis that produces defective platelets causing platelet activation and inactivation of fibrinolytic system due to defect in PIGA gene.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with a history of extensive small bowel resection due to necrotizing enterocolitis is diagnosed with short bowel syndrome. Which among the following surgical procedures can help increase the bowel length and potentially reduce the dependency on parenteral nutrition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bianchi procedure

 

Explanation:

  • The Bianchi procedure/ Longitudinal intestinal lengthening and tailoring (LILT) is recognised as an effective surgical treatment for short bowel syndrome (SBS).
  • Bianchi initially described the procedure for intestinal lengthening where the mesenteric vascular bed is divided into two systems.
  • The enlarged small intestine is split into two parallel segments, each with its own blood supply, and then reconnected.
  • This technique reduces the small intestine's diameter by 50% and doubles its length.

 

Whipple Procedure ( Pancreaticoduodenectomy), Billroth I and II procedures and Ileostomy (Option B, C and D) don't involve intestinal lengthening

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is evaluated at a fertility clinic due to difficulty conceiving. A transvaginal ultrasound shows a follicle with a large fluid-filled antrum and a well-defined cumulus oophorus. Which stage of follicle maturation does this represent?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Graafian follicle

 

Explanation:

The Graafian follicle (Mature Follicle) is the final stage before ovulation. It is characterised by a large fluid-filled antrum and a well-defined cumulus oophorus surrounding the oocyte. This stage indicates that the follicle is fully mature and ready to release the oocyte during ovulation.

  • Primordial Follicle (Option C): The initial stage where follicles are in a dormant state. These consist of a primary oocyte surrounded by a single layer of squamous granulosa cells.
  • Primary Follicle (Option A): The primordial follicle matures into a primary follicle where the granulosa cells become cuboidal, and the zona pellucida forms around the oocyte.
  • Secondary Follicle (Option B): The primary follicle grows larger, forming multiple layers of granulosa cells, and small fluid-filled spaces begin to appear. The theca interna and externa layers develop around the follicle.
  • Tertiary Follicle (Antral Follicle): The secondary follicle further develops as the fluid-filled spaces coalesce to form an antrum. The granulosa cells form the cumulus oophorus surrounding the oocyte.

Stages of Follicle Maturation:

Primordial Follicle

↓

Primary Follicle

↓

Secondary Follicle

↓

Tertiary Follicle (Antral Follicle)

↓

Graafian Follicle (Mature Follicle)

questions.text: 30-year-old lady is admitted due to polytrauma. On day 3 of admission, she develops sudden onset breathing difficulty and spO2 is 70% on room air. On examination pulse is 120/min BP 100/80 mm Hg with loud S1 and wide split S2. Which of the following is first test to be done in this case?
questions.solution: The patient is having pulmonary embolism as evidenced by wide split S2 that indicates RVF. Fat embolism does not cause heart failure but non cardiogenic pulmonary edema. Hence option A is ruled out. Option C will not help in arrival at diagnosis. Option D is IOC of pulmonary embolism but is done after D- Dimer assay.

questions.text: A 27-week gestational-age preterm infant in the NICU experiences persistent apnea lasting over 20 seconds despite gentle tactile stimulation and supplemental oxygen. Nasal continuous positive airway pressure (nCPAP) has been used but has not resolved the episodes. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Continue nasal continuous positive airway pressure (nCPAP)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Administer intravenous caffeine citrate

 

Explanation:

  • Caffeine is the treatment of choice for recurrent or persistent apnea of prematurity that does not respond to initial measures like tactile stimulation or nCPAP.
  • It increases central respiratory drive, lowers the threshold for response to hypercapnia, enhances diaphragmatic contractility, and prevents diaphragmatic fatigue.

 

Management of Apnea of Prematurity:

  • For mild and intermittent episodes: Gentle tactile stimulation or provision of supplemental oxygen by nasal cannula is often sufficient.
  • If apnea episodes are more frequent or prolonged, nasal continuous positive airway pressure (nCPAP) or heated humidified high-flow nasal cannula (HHHFNC) can be used to maintain airway patency.
  • For recurrent or persistent apnea:
    • Methylxanthines (e.g., caffeine) are preferred because they effectively stimulate respiratory drive and reduce the incidence and severity of apnea.
    • Caffeine aids in extubation and lowers Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) risk with fewer side effects than theophylline.
    • It is safe for oral or intravenous use with a wide therapeutic window and minimal need for serum monitoring.

 

Continuing nCPAP (Option A) is beneficial for managing obstructive or mixed apnea by maintaining airway patency but is less effective for central apnea. Since the apnea persists despite nCPAP, additional pharmacological intervention is needed.

 

Initiate doxapram infusion (Option C): Doxapram is a respiratory stimulant but is less commonly used due to side effects and is typically considered only if methylxanthines are ineffective.

 

Start low-dose theophylline (Option D): Theophylline is another methylxanthine but is less preferred than caffeine due to a shorter half-life and higher risk of side effects d/t narrow therapeutic range (5-15 microgram), such as tachycardia and feeding intolerance.

questions.text:
The image shows a 16 year old boy brought to the clinic by his father with an unusual pattern of hair loss. History states that he has become increasingly reclusive, avoiding family gatherings and showing less interest in his usual hobbies spending most of his time alone in his room. The boy himself appears unaware of the issue and has no complaints.



 

What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Trichotillomania


Explanation:

The boy with the above history and a characteristic Friar Tuck hair loss pattern has trichotillomania.

Trichotillomania:

  • It is a psychiatric disorder in which obsessive, recurrent pulling of one’s hair results in hair loss.
  • It is seen in adolescents or young adults, more commonly in girls.
  • Patchy hair loss with broken hair of variable lengths is seen in commonly accessible sites like the frontoparietal area of the scalp.
  • In the Friar Tuck sign or Tonsure pattern, there is uneven hair loss in a circular pattern with surrounding hairs remaining unaffected.

  • Perifollicular hemorrhages can also be seen because of trauma to the scalp.
  • Skin biopsy shows empty hair follicles, with some forming soft twisted hairs described as tracheomalacia.
  • Treatment includes cognitive behavioral therapy and antipsychotic medications like SSRI and paroxetine.
  • Trichobezoar/ Rapunzel syndrome is caused by chronic ingestion of hair; it is commonly seen in young females who may have psychological disorders, such as trichophagia and trichotillomania. Common symptoms are abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and weight loss.

Netherton syndrome (Option D) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the serine protease inhibitor. Characteristic triad includes,

  • Congenital Ichtyosiform erythroderma.
  • Trichorrhexis invaginata (Bamboo hair).
  • Atopic diathesis.

Alopecia areata (Option B) is an autoimmune condition where the immune system mistakenly attacks hair follicles, leading to sudden, round patches of hair loss. This is not consistent with the given clinical scenario.

Pseudopelade of Brocq (Option C) is a chronic and slowly progressive idiopathic condition with no inflammation, scaling, or erythema.

  • Smooth patches due to scarring alopecia.
  • Footprint in snow appearance-spreading patches of cicatricial alopecia.

questions.text:
Given below are a few statements on various kinds of autopsy. Which of them is true?


	A psychological autopsy is done after suicide.
	Virtopsy combines 2D surface scanning/CAD photogrammetry with radiologic imaging like MRI.
	Psychological autopsy involves data collection.
	The ability to identify the infection status of antemortem from postmortem wounds is limited in Virtopsy.
	Easy to identify postmortem artifacts using Virtopsy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All except 2 and 5

 

Explanation:

 

Virtual autopsy/Virtopsy

Virtopsy is a non-invasive alternative to traditional autopsy using imaging instead of physical dissection.

Technology
  • Utilizes 3D surface scanning, MSCT, MRI, and CAD photogrammetry to create a digital, objective record. (Option D)
  • This can be shared online for secondary opinions and presented as evidence in court if required.

Features
  • Provides high-resolution, colored 3D images in various sections
  • Allows visualization of body surfaces, deeper tissues, organs, coronary vessels, pulmonary emboli, soft tissue trauma, and bone injuries

Limitations
  • High cost of equipment
  • Radiologic imaging limitations, interference from metal
  • Limited ability to distinguish internal organ colors
  • Incomplete database for diagnosis
  • Challenges in identifying infection status, antemortem vs. postmortem wounds (Options B and C ruled out)
  • Difficulty in identifying postmortem artifacts and subtle tissue injuries, and differentiating certain pathological conditions (Option D)

 

Psychological autopsy - Meticulous collection of data after someone’s suicide to understand the circumstances of their death.

questions.text: A 10-day-old preterm infant, born at 30 weeks of gestation, presents with sudden abdominal distension and a bluish discoloration of the abdominal wall. questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with a history of weight loss, mediastinal lymphadenopathy, and pleural effusion. HRCT shows a "tree-in-bud" appearance with lung consolidation and effusion. Pleural fluid analysis reveals low ADA levels and lymphocytic predominance. What is the most likely finding on a biopsy from the lymph node?
questions.solution: Clinical history plus CT findings plus lymphocytosis is highly suggestive of tuberculosis etiology. High Adenosine levels are diagnostic of pleural TB but low levels do not rule out TB. Fungal etiology in immunocompetent patient is highly unlikely. Answer is necrotizing epithelioid granuloma which is characteristic finding of TB. High endemicity of TB is another reason for favoring this option.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with brief, abrupt, involuntary movements of his arms and face for the last 2 months. A history of Huntington's disease in his father, who was diagnosed at 40 years of age and passed away at the age of 50, is found. What is the mechanism behind this patient’s earlier presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Anticipation

 

Explanation:

  • HD is a CAG trinucleotide repeat disorder, seen in the axon region of a gene present on chromosome 4.
  • HD is characterised by the Anticipation/Sherman Paradox.
  • The number of repeats increases with every generation, leading to early and more severe presentation in the next generation.
  • HD features psychiatric disturbances and choreoathetosis early on, with cognitive disturbance and death later.

Examples of diseases showing anticipation include:

Autosomal Dominant

Autosomal Recessive
  • Multiple spinocerebellar ataxias
  • Huntington’s disease – CAG repeats
  • Myotonic dystrophy – CTG
  • Congenital dyskeratosis – TTAGGG (telomere repeating sequence)

Friedreich’s ataxia – GAA

X-linked

Fragile X Syndrome – CGG

Others
  • Crohn’s disease
  • Behcet’s disease


Mosaicism (Option B) refers to the presence of multiple genetically different cell lines in the same individual.

Imprinting (Option C) refers to a gene silencing.

Non-penetrance (Option D): It means that the Gene is received from parents but no symptoms are seen in patient.

questions.text:
A hospital administrator wants to determine if there is a significant association between the type of hospital ward (General, Intensive Care, and Pediatric) and the number of patients who experienced postoperative infections. The data collected over a month is as follows:

 


	
		
			
			Ward
			
			
			Patients with infections
			
			
			Patients without infections
			
			
			Total
			
		
		
			
			General
			
			
			20
			
			
			80
			
			
			100
			
		
		
			
			Intensive Care
			
			
			30
			
			
			70
			
			
			100
			
		
		
			
			Pediatric
			
			
			10
			
			
			90
			
			
			100
			
		
		
			
			Total
			
			
			60
			
			
			240
			
			
			300
			
		
	


 

Using the Chi-Square test, what is the expected number of patients with infections in the General Ward if there is no association between the ward type and infection status?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 20

Explanation:


The expected number for each cell in a Chi-square test is calculated by multiplying the row total by the column total and dividing by the grand total.

The formula for the expected frequency in a cell is: E=(Row Total)×(Column Total) / Grand Total

For the General ward and infections:

= (Total patients in General ward x Total patients with infections) / Total number of patients

= (100 x 60) / 300

= 6000 / 300

= 20

questions.text: A 29-year-old pregnant woman in her third trimester is evaluated by her obstetrician for routine prenatal care. She reports occasional palpitations and mild shortness of breath but has no significant past medical history. The physician explains that these symptoms can be related to normal cardiac changes in pregnancy. Which of the following is a physiological cardiac change typically observed during pregnancy?

choices.text: Decreased cardiac output due to reduced blood volume
Increased systemic vascular resistance leading to hypertension
Increased cardiac output primarily due to increased heart rate and stroke volume
Decreased heart rate due to increased vagal tone

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Increased cardiac output primarily due to increased heart rate and stroke volume


Explanation:
During pregnancy, the heart rate increases by up to 17%, and the stroke volume increases by up to 27%. As a result of this, Cardiac Output increases as

  • Cardiac Output = Heart Rate x Stroke Volume.

Decreased cardiac output due to reduced blood volume (Option A): Cardiac output is not decreased, but it is increased in pregnancy

Increased systemic vascular resistance leading to hypertension (Option B): There is a decrease in systemic vascular resistance, so BP falls during pregnancy.

Decreased heart rate due to increased vagal tone (Option D): There is increase in heart rate during pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Behçet's disease is incorrect?

It is associated with a higher risk of thrombosis

questions.solution: Behcet disease has genital ulcers on scrotum and not on penis. Option A is diagnostic criteria. Pathergy test causes pustule to form after 24-48 hours. Endoscopic findings of Behcet and Crohn’s can be similar. Option D can be explained by vasculitis.
