Assists in glucose uptake

GLUT 4

Heart and skeletal muscle, adipose tissue

Mediates insulin-stimulated glucose uptake

GLUT 5

Small intestine

Facilitates fructose absorption

SGLT 1

Small intestine and kidney

Actively transports glucose against a concentration gradient

 

GLUT 1-5 are facilitative bidirectional transporters, whereas SGLT 1 is a sodium-dependent unidirectional transporter.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman at 34 weeks of gestation presents for a routine prenatal visit. She reports no pain, contractions, or bleeding. An ultrasound performed at 20 weeks showed a placenta previa that remained stable on follow-up ultrasound. What should be the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Immediate hospitalisation and preparation for emergency C-section
Expectant management with periodic transvaginal ultrasounds (TVS) and implementation of the McAfee Johnson regimen
Administration of magnesium sulfate for fetal neuroprotection and immediate delivery
Routine follow-up with monthly abdominal ultrasounds without activity restrictions

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Expectant management with periodic transvaginal ultrasounds (TVS) and implementation of the McAfee Johnson regimen

 

Explanation:

The recommended management involves expectant management in a stable case of placenta previa with no active bleeding or other complications. This includes periodic Transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) monitoring and following the McAfee and Johnson regimen.

 

McAfee and Johnson regime:

It is an expectant management strategy for patients with placenta previa to ensure maternal and fetal safety while aiming to prolong the pregnancy.

 

Indications:
  • The mother is healthy (Hb >10 g % and haematocrit > 30%).
  • Absence of active vaginal bleeding.
  • Gestational age <37 weeks.
  • Reactive CTG.

Steps in McAfee and Johnson regime:
  1. Hospitalise the patient (Bed rest).
  2. Monitoring:
    1. Maternal vitals.
    2. Fetal heart sounds.
    3. Bleeding.
  3. Arrange for blood.
  4. If the patient is Rh (-ve), anti-D should be given.
  5. Injection of corticosteroids to hasten lung maturity of the fetus.
  6. Short-term tocolytic (nifedipine) should be provided if any contractions are present.
  7. If pregnancy <32 weeks: MgSO4 (neural protection).
 

The above-mentioned steps are continued till 37 weeks, after which elective cesarean section can be done.

 

Immediate hospitalisation and preparation for emergency C-section (Option A): No need for now since no bleeding, pain or contractions.

Administration of magnesium sulfate for fetal neuroprotection and immediate delivery (Option C): MgSO4 only in case of extreme preterms and no indication for immediate delivery for now. 

Routine follow-up with monthly abdominal ultrasounds without activity restrictions (Option D): No need of monthly scans and it is advised to avoid exertion.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with dysphagia, throat pain, and a palpable neck mass. Laryngoscopy reveals a lesion on the epiglottis. Further investigations lead to the diagnosis of Laryngeal carcinoma.Which of the following is not a typical characteristic of this condition?

choices.text: Bilateral lymph node metastases are common but occurs late
Hoarseness is usually a late symptom
The most common histological type is squamous cell carcinoma
It may spread to the pre-epiglottic space

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bilateral lymph node metastases are common but occurs late

 

Explanation:

The involvement of epiglottis in laryngeal carcinoma is indicative of supraglottic laryngeal carcinoma, in which nodal metastases occur early and are commonly bilateral.

Supraglottic Laryngeal Carcinoma:

Incidence

Less frequent than glottic cancer; about 30-35% of all laryngeal cancers

Site

Majority on epiglottis, false cords, followed by aryepiglottic folds

Vocal cord involvement

Usually late; vocal cords often spared in early stages

Lymphatic spread
  • Early and often bilateral
  • Upper and middle jugular nodes commonly involved
  • Cancer of infrahyoid epiglottis & anterior ventricular band may extend into pre-epiglottic space (Option D)

Symptoms
  • Early: Often silent, dysphagia, throat pain
  • Late: Hoarseness, weight loss, respiratory obstruction, halitosis (Option B)

Histopathology
  • 90-95% squamous cell carcinoma (Option C)
  • Others include verrucous carcinoma, spindle cell carcinoma
  • Highly anaplastic

Prognosis

Generally worse than glottic cancer due to:

  • Late diagnosis
  • High rate & early lymph node metastasis
  • Anaplastic nature

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of High anion gap metabolic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Causes of HAGMA

Causes of NAGMA

KULT: mnemonic

DR FUSE: mnemonic
  • Ketoacidosis
  • Uremia- AKI, ATN
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Toxins
  • Inborn errors of metabolism like organic acidemia, pyruvate decarboxylase deficiency etc.
  • Diarrhea
  • Renal tubular acidosis
  • Fistula
  • Ureterosigmoidostomy

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and anosmia. A CT scan reveals an invasive mass in the nasal cavity, and a biopsy confirms the diagnosis of olfactory neuroblastoma. Which classification system is commonly used to stage olfactory neuroblastoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Kadish Classification

 

Explanation:

Kadish Classification is the most widely used system for staging olfactory neuroblastoma.

 

Olfactory Neuroblastoma (Esthesioneuroblastoma):

  • Originates from the Olfactory Epithelium in the upper third of the nasal cavity which is characterised by neuroblastic differentiation and can be locally aggressive with a tendency to invade adjacent structures.
  • Bimodal peaks of incidence (10-20 years & 50-60 years)
  • Symptoms:
    • Early Symptoms: Unilateral nasal obstruction and epistaxis (nosebleeds).
    • Advanced Symptoms: Tumour invades the orbit or surrounding structures, causing proptosis, headache, epiphora, diplopia, and blurred vision.
    • Metastasis: Lymph node metastases in the neck can occur in 10-15% of cases.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Intranasal or Endoscopic Examination:
      • Reveals a friable, cherry-red, polypoidal mass
      • Highly vascular, so biopsy should be preceded by imaging studies.
    • Imaging Studies:
      • CT Scan: Shows tumour extent, and possible erosion of cribriform plate/orbital wall.
      • MRI: Detects orbital or intracranial extension.
    • Biopsy: Confirms the tumour type; it may be low-grade with pseudorosette formation or high-grade with nuclear pleomorphism but no rosette formation.
  • Treatment: Craniofacial resection, with or without preoperative radiation or chemotherapy, followed by adjuvant radiation for advanced cases.

 

  • Staging Systems: Kadish Staging System (with Morita’s Modification):

Stage A

Tumour limited to the nasal cavity.

Stage B

Tumour involving the nasal cavity and sinuses.

Stage C

Tumour extending beyond the nasal and paranasal sinuses.

Stage D

Tumor with metastasis to cervical nodes or distant sites.

 

  • Other Staging Systems:
    • Morita’s Staging System
    • Dulguerov and Calcaterra Staging System

 

Breslow Classification (Option B) is used for staging melanoma based on the thickness of the tumor.

 

Ann Arbor Staging Classification (Option C) is used for staging lymphomas.

 

Gleason Classification (Option D) is used for grading prostate cancer based on the pattern of tumor cells.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with a 2-week history of worsening bilateral eye redness, itching, and frequent lacrimation. On examination, hypertrophied, cobblestone-like papillae is seen on the palpebral conjunctiva. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis


Explanation:

  • Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis is the most likely diagnosis given the patient’s age, the characteristic findings of cobblestone-like papillae on the palpebral conjunctiva
  • It commonly affects young children and adolescents, presenting with symptoms such as itching, burning, and lacrimation, and often worsens during warm weather.
     

Vernal keratoconjunctivitis or Spring catarrh

It is a recurrent bilateral conjunctivitis that tends to occur with the onset of warm weather. It primarily affects young children and adolescents, particularly boys.

Course

The condition typically starts in childhood and may resolve on its own over 5–10 years.

Symptoms

Burning, Itching, Photophobia (sensitivity to light), and lacrimation (excessive tearing).

Signs
  • Palpebral Form: Hypertrophied palpebral conjunctiva with a cobblestone appearance;dense fibrous tissue with thickened epithelium.
  • Limbal or Bulbar Form: Opacification at the limbus, gelatinous thickening, and Horner–Trantas dots
  • Pseudogerontoxon/cupid’s bow (which resembles arcus senilis) is a grayish-white ring at the limbus seen in severe limbal vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC).
 
  • Shield ulcers are a significant complication of VKC, particularly in severe cases. These microerosions typically form on the upper third of the cornea.
 
  • Mixed form: Exhibits characteristics of both the tarsal (palpebral) and limbal subtypes, typically presenting in only one eye.
 

Maxwell Lyon's sign is a pseudomembrane formed due to excessive mucus deposition on the papilla resulting in cobblestone papillae.

Histology

In the palpebral form, hypertrophied papillae are observed, rich in eosinophils and other inflammatory cells.

Treatment
  • Topical therapy:
    • Antihistamines - Levocabastine & emedastine
    • Mast cell stabilizers - Sodium cromoglicate
    • Mild steroids - Fluorometholone and loteprednol etabonate,
    • Acetylcysteine can control excess mucus.
  • Local therapy: Subtarsal steroid injections and cryotherapy for severe cases.
  • Surgical treatment: Excision of giant papillae and treatment of shield ulcers with debridement and amniotic membrane or bandage contact lens.
  • Cold compresses and tinted glasses for comfort.
  • Avoid eye rubbing

 

Atopic Keratoconjunctivitis (Option A) presents as a severe ocular surface disorder associated with a history of atopic diseases. It is more chronic and typically affects older children and adults.

 

Bacterial Conjunctivitis (Option C) presents with purulent discharge and often includes a fever or systemic signs. The given presentation does not favor this diagnosis.

 

Chlamydial Conjunctivitis (Option D) often involves a history of sexual contact or transmission and typically affects older children and adults. It usually presents with severe symptoms and sometimes includes a discharge with lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: eGFR grade 3 A is?
Which of the following infections is NOT detected using a Pap smear?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chlamydia trachomatis

Explanation:

Chlamydia trachomatis is not detected using a Pap smear. It requires specific nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs) or other swab-based tests.

 

 

Infections Detected using Pap Smear:

  1. Human Papillomavirus (HPV): Identifies cellular changes, specifically dysplasia, at the transformation zone, often caused by HPV infection. HPV is determined through further testing, such as HPV DNA testing. (Option A)
  2. Trichomonas: Grey-green color. (Option D)
  3. Candida (Yeast Infection): Stains red. (Option C)
  4. Herpes simplex virus (HSV): Identified by the presence of multinucleated giant cells and other cytopathic effects.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old male with asthma presents to the emergency department with worsening shortness of breath and wheezing. He is placed on supplemental oxygen and bronchodilators.

What is the most likely Capnographic waveform for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option C

Explanation:

  • The capnographic waveform shows a characteristic Shark fin appearance.
  • This occurs in Bronchospasms (asthma, COPD exacerbation), partially obstructed ET tube, or breathing circuit.

 

Different Types of Capnographic Waveforms:

 

A normal wave in controlled mechanical ventilation

 

Normal wave during spontaneous breathing

Bronchospasm (asthma, COPD exacerbation) / partially obstructed ET tube or breathing circuit

  • Shark fin appearance

 

Spontaneous breathing effort during controlled mechanical ventilation (Curare notch)

  • Curare cleft, or notch, is seen during spontaneous ventilation.
  • Patients partially paralyzed with muscle relaxants may make respiratory efforts at any time during the respiratory cycle with controlled ventilation.
  • As the muscle relaxant is reversed, the curve becomes normal in shape. (Option D ruled out)

 

Role in Intubation:

  • End tidal is used as the gold standard for confirmation of endotracheal tube position.
  • Esophageal intubation can initially produce an EtCO2 due to gastric CO2 however this should taper after a few breaths.
  • Right main-stem intubation may still have a normal EtCO2, so get a CXR to confirm optimal tube positioning.

Role during Cardiac Arrest:

  • EtCO2 > 20 suggests good quality CPR.
  • If it starts to drop, consider switching compressors or making sure the LUCUS is in the appropriate position.
  • A sudden increase in EtCO2 greater than 10 from the patient’s baseline can be an early indication of ROSC.

Hypoventilation (Option A ruled out)

Hyperventilation (Option B ruled out)

Flat Capnogram: Sudden and abrupt fall of EtCO2 to zero can be seen in:

  • Accidental extubation (most common)
  • Disconnection of CO2 transducer
  • Sudden cardiac arrest
  • Massive pulmonary embolism

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a severe migraine headache that has been ongoing for several hours. She reports that her headache is accompanied by nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. She has tried over-the-counter pain relievers without relief. What medication would you prescribe to help alleviate her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Sumatriptan

Explanation:

Sumatriptan is a more potent and specific migraine treatment that provides superior pain relief than paracetamol.

Mechanism of Action
  • It is a selective 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonist that activates other subtypes of 5-HT1 receptors only at very high concentrations.
  • Inhibits the release of calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) and causes cranial vasoconstriction.

Administration and Efficacy
  • It is administered at the onset of a migraine attack and is as effective and better tolerated than ergotamine.
  • About 3/4 of patients obtain complete or significant relief within 2-3 hours.
  • Available in various formulations such as Oral tablets, Nasal sprays, Injections, and Rectal suppositories.

Pharmacokinetics
  • Oral bioavailability of only 15% and S.C. administration is absorbed rapidly and completely
  • Rapidly metabolised by the MAO-A isoenzyme
  • Metabolites are excreted in urine, with an elimination half-life of approximately 2 hours.

Side Effects
  • Tightness in the head and chest, a feeling of heat, and other paresthesias in the limbs, dizziness, and weakness. 
  • Usually mild and short-lasting, but can be dose-related.

Paracetamol (Option B): It is not effective enough for treating moderate to severe migraine pain. 

Telotristat (Option C): It is not indicated for treating acute migraine attacks. It is used to treat carcinoid syndrome diarrhoea.

Morphine (Option D): It is not recommended for migraine due to its side effects and potential for abuse. Opioids like morphine are generally not considered first-line treatments for migraine.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about aflatoxicosis?

choices.text: The G1 variant is not associated with hepatocellular carcinoma
The B1 variant can commonly be associated with infantile cirrhosis
The minimum temperature that favours toxin formation is 18 degrees C
Keeping moisture content <22% is recommended for prevention

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The B1 variant can commonly be associated with infantile cirrhosis

Explanation:

The B1 variant of aflatoxins can be responsible for the occurrence of infantile cirrhosis, as evidenced by the detection of the same in breast milk and also in the urine of the affected infants

 

Aflatoxicosis

Clinical features
  • Features of hepatotoxicity (jaundice, hepatomegaly)
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma

Causative agent
  • Infestation of Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus over stored rice, wheat, and corn
  • Produce mycotoxins: aflatoxin B1 & G1 (both are hepatotoxic & carcinogenic) (Option A)

Risk factors
  • Storage temperature of 11 to 37 degree Celsius (Option C)
  • Moisture content >16%

Prevention
  • Educating people
  • Moisture content <10% during storage (Option D)

questions.text: A 60 y/o man presents with watery eyes, redness, swelling at the inner corner of his right eye, and persistent thick yellow discharge. O/E there is pouting of lacrimal puncta and yellow granules from the punctum upon massage. Which organism is most likely responsible, and what is the definitive treatment?

choices.text: Eikenella corrodens; Oral antibiotics and steroid drops.
Staphylococcus aureus; Topical antibiotics and warm compresses
Chlamydia trachomatis; Irrigation and syringing of the tear duct.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Actinomyces israelii; Canaliculotomy

Explanation:

  • Canaliculitis is diagnosed based on symptoms and clinical findings.
  • Actinomyces israelii is the most common cause of canaliculitis with yellow granules.
  • Canaliculotomy is the definitive treatment to remove concretions and resolve the infection.
  • It involves accessing and cleaning out the canaliculus to remove concretions and ensure thorough treatment of the infection.

 

Canaliculitis:

  • Canaliculitis is an inflammation or infection of the lacrimal canaliculus.

Causes:

  • Bacterial infection- most commonly Actinomyces israelii
  • Other bacteria: Staphylococcus, Streptococcus, Eikenella, Lactococcus, Nocardia
  • Fungal infections.
  • Viral infections.

Symptoms:

  • Eye-watering & discharge.
  • Swelling and redness near the corner of the eye
  • Pouting or swollen lacrimal punctum
  • Mattering on the eyelids
  • Expression of yellow granules, concretions, or stones from the punctum when massaged

Treatment:

  • Initial: Topical and systemic antibiotics, warm compresses, local massage, irrigation and syringing of the tear duct
  • Definitive: Surgery often required for effective treatment
    • Canaliculotomy for direct access and curettage. Safe and effective procedure.
    • Punctal dilation or punctoplasty with curettage
    • Canaliculoplasty with intubation to avoid scarring
  • Follow-up with antibiotic treatment and addressing underlying causes, such as a loose punctal plug

 

Eikenella corrodens; Oral antibiotics and steroid drops (Option A): Eikenella corrodens is less common than Actinomyces israelii for canaliculitis. The treatment listed (oral antibiotics and steroid drops) is not definitive for this condition but rather a part of initial management.

Staphylococcus aureus; Topical antibiotics and warm compresses (Option B): Staphylococcus aureus can cause canaliculitis, but Actinomyces israelii is more common. The treatment mentioned (topical antibiotics and warm compresses) is not sufficient for definitive management but is a part of initial management.

Chlamydia trachomatis; Irrigation and syringing of the tear duct (Option D): Chlamydia trachomatis is not typically responsible for canaliculitis with yellow granules. Irrigation and syringing alone are part of initial management.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presented with skin lesions, as shown in the image. On examination, bilateral ulnar and lateral popliteal nerves were enlarged.  According to the National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP) Guidelines, what would be the most appropriate treatment for the child on day 1?

choices.text: Rifampicin 600 mg Clofazimine 300 mg Dapsone 100 mg

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) ﻿﻿﻿Rifampicin 450 mg Clofazimine 150 mg Dapsone 50 mg

Explanation:

A 12-year-old child presents with clinical features suggestive of multibacillary (MB) leprosy:

  • Multiple papules and nodules on the face

  • Nodular thickening of the earlobes

These are classical features of MB leprosy (high bacterial load and involvement of skin and nerves), requiring multibacillary multidrug therapy (MB-MDT) as per National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP) guidelines in India.

 

NATIONAL LEPROSY ERADICATION PROGRAMME (NLEP)

Cardinal Features

Paucibacillary

Multibacillary

Skin: Hypopigmented/hypo-anaesthetic patches

1-5

>1

Nerves Thickened +/- Tenderness

 No nerve / only one nerve with or without 1 to 5 lesions

          >1

SSS AFB

Absent

Present
  • ﻿﻿The presence of one of the three signs can establish the diagnosis of leprosy.

Treatment

TREATMENT OF HANSEN’S DISEASE (WHO REGIME)

Drugs

PB

MB

Rifampicin

600 mg once a month

600 mg once a month

Dapsone

100mg daily

100mg daily

Clofazimine

300mg once a month 50mg daily

300mg once a month 50mg daily

Duration

6 months

12 months

 

Rifampicin 600 mg, Clofazimine 300 mg, Dapsone 100 mg (Option B): is incorrect because these are adult MB-MDT doses, appropriate for individuals ≥15 years. A 12-year-old would be overdosed with these amounts, especially with 600 mg Rifampicin and 100 mg Dapsone.

Rifampicin 450 mg, Clofazimine 150 mg, Dapsone 100 mg (Option C): is incorrect because although the Rifampicin and Clofazimine doses are correct for a 10–14-year-old, Dapsone 100 mg is double the recommended dose for this age group (should be 50 mg), posing a risk of haemolysis, particularly in G6PD-deficient children.

Rifampicin 300 mg, Clofazimine 150 mg, Dapsone 50 mg (Option D): is incorrect because Rifampicin 300 mg is under-dosed for a 12-year-old; this dose is intended for children under 10 years.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man complains of difficulty moving his arms and states that they feel "stiff." Upon examination, both arms show increased resistance to passive movement. The resistance is present throughout the range of motion and does not change with the speed of movement. What is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Lesion of the extrapyramidal tract

 

Explanation:

 

  • Rigidity is defined as an increased resistance to passive movement that is not velocity-dependent, meaning the resistance remains constant regardless of the speed of movement.
  • Rigidity is a feature of extrapyramidal lesions.

 

Feature

Spasticity

Rigidity

Definition

Velocity-dependent resistance

Velocity-independent resistance

Mechanism

Lesion of the pyramidal tract (Option C)

Lesion of the extrapyramidal tract

Clinical Finding

Resistance increases with speed

Resistance is continuous and does not vary with the speed of movement

Example

Clasp-knife spasticity

Lead pipe rigidity, cogwheel rigidity

Associated with

Weakness

Hypertonia

 

Lower motor neuron lesions are characterized by hypotonia (decreased muscle tone), muscle wasting (atrophy), weakened or absent reflexes, and flaccid paralysis. (Option A)


Cerebellar lesions can cause motor dysfunction, hypotonia, not rigidity. (Option B)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is found dead at home. On examination, his postmortem staining is as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Carbon monoxide poisoning

Explanation:

  • The given image shows Cherry-red discoloration
  • Cherry-red discoloration of the skin and tissues is characteristic of carbon monoxide poisoning due to the formation of carboxyhemoglobin (COHb), particularly when levels exceed 30%.

Postmortem Staining in Poisoning Cases

  • Postmortem staining (Livor mortis) is the skin discoloration after death due to blood settling in dependent areas.
  • The color of the staining can indicate certain types of poisoning:

Poison

Postmortem Staining Characteristics

Opium (Option A ruled out)

Purple or blackish staining

Carbon monoxide (Option C)

Cherry red discoloration (COHb > 30%)

Hydrogen sulfide (Option B ruled out)

Greenish discoloration in tissues

Datura

Asphyxial signs (no specific color)

Organochlorine/Kerosene (Option D ruled out)

Asphyxial signs (no specific color)

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman presents with bone pain and tenderness over her lower back. Imaging reveals multiple lytic lesions in the vertebral column. Laboratory tests indicate anaemia, elevated serum calcium levels, and monoclonal gammopathy. A bone marrow biopsy confirms plasma cell proliferation. Microscopic examination of the biopsy reveals intracellular inclusions, as shown in the image. What is the composition of the intracellular inclusions marked in the image?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Accumulations of immunoglobulins

 

Explanation:

The clinical presentation is highly suggestive of multiple myeloma, a plasma cell dyscrasia characterized by bone pain, lytic lesions, anaemia, hypercalcemia, and monoclonal gammopathy.

Microscopic examination of the bone marrow biopsy may reveal the presence of intracellular inclusions, such as Russell bodies (Immunoglobulins in the cytoplasm) and Dutcher bodies (containing Ig in the nucleus), within some plasma cells.

questions.text: A 28 y/o woman, G2P2, presents to the emergency on postpartum day 10 with complaints of vaginal bleeding. She reports with fever, chills, and feels lightheaded and weak. O/E, the uterus is larger than expected for her postpartum state, and there is moderate vaginal bleeding. Her hemoglobin level is 7.8 g/dL. All of the following can cause postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) in this patient, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Uterine atony

 

Explanation:

  • This is a case of Secondary postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), also known as a delayed or late puerperal hemorrhage, which occurs between 24 hours and 12 weeks after delivery.
  • Clinically significant uterine bleeding occurs in about 1% of women, usually within 1 to 2 weeks of delivery.
  • Uterine atony is the failure of the uterus to contract effectively after delivery and is the most common cause of primary PPH (occurring within the first 24 hours postpartum).
  • It leads to excessive bleeding immediately after birth rather than delayed bleeding. This patient's presentation on postpartum day 10 makes uterine atony an unlikely cause of her current symptoms.

Secondary Postpartum Hemorrhage

Cause

Description

Retained Placental Fragments and Membranes (Option A)
  • Most common cause
  • They can prevent proper uterine involution and healing, leading to significant bleeding.
  • Rarely, retained products undergo necrosis and fibrin deposition, forming a placental polyp that can cause severe hemorrhage.

Infection

Tissue breakdown and delayed healing

Endometritis (Option C)
  • Inflammation of the uterine lining and delayed healing.
  • Symptoms typically include fever, uterine tenderness, and foul-smelling lochia.

Subinvolution of Placental Site
  • Uterus's failure to return to its normal size after delivery.
  • When the placental site heals slowly, it can increase the risk of secondary bleeding

Uterine artery Pseudoaneurysm (Option D)

  • A severe but rare cause of secondary PPH.
  • It occurs when a pseudoaneurysm forms in the uterine artery, leading to delayed hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with a sensation of a bulge in her vaginal area, which worsens on straining. On examination, a protrusion of the vaginal apex beyond the hymen is noted. There is no associated urinary incontinence. What is the most appropriate management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Vaginal hysterectomy and uterosacral suspension

Explanation:

Vaginal hysterectomy, along with uterosacral suspension, which treat prolapse and support the vaginal apex, respectively, are preferred in post-menopausal women presenting with vault prolapse.

 

Treatment options for vault prolapse in females

Treatment Option

Indications

Conservative (pelvic floor exercises) (Option A)

Mild prolapse, asymptomatic, patient preference

Pessary fitting (Option B)

Symptomatic prolapse, desire for non-surgical management in mild to moderate cases.

Vaginal hysterectomy and uterosacral suspension

Significant prolapse, symptomatic, desire for definitive surgical correction

McCall culdoplasty (Option D)

Significant posterior vaginal wall prolapse, desire for surgical repair in which preservation of the uterus is desired.

Sacrocolpopexy

Severe prolapse, previous failed repairs, desire for durable support

Colpocleisis

Elderly or frail patients, desire for definitive closure of the vagina

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought by his parents due to episodes of brief staring spells associated with a loss of awareness, lasting 10 to 20 seconds, occurring multiple times a day, especially during stress or fatigue. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Ethosuximide

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario is characteristic of typical absence seizures, a type of generalised onset non-motor seizure with unresponsiveness and staring spells.
  • They are generally seen in children aged 5 to 15 years.
  • A classic EEG finding of a 3-Hz spike and wave discharges is found.
  • Ethosuximide is the drug of choice in typical absence seizures. It blocks T-type calcium channels in the thalamus and prevents the firing of action potential to the cortex.
  • Valproate (Option A) is the DOC in atypical absence seizures.
  • Phenytoin (Option B) and Carbamazepine (Option C) are contraindicated in the Absence seizures.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true regarding the Net reproductive rate (NRR)?

choices.text: Defined as the no. of daughters or girls a newborn girl will bear or will have throughout her reproductive lifespan, considering the current age-specific fertility patterns and mortality rates
The most sensitive indicator to evaluate the National family planning program

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Indicator of complete family size.

Explanation: The Total Fertility Rate (TFR) indicates the complete family size, not the Net reproductive rate.

Net reproductive rate (NRR)

Definition

NRR is the number of daughters or girls a newborn will bear or have throughout her reproductive lifespan, considering the current age-specific fertility patterns and mortality rates. (Option B)

Interpretation

  • It is the most sensitive indicator to evaluate National family planning program (Option C)
  • It is a mortality-dependent fertility indicator. (Option D)
  • It is the best measure of growth of a population.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with a 3-day history of worsening lower abdominal pain, fever, and diarrhea with mucus. She reports a feeling of pressure in her pelvis and says that even sitting is excruciating. Her medical history is significant for diverticulitis, which was treated conservatively 6 weeks ago. Tenderness to palpation in the lower abdomen, and a rectal examination are present. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pelvic Abscess

 

Explanation:

  • This patient's symptoms, combined with her recent history of diverticulitis, point towards a pelvic abscess.

 

Clinical Features of Pelvic Abscess:

  • Lower abdominal pain and tenderness due to pus accumulation.
  • Fever accompanied by chills and rigor.
  • Pus irritates the anterior rectal wall (since the pouch of Douglas is in contact with this area) causing multiple episodes of loose stools with mucus.
  • Digital rectal examination may reveal a bulge on the anterior wall of the rectum.

 

Investigation:

  • Initial investigation: Ultrasound.
  • Investigation of choice: Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT).

 

Management:

  • If a clean window is present:
    • Percutaneous aspiration guided by ultrasound or CT (preferred treatment) is performed.
  • If no clean window is available due to bowel loops adhering to the abscess cavity:
    • For females: Posterior colpotomy through the posterior vaginal wall (in close contact with the pouch of Douglas).
    • For males: Anterior rectal drainage through the anterior rectal wall.

questions.text: An immigrant laborer comes to your Sunday volunteer clinic complaining of thickening of the skin on his scalp. The lesions are not itchy, cross the hairline, and are not associated with loss of hair as shown in the given image. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Pityriasis amiantacea

 

Explanation: 

  • Pityriasis amiantacea is a scalp condition characterized by the formation of thick, asbestos-like scales that adhere to the hair shafts.

  • While the lesions are typically not itchy, they could cause hair loss if left untreated.
  • Can be secondary to an underlying inflammatory skin disorder such as:
    • Psoriasis
    • Lichen simplex
    • Scalp infections
  • Treatment
    • Topical corticosteroids
    • Keratolytic agents

Seborrheic dermatitis (Option B) is a scalp condition with red, itchy, greasy scales that affects areas rich in sebaceous glands, like the scalp, face, and upper trunk it can be caused by the fungi Malassezia furfur.

 

Pityriasis rosea (Option C) presents with oval-shaped, pink, or red patches on the trunk, arms, or legs. It doesn't involve the scalp, and the lesions don't cross the hairline. It is also caused by Malassezia furfur.

Tinea barbae (Option D) is a fungal infection of the beard area in men, characterized by erythematous plaques and pustules.

questions.text: During induction of anesthesia, a patient receiving etomidate shows an increase in blood pressure and heart rate. How does etomidate primarily achieve cardiovascular stability?

choices.text: By activating the sympathetic nervous system

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Through α2-adrenoceptor activation

Explanation:

Etomidate activates α2-adrenoceptors, which increases blood pressure and contributes to cardiovascular stability by preventing excessive sympathetic stimulation.

Effects of Etomidate on the Cardiovascular System

  • Hemodynamic Stability:
    • Etomidate maintains hemodynamic stability by not affecting the sympathetic nervous system or baroreceptor function. (Option A & B)
  • Blood Pressure Effects:
    • Activation of α2-adrenoceptors leads to increased blood pressure, contributing to cardiovascular stability during anesthesia induction.
  • Comparison with Other Anesthetics:
    • Minimal cardiovascular effects distinguish etomidate from other rapid-onset anesthetics, making it suitable for patients with heart conditions.
  • Patient Suitability:
    • Effective for patients with valvular or ischemic heart disease and those with poor cardiac function during non cardiac surgeries.
  • Hemodynamic Responses:
    • Etomidate may lead to more hypertension and tachycardia compared to propofol during induction.
  • Oxygen Supply and Demand:
    • Maintains a stable myocardial oxygen supply-to-demand ratio. (Option D)
  • Analgesic Considerations:
    • Lacks analgesic properties; should be combined with opioids to manage hemodynamic changes during laryngoscopy and intubation.
  • Advantages in Hemorrhagic Shock:
    • In cases of hemorrhagic shock, etomidate's pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics remain largely unchanged, making it advantageous for induction.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a three-week history of progressively worsening temporal headaches, jaw pain, and visual disturbances. On examination, her right temporal artery appears swollen and tender to palpation. Which of the following statements regarding this condition are false?

choices.text: It is the most common cause of vasculitis in adults
It occurs as a result of a B cell-mediated immune response
It is associated with polymyalgia rheumatica

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It occurs as a result of a B cell-mediated immune response.

 

Explanation :

  • The clinical presentation of a 68-year-old woman with worsening temporal headaches (classical symptom), jaw pain (most specific symptom), visual disturbances (most dangerous complication), and tender and swollen right temporal artery points towards the diagnosis of giant cell arteritis.

Temporal arteritis/Giant cell arteritis:

  • Giant cell (temporal) arteritis involves large- to medium-sized arteries. (Option A ruled out)
  • Epidemiology: Most common type of vasculitis in adults (usually >50 years old) (Option B ruled out)
  • It is frequently associated with polymyalgia rheumatica. (Option D ruled out)
  • It is a T-cell-mediated immune response (Option C)
  • Biopsy findings: 
    • Giant cells
    • Granulomas
    • Fragmentation of internal elastic lamina
  • Special stain: Verhoeff-Van Gieson stain (to visualize elastic lamina)
  • Fragmentation of internal elastic lamina: Elastic lamina is mostly present everywhere but fragmented in some places.

questions.text: Which of the following is a pathognomonic feature of a lightning strike injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lichtenberg figures (Lichtenberg flowers)

 

Explanation:

Lichtenberg flowers: These are characteristic fern-like patterns that appear on the skin following a lightning strike.

 

Lightning stroke

  • Lightning bolt(DC>1000 million V) is produced when the charged undersurface of a thundercloud sends its electrical charge to the ground.
  • Death is caused by high voltage current due to cardiopulmonary arrest or electrothermal injuries.

 

Lichtenberg flowers/Arborescent markings:

  • Pathognomic feature of lightning strike.
  • Superficial, several inches long, thin, irregular, tortuous, dendritic red marks on the skin having resemblance to the branches of a tree.
  • This Fern-like pattern of erythema in the skin is usually found over the shoulders or flanks.
  • Appears within 1hr and disappears in 24-48 hrs if person survives.

 

 

 

Other features of lightning strike:

  • Development of edema of skin at the point of entry wound.
  • Linear burns and surface burns
  • Fusing and magnetisation of metallic articles.
  • Contusions, lacerations, rupture of tympanic membrane.
  • Singed hair and patterned skin burns marks underneath metal articles of jewellery.

Joule burns (Option B): These are burns caused by the conversion of electrical energy into heat within the body and are not specific to lightning strikes. They can occur in any electrical injury.

 

Crocodile skin lesions (Option C): These are indicative of other types of electrical injuries, characterized by a specific pattern of skin damage but are not unique to lightning strikes.

 

Sparrow foot marks (Option D): Peculiar facial lacerations due to contact with the shattered windscreen seen in transportation injuries.

questions.text:
Match the following sterilisation techniques with their respective control methods.


 


	
		
			
			Sterilisation technique
			
			
			Control method 
			
		
		
			
			1. Hot air oven
			
			
			a. Bacillus pumilus
			
		
		
			
			2. Autoclave
			
			
			b. Serratia marcescens
			
		
		
			
			3. Membrane filtration
			
			
			c. Bacillus atrophaeus/subtilis spores
			
		
		
			
			4.Ionizing Radiation
			
			
			d. Geobacillus stearothermophilus spores
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, 4-a

 

Explanation:

Sterilisation technique

Control method

1. Hot air oven

c. Bacillus atrophaeus/subtilis spores

2. Autoclave

d. Geobacillus stearothermophilus spores

3. Membrane filtration

b. Serratia marcescens

4.Ionizing Radiation

a. Bacillus pumilus

 

These control methods are biological indicators used to check the effectiveness of the sterilisation method.

 

  • Spores of bacillus atrophaeus/subtilis are used as a control method for hot air ovens and ethylene oxide sterilisation (used mainly for heart-lung machines).
  • Spores of geobacillus stearothermophilus are used as a control method for autoclave and plasma sterilisation.
  • Bacillus globigi is also used as a control method for ethylene oxide sterilisation.
  • Serratia marcescens and Brevundimonas diminuta are used as control methods for membrane filters.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient with treatment-resistant schizophrenia has started on clozapine. What is the appropriate duration and frequency of blood test monitoring for this patient taking clozapine?

choices.text: Weekly for 6 months, bi-weekly for 6 months, then monthly.
Monthly for 6 months, then every 3 months.
Weekly for 3 months, bi-weekly for 3 months, then monthly.
Monthly for 1 year, then every 6 months.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Weekly for 6 months, bi-weekly for 6 months, then monthly.

Explanation:

  • Clozapine is associated with a risk of agranulocytosis, especially during the first year of treatment.

  • Regular monitoring of Absolute Neutrophil Count (ANC) is mandatory to detect early neutropenia or agranulocytosis.

  • The standard hematological monitoring schedule for patients on clozapine is:

    • Weekly for the first 6 months

    • Every 2 weeks (bi-weekly) for the next 6 months

    • Monthly after 1 year, if ANC remains stable

Monitoring Phase Frequency Duration
Initial phase Weekly First 6 months
Intermediate Bi-weekly Next 6 months
Maintenance Monthly After 1 year, lifelong while on clozapine

 

Monthly for 6 months, then every 3 months (Option B): This monitoring frequency is dangerously infrequent for clozapine, especially during the crucial initial months, and does not meet safety guidelines for agranulocytosis risk.

Weekly for 3 months, bi-weekly for 3 months, then monthly (Option C): This option has an insufficient duration of intensified weekly and bi-weekly monitoring (only 3 months each), leaving patients at higher risk for undetected agranulocytosis compared to the standard 6-month periods.

Monthly for 1 year, then every 6 months (Option D): This schedule is grossly inadequate for clozapine safety monitoring, particularly during the critical first year, and would not allow for timely detection of severe neutropenia or agranulocytosis.

questions.text: In a population of 1000 people who are at high risk of contracting syphilis, 650 were confirmed to be positive by serological studies. A new test that acts by detecting a new biomarker "X" has been introduced and 600 were found to be positive among serology-positive patients. 120 out of the remaining 350 people were also found to be having “X”. What is the positive predictive value of this new test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  C) 83%

Explanation:

The positive predictive value of a test reflects the ratio of patients who actually have the disease to those who had positive test results.

From the data given above,

 

 

Serology positive

Serology negative

"X" positive

600

(a-true positive)

120

(b-false positive)

"X" negative

50

(c-false negative)

230

(d-true negative)

Positive predictive value = a/a+b = 600/600+120 = 83%

The negative predictive value of a test reflects the probability that it will be negative in healthy, non-diseased individuals.

In the above example,

Negative predictive value = d/c+d = 230/230+50 = 82%

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the rubella-containing vaccine (RCV) is incorrect?

choices.text: The live attenuated RA 27/3 strain is used in the rubella vaccine
RCVs have a shelf-life of 2-3 years when stored at 4°C
The recommended dose of RCV is 1.0 ml injected subcutaneously
Recipients of RCV are advised not to become pregnant for 1 month after vaccination

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The recommended dose of RCV is 1.0 ml injected subcutaneously.

 

Explanation:

 

RUBELLA VACCINE AND VACCINATION STRATEGY

Strain Used

Live attenuated RA 27/3 (Option A ruled out)

Formulations

Monovalent, MR, MMR, MMRV

Dosage

Single 0.5 ml dose, subcutaneously in anterolateral thigh or outer upper arm. (Option C)

Dose Effectiveness

Single-Dose Strategy: Effective for rubella elimination if high coverage is achieved. >95% effectiveness for a single dose

Two-Dose Strategy: Practical when combined with measles vaccination using MR or MMR vaccine

Storage Conditions

RCVs: 2-8°C, protected from light

Diluent vials: Ambient temperature, not frozen

Shelf-Life

2-3 years at 4°C (Option B ruled out)

Target Groups

Priority 1: Non-pregnant women of reproductive age

Priority 2: Children between 1-14 years

Priority 3: Routine vaccination of children <1 year

Pregnancy Advisory

Recipients advised not to become pregnant for 1 month after vaccination as it increases the risk of congenital rubella syndrome. (Option D ruled out)

But it is not an indication for MTP if the woman does get pregnant within 1 month of vaccination

questions.text:
A 40-year-old patient is brought to the emergency department with melena and dizziness. Her BP is 100/ 80 mmHg, and her pulse rate is 100 bpm. Her lab investigations reveal Hb of 8 gm/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 25 mg/dL. Based on the Blatchford score, which of the following findings would most significantly increase her risk stratification score?

a. Systolic blood pressure less than 100 mm of Hg

b. High blood urea nitrogen level (> 25)

c. Diagnosis of Mallory Weiss syndrome

d. Heart rate more than 100 bpm
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) a, b and d

 

Explanation:

  • All the options except the diagnosis of Mallory Weiss syndrome are a component of the Blatchford scoring system.
  • The most commonly used risk stratification systems include:
    • Rockall- Bayler score
    • Blatchford score

 

Blatchford score

Rockall- Bayler score

Used for initial assessment in case of bleeds

Most useful as it is based on endoscopic findings
  • Pulse
  • Blood Urea nitrogen
  • Systolic Blood pressure
  • Haemoglobin
  • Presence of
    • Melena
    • Syncope
    • Hepatic or Cardiac dysfunction
  • Comorbid disease (cardiac, hepatic, renal, or disseminated)
  • Age (<60 years, 60-79 years, >80 years)
  • Shock
    • Systolic BP <100 mm Hg
    • Pulse rate >100 beats/min
  • Diagnosis at the time of endoscopy (Non-malignant lesions, or malignant lesions like Mallory weiss syndrome, GI malignancy)
  • Endoscopic Stigmata of recent bleed

questions.text: 60-year-old patient is admitted with low urine output and swelling all over the body. BUN: 140 mg/dl, serum creatinine 8.0 mg/dl and urine protein by dipstick is 4+. USG abdomen shows normal size kidney. Which of the following is useful for distinguishing acute kidney injury from chronic kidney disease?
questions.solution: Urine albumin grades A1,A2 and A3 help in monitoring progression of CKD. Option A and C are reduced in both AKI and CKD. Option B is ruled out as size of kidney is normal to enlarged in diabetic nephropathy and amyloidosis but are examples of CKD.

questions.text: A physiologist is studying blood flow in a network of four parallel blood vessels. The effective resistance of the network of vessels is 4.8 R units. The pressure at the proximal end of the network is 150 mmHg, and the pressure at the distal end is 90 mmHg. What is the total blood flow rate through the network of vessels?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Effective Perfusion Pressure = 150 mmHg − 90 mmHg= 60 mmHg
  • Using the blood flow analogue of Ohm's law: Blood flow (F) in any part of the circulatory system is determined by the effective perfusion pressure (P) and the resistance (R) it encounters: F = P/R
    • 𝑅 total = 4.8R units
    • Flow = Pressure / Resistance = 60/4.8 =12.5 L/s
