questions.text: A 38-year-old female with a history of chronic kidney disease presents with persistent fatigue, bone pain, and muscle weakness. Blood work reveals elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP), high serum phosphorus, and low serum calcium. What will the result of 1,25 dihydroxy vitamin D likely reveal?

choices.text: Estimating 1, 25 dihydroxy vitamin D is unnecessary.

questions.solution:
Patients with CKD often have reduced 1α-hydroxylase, leading to lower levels of active vitamin D: 1,25 dihydroxy vitamin D.

1,25 dihydroxy Vitamin D in Chronic kidney disease:

  • In chronic kidney disease (CKD), estimating 1,25 dihydroxy vitamin D levels is essential due to the kidneys' role in vitamin D metabolism. (Option B ruled out)
  • The kidneys are the primary site where 1α-hydroxylase converts inactive vitamin D (25 hydroxy cholecalciferol) into its active form, 1,25 dihydroxy cholecalciferol.
  • Patients with CKD often have reduced 1α-hydroxylase, leading to lower levels of active vitamin D: 1,25 dihydroxy vitamin D. (Options A and D ruled out)
  • Impact on Calcium Homeostasis: Low levels in CKD causes hypocalcemia.
  • Secondary Hyperparathyroidism: To compensate for low calcium, PTH increases and has negative consequences for bone health.
  • Renal Osteodystrophy: Abnormal bone turnover, as evidenced by the elevated alkaline phosphatase in the clinical scenario.
  • Diagnostic Value: 1,25 dihydroxy cholecalciferol has a longer half-life and remains stable. Therefore, it provides a more reliable test for vitamin D status in CKD and helps guide appropriate treatment.
  • Treatment:
    • Dialysis.
    • Calcimimetic drugs - Cinacalcet and Etelcalcetide.

questions.text:
Correctly match the following statements with True(T)/ False(F)

1) Continuity is disrupted in tangentiality

2) Goal is not reached in circumstantiality

3) Perseveration is associated with organic mental disorder

4) Continuity is preserved in perseveration

5) Thought blocking is associated with schizophrenia
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) 1-F,2-F,3-T,4-F,5-T

Explanation:

The correct statements are,

1) Continuity is maintained in tangentiality

2) Goal is reached in circumstantiality

3) Perseveration is associated with organic mental disorder

4) Continuity is disrupted in perseveration

5) Thought blocking is associated with schizophrenia

Hence, 1-F,2-F,3-T,4-F,5-T is the correct answer.

Disorders of flow/stream of thought:

Continuity maintained with increased speed:
  • Flight of ideas: rapid flow of ideas from one to another, connected and partially understandable
  • Prolixity: Milder form of flight of ideas
  • Clang association: sentences with rhyming

Continuity maintained with decreased speed: (Statement-1)
  • Thought slowing/retardation: Decrease in speed of thought, seen in depression
  • Circumstantiality: Overinclusion of trivial and unnecessary details, but ultimately reaches the answer. (Statement-2)
  • Tangentiality: Flow of irrelevant thoughts that deviates from the main topic and never reaches the answer.

Continuity disrupted:

  • Perseveration: (Statement-4)
    • Same thought persists beyond the point of relevance.
    • Pathological repetition of the same response to different stimuli.
    • Seen in organic mental disorder (Statement-3) and schizophrenia.
  • Thought blocking:
    • Sudden arrest of thought and then the person resumes with an entirely new thought.
    • Seen in schizophrenia. (Statement-5)

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with breast cancer is undergoing chemotherapy with cisplatin. Despite receiving antiemetics during the initial 24 hours, she experiences nausea and vomiting 48 hours after chemotherapy. Which of the following drugs below is most effective in preventing delayed emesis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Aprepitant

Explanation:

This patient’s history and clinical symptoms suggest delayed chemotherapy-induced vomiting (CINV). Among the given options, aprepitant is the most effective drug for delayed CINV.

  • Aprepitant is an NK1 receptor antagonist that prevents delayed phases of CINV (CINV > 24hrs) when standard anti-emetics are ineffective.
  • It blocks substance P, a neuropeptide associated with vomiting.
  • Other NK1 receptor antagonists include
    • Fosapripitant (injectable)
    • Netupitant.
    • Rolapitant (longest half-life of 180 hours).

 

Antiemetic drugs:

 

Examples

Uses

Side effects

5-HT3 receptor antagonists
  • Ondansetron (shortest-acting, weak 5-HT4 antagonist)
  • Palonosetron (longest-acting + most potent)
  • Granisetron (can be given intradermal)
  • Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting
    • Early onset: Ondansetron
    • Late onset: Palonosetron
  • Headache
  • QT prolongation
    • Maximum: Dolasetron
    • Minimum: Palonosetron
  • Hypotension

Centrally acting D2 antagonists
  • Metoclopramide
  • Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.
  • Gastroparesis.
  • Paralytic ileus.
  • Bowel cleansing.
  • Extra-pyramidal symptoms (acute dystonia).
  • Severe hyperprolactinemia.
  • Domperidone
    (Option B)
  • Mild-moderate vomiting.
  • GERD.
  • Minor EPS features.
  • Mild hyperprolactinema.

Neurokinin-1 inhibitors
  • Aprepitant
  • Fosaprepitant
  • Rolapitant
  • Netupitant
  • Late-onset nausea and vomiting (DOC)
  • Post-operative nausea and vomiting.
  • Rolapitant:
    • Neutropenia.
    • Hiccups.
    • Decreased appetite.
    • Dizziness.

Cannabinoids
  • Dronabinol
    (Option A)
  • Nabilone
  • Chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (refractory cases).
  • Appetite stimulant (can be used in HIV and anorexia patients.
  • Hypotension.
  • Conjunctival injection (bloodshot eyes)

Antihistamines
  • Cyclizine
  • Meclizine
  • Promethazine
  • Diphenhydramine
  • Motion sickness
  • Sedation.
  • Doxylamine
  • Morning sickness (given with pyridoxine)
  • Dry mouth
  • Drowsiness
  • Dry mouth
  • Constipation

Muscarinic receptor antagonists
  • Hyoscine (scopolamine)
  • Motion sickness (DOC, available as a transdermal patch)
  • Dry mouth.
  • Visual disturbances.
  • Drowsiness.
  • Glucocorticoids (Option D) (dexamethasone) are used as an adjunct in the management of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.
  • M/C used drugs for delayed emesis associated with cancer chemotherapy: Ondansetron (5-HT3 antagonist) + Aprepritant (NK-1 inhibitor) + Dexamethasone.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements:

i) f IPV is a live attenuated vaccine.

ii) fIPV is not effective in control of epidemics

iii) OPV has a shorter shelf life than IPV

iv) fIPV provides humoral immunity only

v) 5 ml of fIPV is administered via IM route

Which of the following are correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Ansqwer:B) ii, iii and iv

Explanation:

  • i) IPV is a live attenuated vaccine: Incorrect

    • IPV (Inactivated Poliovirus Vaccine) is a killed (inactivated) vaccine.

  • ii) fIPV is not effective in control of epidemics: Correct

    • Fractional IPV (fIPV) is not ideal for rapid outbreak control because it does not induce sufficient mucosal immunity, which is required for halting poliovirus transmission.

    • OPV is preferred in epidemic situations due to its ability to induce gut immunity and stop transmission.

  • iii) OPV has a shorter shelf life than IPV: Correct

    • OPV is a live virus vaccine, requiring strict cold chain maintenance and has a shorter shelf life than IPV, which is inactivated and more stable.

  • iv) fIPV provides humoral immunity only: Correct

    • fIPV induces humoral (systemic) immunity but does not provide strong mucosal immunity in the intestines, which is necessary to prevent virus shedding.

    • OPV provides both humoral and mucosal immunity.

  • v) 5 ml of fIPV is administered via IM route: Incorrect

    • fIPV is given as 0.1 ml intradermally, not 5 ml intramuscularly.

    • The standard full-dose IPV (not fractional) is given intramuscularly (IM).

Differences Between IPV and OPV

Feature IPV (Inactivated Poliovirus Vaccine) OPV (Oral Poliovirus Vaccine)
Type of Vaccine Inactivated (killed) virus Live attenuated virus
Route of Administration Intramuscular (IM) or Intradermal (ID) Oral (drops)
Immunity Provided Systemic (humoral) immunity Systemic + mucosal immunity (gut immunity)
Effectiveness in Epidemics Not effective in stopping transmission Highly effective in epidemic control
Prevention of Virus Shedding Limited effect on intestinal virus shedding Strong gut immunity prevents shedding
Shelf Life & Storage More stable, longer shelf life Less stable, requires strict cold chain
Risk of Vaccine-Derived Poliovirus (VDPV) No risk of VDPV Small risk of VDPV due to live virus reversion
Use in Eradication Programs Primarily used in polio-free areas Used in endemic and outbreak settings

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl presents with complaints of hip pain that has been progressively worsening over the last six months. She has had a noticeable loss of appetite, weight loss, and night sweats during this time. On examination, she exhibits an antalgic gait, and the X-ray image is shown below. Which stage of this condition does this patient most likely represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Stage IV


 

Explanation:

  • This case points to a diagnosis of tuberculosis of the hip (TB hip).
  • Chronic hip pain, loss of appetite, and antalgic gait are classic indicators of a serious underlying condition like TB
  • Site of TB infection at the hip: Acetabulum > Femur
  • The presence of a wandering acetabulum on X-ray is consistent with Stage IV of the following classification:

 

Babulkar and Pandey Clinico-Radiological Classification

Stage

Clinical Findings

X-ray findings

Stage I: Synovitis

(Option A)
  • Irritable hip
  • Increased FABER (Flexion, Abduction, External Rotation)
  • Apparent lengthening due to FABER (Position of ease due to synovitis)
  • Terminal movements are restricted by 25%

Normal or haziness of the articular margins

 

Stage II: Early Arthritis

(Option B)
  • Early joint pain, stiffness
  • Increased FADIR (Flexion, Adduction, Internal Rotation)
  • Apparent shortening due to FADIR
  •  
  • Gluteal and Quadriceps muscle wasting
  • ROM restricted by 50%

Osteopenia and narrowing of joint space

Stage III: Late Arthritis

(Option C)
  • Marked FADIR
  • True shortening
  • Gross restriction of movements (usually >50%)

Marked subchondral erosion and destruction

Stage IV: Pathological Dislocation

/severe arthritis

 
  • Marked FADIR
  • Gross shortening
  • Severe destruction and loss of joint space
  • "Wandering/traveling Acetabulum": Pathological dislocation/subluxation due to gross destruction of the femoral head or the superior acetabular margin.

 

  • End stage of TB hip/arthritis: Fibrous ankylosis
  • End stage of TB spine: Bony ankylosis

 

Note:

Causes of FADIR deformity of the hip:

  • TB HIP
  • Femoroacetabular impingement syndrome

Otherwise, all other hip pathology has FABER.

questions.text: The image below shows the sites of action for different ETC inhibitors. Based on the image, which of the following is the site of action of Cyanide?
questions.solution:
Cyanide is a strong inhibitor of Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase). t blocks electron transfer to oxygen, disrupting the electron transport chain and reducing ATP production, potentially causing cellular damage.

Inhibitors of the Electron Transport Chain (ETC):

Inhibitor

Target Site

Mechanism

Rotenone

Amobarbital

Piericidin A

Complex I (Option A ruled out)

(NADH dehydrogenase)

 Blocks electron transfer from NADH in Complex I to ubiquinone.

TTFA (Thenoyltrifluoroacetone)

Carboxin

Complex II

(Succinate dehydrogenase)

Blocks electron transfer from Complex II to ubiquinone​

Malonate

Complex II

 Blocks Complex II activity via competitive inhibition.

Antimycin A

BAL

Complex III (Option C ruled out)

Cytochrome bc1 complex

 Blocks electron transfer from Complex III to cytochrome C.

Cyanide (CN−)

Carbon monoxide (CO)

Hydrogen Sulfide (H2S)

Complex IV (Option D)

(Cytochrome c Oxidase)

 Inhibits electron transfer from Complex IV to oxygen, halting respiration.

Oligomycin

ATP Synthase (Complex V)

(Option B ruled out)

 Inhibits the proton channel of ATP synthase, preventing ATP formation.

Atractyloside

Adenine Nucleotide Translocase

Blocks ADP/ATP exchange across the mitochondrial membrane​

 

Note:

  • ADP to ATP conversion is inhibited by: Oligomycin
  • ADP to ATP transfer is inhibited by: Atractyloside

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman, postmenopausal for the past 5 years, presents with a complaint of intermittent episodes of vaginal bleeding over the last month. Pelvic ultrasound reveals an endometrial thickness of 6 mm. What is the most appropriate investigation for evaluating postmenopausal bleeding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Endometrial biopsy.

 

Explanation:

  • In a postmenopausal woman presenting with postmenopausal bleeding, with an endometrial thickness of 6 mm on ultrasound, the most appropriate investigation is an endometrial biopsy.
  • It is the most definitive method to diagnose endometrial hyperplasia, polyps, or cancer in postmenopausal women with bleeding and increased endometrial thickness.

 

Investigation approach in Post-menopausal bleeding:

  • History and examination to be done. Transvaginal ultrasound should be done if the cervix looks normal, which is the first step in diagnosis.
  • A 4 mm or greater endometrial thickness in postmenopausal women is considered abnormal. It requires further evaluation since there is an increased chance of endometrial hyperplasia, and cancer rises with increasing endometrial thickness.
  • If growth/lesion is present in the cervix, a cervical biopsy should be done to rule out cervical malignancy.

 

Repeat pelvic ultrasound in 3 months (Option A): Delaying further investigation is not appropriate because postmenopausal bleeding requires timely evaluation to rule out malignancy or other significant pathology. An endometrial thickness of 6 mm is above the normal threshold and needs immediate investigation.

 

CA 125 serum levels (Option B): CA 125 is a marker for ovarian cancer, not endometrial cancer. It is not specific or primary for evaluating postmenopausal bleeding.

 

Pap smear (Option C): A Pap smear screens for cervical cancer, not endometrial issues. It does not provide information about the endometrium, the main concern in postmenopausal bleeding.

questions.text: During routine monitoring at 36 weeks gestation, a pregnant woman shows a non-reassuring fetal heart rate pattern on CTG. The observed waveform is smooth and undulating, with a fixed frequency (3-5 cycles/min) and amplitude (5-15 bpm). The fetal heart rate ranges 120-160 bpm. Which CTG pattern is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Sinusoidal pattern

Explanation:

The sinusoidal pattern, describing a smooth, regular fetal heart rate oscillation is associated with severe fetal anaemia or maternal opioid use

A sinusoidal pattern in a cardiotocography (CTG) trace resembles a sine wave, with a stable fetal heart rate (FHR) and fixed or absent baseline variability lasting more than 30 minutes. Accelerations are absent in a true sinusoidal pattern. This pattern is often associated with:

  • Fetal anaemia
  • Fetomaternal haemorrhage
  • Vasa Previa
  • Fetal hypoxia (acidosis)

A sinusoidal pattern can also occur when the mother has been given narcotics.

The pseudo sinusoidal pattern shows a 'saw-toothed' pattern. It differs from the true sinusoidal pattern because it indicates a well-oxygenated fetus.

Acceleration pattern (Option A): Reassuring fetal status
Saltatory pattern (Option B): Sign of fetal distress
Variable deceleration pattern (Option D): Linked to umbilical cord compression

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is admitted to the emergency department with symptoms of muscle spasms and difficulty breathing. She has recently been hyperventilating due to anxiety and reports a tingling sensation in her fingers. On examination, she exhibits a positive Chvostek sign and Trousseau sign. Which of the following best explains the underlying mechanism of tetany in this patient?

choices.text: Increased calcium absorption due to high levels of parathyroid hormone
Decreased ionized calcium leading to increased excitability of nerve and muscle cells
Increased protein ionization due to low pH causing more free Ca2+ availability
Enhanced bone calcium mobilization from decreased parathyroid hormone levels

questions.solution:
Tetany is primarily caused by a decrease in extracellular ionized calcium (Ca2+). This reduction increases the excitability of nerve and muscle cells, leading to symptoms such as muscle spasms and laryngospasm.

 

Tetany:

  • It is characterized by extensive skeletal muscle spasms
  • Cause: Decrease in extracellular ionized calcium (Ca2+), leading to increased excitability of nerve and muscle cells.
  • Mechanism:

Increased Excitability: Reduced extracellular Ca2+ lowers its binding to voltage-gated sodium channels in nerve and muscle cells.

Action Potential Generation: Lower Ca2+ binding decreases the activation threshold of these channels, making them more likely to open and trigger action potentials.

  • Complication: Laryngospasm can obstruct the airway and potentially cause fatal asphyxia.

 

Calcium and Tetany:

  • Normal Total Calcium Levels: Total calcium might appear normal, but a decrease in ionized calcium can still cause tetany.
  • Influence of pH: Increased pH (alkalosis) from hyperventilation increases plasma protein ionization, binding more Ca2+ and reducing free Ca2+ availability.

 

Signs of Tetany:

  • Chvostek Sign: Contraction of facial muscles upon tapping the facial nerve.
  • Trousseau Sign: Spasm of upper extremity muscles, causing wrist and thumb flexion with finger extension; elicited by occluding circulation with a blood pressure cuff.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the drainage pathway of the sinus that is marked with an arrow in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Middle meatus.

Explanation:

The frontal sinus is an air-filled cavity located in the frontal bone. The frontal sinus drains through the frontonasal duct into the infundibulum and finally into the middle meatus.

 

Contents and Cells Around the Frontal Sinus:

  1. Agger Nasi:
    • The agger nasi is an ethmoidal air cell situated in front of the uncinate process.
    • The degree of pneumatization of this cell determines the thickness of the nasofrontal beak and the position of the superior uncinate process.
  2. Uncinate Process:
    • This thin, bony structure has various attachment points, typically inserting into the medial orbital wall in 85% of cases. In fewer cases, it attaches to the skull base or the middle turbinate.
    • The drainage pathway of the frontal sinus is generally medial to the uncinate process.
  3. Frontal Cells:
    • These are ethmoidal air cells that extend towards the frontal sinus.

 

Sinus

Appearance

Full Development

Maxillary

Present at birth

15-18 years

Ethmoid

Present at birth

12-14 years

Sphenoid

3-5 years

12-15 years

Frontal

3-4 years

18-20 years

 

Sphenoethmoidal recess (Option A): Incorrect; this is the drainage site for the sphenoid sinus, not the frontal.

 

Superior meatus (Option B): Incorrect; posterior ethmoid air cells drain here, not the frontal sinus.

 

Ethmoid bulla (Option D): Incorrect; while it’s a key structure in the lateral nasal wall, it is the site where middle ethmoid air cells typically drain—not the frontal sinus.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding the neonatal conditions described?

 


	Mastitis neonatorum typically presents with bilateral breast swelling
	Vaginal bleeding in neonates usually resolves within 10 days.
	Hymenal tags are usually symptomatic and often require medical treatment.
	Term neonates can lose up to 10% of their birth weight in the first week of life.
	Physiologic phimosis usually resolves by age 3-5 and is generally asymptomatic.
	Preterm infants regain their birth weight within 7-10 days.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 2, 4, 5

 

Explanation:

  • Neonatal vaginal bleeding is a normal physiological process caused by decreased maternal estrogen and typically resolves within 10 days. (Statement 2)
  • It is normal for term neonates to lose 7-10% of their birth weight in the first week due to loss of extracellular fluid. (Statement 4)
  • Physiologic phimosis is a normal condition where the foreskin cannot be retracted and generally resolves by age 3-5 without causing symptoms. (Statement 5)

 

Condition

Features

Duration

Management

Mastitis Neonatorum
  • Infection of breast tissue related to maternal hormones.
  • Symptoms include unilateral breast swelling, erythema, warmth, tenderness, and possible purulent discharge. (Statement 1)

Resolves within a few weeks

Antibiotics; usually resolve on their own

Vaginal Bleeding
  • Normal due to decreased maternal estrogen.
  • Symptoms include a small amount of blood-tinged discharge or bleeding.

Resolves within 10 days

Medical evaluation if bleeding persists or if other concerns arise

Hymenal Tags

  • Benign remnants of tissue at the vaginal opening.
  • Normal anatomical variations and typically asymptomatic.

Often resolves on its own (Statement 3)

Treatment only if causing discomfort

Physiologic Weight Loss
  • Expected weight loss in the first week of life.
  • Term neonates lose 7-10% of birth weight; preterm infants lose 10-15%.
  • They then gain about 20 to 40 grams daily.
  • This initial weight loss is primarily due to the loss of extracellular fluid, while subsequent weight gain is attributed to increased intracellular water and solids, supporting cellular growth.

Term infants regain within 7-10 days; preterm infants by 10-14 days (Statement 6)

Weight gain of 20-40 grams daily after regaining birth weight.

Physiologic Phimosis
  • A normal condition where the foreskin cannot be retracted due to preputial adhesion.
  • Generally asymptomatic.
  • This differs from pathologic phimosis which involves scarring or inflammation, which may need treatment.

The prepuce becomes retractable by 3 yr of age. Resolves by age 3-5; may take longer

Gentle retraction during bathing to aid in loosening.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man from a rural area presents with fever, malaise, and bleeding gums. He reports recent exposure to rodent droppings in his home. Which virus is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lassa fever virus

Explanation:
Lassa fever virus, part of the Arenaviridae family, is transmitted through rodent exposure and is known to cause hemorrhagic fever, fitting the scenario.

Arenaviridae Family

  • Organisms & Diseases:
    • Includes Lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus, Lassa fever virus, and South American hemorrhagic fever viruses.
    • It is known to cause severe hemorrhagic illness in humans.
  • Structure:
    • Spherical or pleomorphic, 50–300 nm in size, with a unique sandy appearance due to ribosome-like particles.
    • Composed of single-stranded, negative-sense RNA in two circular segments; has a helical structure.
  • Vector:
    • Primarily infects rodents as their natural host.
  • Reservoir:
    • Rodents serve as the primary reservoir
  • Transmission:
    • Occurs rarely in humans, often through contact with rodent excretions or materials contaminated by infected rodents.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Diagnosed through clinical recognition of hemorrhagic illness symptoms and laboratory testing specific to the virus type like RT-PCR and ELISA

Astrovirus (Option A) generally causes mild gastroenteritis, primarily in children, and does not lead to hemorrhagic symptoms.

Rotavirus (Option B) is associated with gastroenteritis in children and does not present with hemorrhagic symptoms or rodent transmission.

Coronavirus (Option D) mainly causes respiratory symptoms and is not typically linked to hemorrhagic fever or rodent transmission.

questions.text:
A man presents to the ER with recurrent episodes of pulsations in neck and palpitations. His ECG reveals narrow complex tachycardia. What is the best treatment to prevent recurrence of these episodes?

a. Synchronized DC cardioversion

b. Catheter ablation

c. IV adenosine 6 mg bolus followed by saline push

d. Carotid sinus massage
questions.solution: The question is asking for prevention and not acute management. Option a, c and d are used for emergency management. Abolishment of re-entry circuit is done with catheter ablation.

questions.text:
Match the lipoprotein with its function.


	
		
			
			Lipoprotein
			
			
			Function
			
		
		
			
			1.Chylomicron
			
			
			a.Transports triglycerides from the liver to muscle and adipose tissue
			
		
		
			
			2.Very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL)
			
			
			b.Transports cholesterol from peripheral tissue to the liver
			
		
		
			
			3. Low-density lipoprotein (LDL)
			
			
			c.Transports cholesterol from the liver to peripheral tissues
			
		
		
			
			4. High-density lipoprotein (HDL)
			
			
			d.Transports triglycerides from the gut to muscle and adipose tissue
questions.solution:
Since lipids are insoluble in water, they are transported in blood as lipoproteins

Lipoprotein

Function

Chylomicron

Transports triglycerides from the gut to liver, muscle and adipose tissue

Very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL)

Transports triglycerides from the liver to muscle and adipose tissue

Intermediate-density lipoprotein (IDL)

VLDL remnant

Low-density lipoprotein (LDL)

Transports cholesterol from the liver to peripheral tissues

High-density lipoprotein (HDL)

Transports cholesterol from peripheral tissue to the liver

questions.text: A 26 year old woman presents for a routine gynecological examination. During her examination, vaginal cytology is performed and the following cells are seen. These cells predominate under the effect of which hormone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Estrogen

Explanation:

Superficial cells predominate in vaginal cytology under the influence of estrogen. This is typically seen during the proliferative phase of the menstrual cycle when estrogen levels are high.

 

Hormonal Influence on Vaginal Cytology:

1. Estrogen Effect:

  • Promotes superficial cell maturation: Results in large, thin, eosinophilic cells with pyknotic nuclei (cornified cells).
  • Background: Remains clear.

2. Progesterone Effect (Option A):

  • Promotes intermediate cell maturation: Leads to basophilic cells with vesicular nuclei.
  • Background: Appears "dirty."

3. Other Hormonal Effects:

  • Androgens, corticosteroids, birth control pills, and pregnancy also cause intermediate cell maturation.

4. Lack of Hormonal Activity:

  • Results in parabasal cell dominance, with small, round, basophilic cells.

 

Luteinizing hormone (LH) (Option C) is primarily involved in triggering ovulation. While it plays a crucial role in the menstrual cycle, it does not directly influence the maturation of vaginal epithelial cells. 

Follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) (Option D) is responsible for stimulating the growth of ovarian follicles. However, FSH does not directly affect the maturation of vaginal cells.

questions.text:
Match the type of cataract with the etiology


	
		
			
			Type of cataract 
			
			
			Etiology 
			
		
		
			
			a. Posterior subcapsular
			
			
			1. Glassblowers
			
		
		
			
			b. Anterior subcapsular-granular
			
			
			2. Miotics
			
		
		
			
			c. Posterior cortical
			
			
			3. Steroids
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) a3,b2,c1

 

Explanation:

Toxic cataract:

  • Steroids - Prolonged use in high doses may cause posterior subcapsular cataracts. Children are more susceptible
  • Other causes of posterior subcapsular cataract: Galactosemia, Myotonic dystrophy, BLUNT trauma, complicated cataract, chloroquine, busulfan, NF2,
  • Glaucoma by TOPICAL steroids and cataract by SYSTEMIC STEROIDS (mnemonic: GTCS)
  • Miotics - Especially long-acting cholinesterase inhibitors such as echothiophate, demecarium bromide, and diisopropyl fluorophosphate (DFP) may cause anterior subcapsular-granular cataracts
  • Other causes of anterior subcapsular cataract - Amiodarone, chlorpromazine, busulfan, gold, and allopurinol
  • AACG ( Mnemonic): Atopic dermatitis- shield cataract, Amiodarone, Chlorpromazine, Gold deposit, AACG(acute angle closure glaucoma)

 

Radiation cataract: Infrared (heat) cataract-

  • Infrared aka glassblower cataract
  • Lens capsule exfoliation with discoid posterior opacities
  • X-ray, gamma rays, neutron exposure: Inadequately protected technicians, patients treated for malignant tumors, and workers of atomic energy plants are at risk.

 

Traumatic cataract: blunt trauma: Rosette cataract

  • It is a cortical cataract that starts from the posterior cortex.

Electric Shock cataract/ Lightening cataract: It leads to Stellate ASC

questions.text: A neonate presents with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. A HIDA scan is performed and results are shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Neonatal hepatitis

 

Explanation:

The given image shows normal filling of gallbladder and excretion of radioisotope into the intestine, suggesting neonatal hepatitis.

 

Neonatal Hepatitis:

It refers to inflammation of the liver in newborns, typically presenting within the first few weeks of life.

 

Etiology: Causes include viral infections (e.g., cytomegalovirus, rubella, hepatitis B), metabolic disorders, genetic conditions, and idiopathic origins.

 

Clinical Presentation: Jaundice, hepatomegaly, dark urine, and poor weight gain.The disease can present as either mild or severe, with the potential for liver failure in severe cases.

 

Diagnosis: Diagnosed through a combination of clinical evaluation, liver function tests (elevated ALT, AST), and specific serologic and metabolic tests.

  • HIDA: Shows normal excretion of radioisotope into the intestine.
  • Liver biopsy may show giant cell transformation, indicative of neonatal hepatitis.

 

Differential Diagnosis: Biliary atresia or genetic/metabolic liver diseases.

 

Treatment: Mainly supportive, including nutritional support and fat-soluble vitamin supplementation.

 

In acute cholecystitis (Option C): Filling of gallbladder is absent due to obstruction of cystic duct.

In Extrahepatic biliary atresia (EHBA) (Option A) and Bile duct stricture (Option D) there is absence of excretion of radioisotope into the intestines.

questions.text: 30 year old man presents with palpable purpura over lower limbs and joint pain involving knees and ankle joints along with fatigue and weakness. On examination livedo reticularis is noted. Urine examination shows hematuria with RBC casts. Past medical history is noted for Hepatitis C. diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Classic clinical triad (Meltzer’s Triad):

  • Purpura – Especially palpabe purpura over lower limbs
  • Arthralgia/Arthritis – typically non-erosive
  • Weakness – Fatigue, Constitutional symptoms

Other common features:

  • Peripheral neuropathy – Mononeuritis multiplex
  • Glomerulonephritis – Often a membranoproliferative pattern (MPGN)
  • Raynuad phenomenon
  • Hepatosplenomegaly, Lymphadenopathy
  • Cutaneous ulcers, Livedo reticularis

 

Serum sicknesss – Classic Presentation

  • Onset: 1-2 weeks after exposure to foreign protein (e.g., antitoxins, monoclonal antibodies, or some antibiotics like cefaclor, penicillin)

 

Key clinical features:

  • Fever – Sudden onset
  • Urticarial or maculopapular rash – often itchy, non-blanching
  • Arthralgia or arthritis – Large joints, non-destructive
  • Lymphadenopathy – Especially cervical
  • Myalgia and Malaise – General constitutional symptoms
  • Proteinuria and hematuria – If renal involvement is present

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman presents at 30 weeks of gestation with BP of 170/110 mmHg and proteinuria. She is stable without evidence of end-organ damage. According to the algorithm for managing severe preeclampsia, what is the recommended management approach?

choices.text: Consider expectant management in a tertiary care centre
Monitor closely for 24 hours and discharge
Administer antenatal corticosteroids and terminate pregnancy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Consider expectant management in a tertiary care centre.

 

Explanation:

Before 34 weeks of gestation with severe hypertension (BP > 160/110mm Hg), expectant management may prolong pregnancy to improve neonatal outcomes if maternal and fetal conditions are stable.

 

Algorithm for Treating Preeclampsia

Initial Evaluation
  • Perform comprehensive maternal and fetal evaluation.
  • CBC with platelet estimate, serum creatinine, LDH, AST, ALT, and proteinuria testing.
  • Fetal evaluation: USG for estimated fetal weight, amniotic fluid volume, and fetal antepartum testing.

Decision for Delivery vs Expectant Management
  • 34+ Weeks Gestation: Deliver promptly upon maternal stabilization or with labor/prelabor rupture of membranes; do not delay for steroid administration.
  • Before 34 Weeks Gestation with Severe Preeclampsia: Consider expectant management in a tertiary care setting if maternal and fetal conditions are stable.
  • 37+ Weeks Gestation with Gestational Hypertension or Preeclampsia Without Severe Features: Opt for delivery rather than expectant management upon diagnosis.
  • Before 37 Weeks Gestation with Gestational Hypertension or Preeclampsia Without Severe Features: Managed as an outpatient; requires frequent fetal and maternal evaluation. Deliver only if specific conditions necessitate immediate intervention.

Management During Expectant Management
  • Closely monitor maternal and fetal conditions.
  • Serial laboratory testing: CBC, liver enzymes, serum creatinine.
  • Use antihypertensive therapy for acute-onset severe hypertension (systolic ≥160 mm Hg or diastolic ≥110 mm Hg).
  • Administer antenatal corticosteroids and monitor for 48 hours if delivery is indicated before 34 weeks gestation. 

Regularly check for Conditions Necessitating Delivery Regardless of Gestational Age

Maternal Conditions

Fetal Conditions
  • HELLP syndrome
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Eclampsia
  • Suspected acute placental abruption, or vaginal bleeding without placenta previa
  • Uncontrolled severe-range blood pressure
  • Worsening renal function
  • Persistent headaches, epigastric/right upper quadrant pain
  • Visual disturbances
  • Motor deficits
  • Altered sensorium
  • Stroke
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Abnormal fetal testing
  • Fetal death
  • Fetus with low survival likelihood (lethal anomaly, Extreme prematurity)
  • Persistent reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery

Postpartum Management
  • Monitor blood pressure and symptoms post-delivery.
  • Consider NSAIDs for pain management instead of opioids.

 

Delivery is typically done at or after 34 weeks of gestation, not necessarily at 30 weeks without severe features (Option A ruled out).

 

Monitoring for fetal distress is part of ongoing management, not initial for severe preeclampsia without immediate delivery indications (Option C ruled out)

 

Corticosteroids are recommended if delivery is anticipated before 34 weeks also no need to terminate the pregnancy (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of urinary leakage. She reports that she leaks urine when she coughs, sneezes, or exercises. She also experiences occasional sudden urges to urinate that she cannot control, especially when she hears running water or after holding her urine for some time. Which types of urinary incontinence are likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mixed urinary incontinence

Explanation:

  • Mixed urinary incontinence refers to a combination of two types of urinary incontinence: stress urinary incontinence (SUI) and urge urinary incontinence (UUI). This condition is characterised by symptoms of both types occurring concurrently in an individual.
  • Individuals with mixed urinary incontinence experience symptoms of both SUI and UUI. They may have leakage of urine during activities that increase abdominal pressure (SUI), as well as sudden urges to urinate that lead to involuntary leakage (UUI).

Types of urinary incontinence:

Type

Description

Stress urinary incontinence

Involuntary loss of urine with effort or physical exertion or when sneezing or coughing.

Urgency urinary incontinence

Involuntary loss of urine associated with urgency or sudden, compelling desire to void that is difficult to defer.

Mixed urinary incontinence

Involuntary loss of urine associated with urgency and with physical exertion, sneezing or coughing.

Overactive bladder

Urinary urgency, typically accompanied by frequency and nocturia, with or without urge urinary incontinence, in the absence of urinary tract infection or other obvious pathology.

Nocturnal enuresis

Involuntary loss of urine that occurs during sleep.

Functional urinary incontinence

Involuntary loss of urine that is due to cognitive, functional, or mobility impairments in the presence of an intact lower urinary tract system.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of chronic osteoarthritis presents to the emergency department with chest pain and shortness of breath. He has been taking an NSAID for pain management for the past few months. On examination, he appears diaphoretic and in distress. The ECG reveals ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads. Troponin levels are elevated. What is the most likely drug causing this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Rofecoxib

Explanation:

Rofecoxib and Valdecoxib, selective COX-2 inhibitors, were withdrawn from the market due to their association with a higher risk of atherothrombotic events.

  • COX-2 inhibitors reduce endothelial PGI2 production without affecting platelet TXA2 synthesis → Prothrombotic state → Increased cardiovascular risk.
  • Hence, they should be reserved for high-risk peptic ulcer patients at the lowest dose and shortest duration and avoided in patients with a risk of heart disease.

Aspirin and Naproxen (Options A and B): are safer for cardiovascular patients due to their antiplatelet effects. Aspirin irreversibly inhibits platelet aggregation primarily by inhibiting COX-1, which reduces the risk of cardiovascular events. Similarly, Naproxen's longer half-life and COX inhibition contribute to cardiovascular safety.

Nefopam (Option C): doesn't act on the COX enzyme. It is a serotonin-norepinephrine dopamine reuptake inhibitor (SNDRI). It is used to treat migraines and post-anesthetic shivering. It is not known to cause cardiovascular events like STEMI.

questions.text: The 45-year-old multiparous woman underwent a hysterectomy for abnormal uterine bleeding after failed medical management. The uterus is firm and irregularly enlarged with multiple tumours in the myometrium with a characteristic whorled appearance on cut-section. HPE shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Uterine Fibroid

 

Explanation:

  • Uterine Fibroid presents with heavy bleeding, pelvic pain, and a firm, irregularly enlarged uterus.
  • Histopathology reveals interlacing bundles of smooth muscle cells with a characteristic whorled appearance.
  • Fibroids have an Eosinophilic cytoplasm and oval nuclei (cigar-shaped) with blunt ends.

Adenomyosis (Option A) is the presence of endometrial glands and stroma within the myometrium, usually causing a uniformly enlarged and tender uterus. Histopathologically, adenomyosis shows endometrial glands and stroma interspersed within the myometrium.

 Endometrial Polyps (Option B) present with intermenstrual spotting rather than heavy bleeding. Histopathologically, endometrial polyps show irregularly shaped glands and a fibrous stroma, sometimes with blood vessels.

 Endometriosis (Option D) is endometrial-like tissue outside the uterus, causing chronic pain and infertility, with histopathology showing ectopic endometrial glands and stroma.

questions.text:
Match the following newer hypolipidemic drugs with their corresponding Mechanisms of Action (MOAs):


	
		
			
			Drug
			
			
			Mechanisms of Action
			
		
		
			
			1. Ezetimibe
			
			
			A. Inhibition of cholesterol absorption in the intestines
			
		
		
			
			2. Alirocumab
			
			
			B. Inhibition of PCSK9 enzyme
			
		
		
			
			3. Lomitapide
			
			
			C. Inhibition of microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP)
			
		
		
			
			4. Bempedoic acid
			
			
			D. Inhibition of ATP citrate lyase
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-D

 

Explanation:

 

Ezetimibe
  • Disrupts cholesterol and phytosterol absorption in the small intestines via PCIL1 transporter protein interference.
  • Ezetimibe, with statins, enhances LDL-C reduction by inhibiting statin-induced cholesterol synthesis rise.

PCSK9 inhibitors

  • PCSK9 inhibitors: Monoclonal antibodies block PCSK9 action, promoting LDL receptor recycling and degradation, enhancing LDL clearance.

Lomitapide
  • An inhibitor of microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP).
  • Action on MTP hinders the production of VLDLs in liver cells and chylomicrons in the intestinal epithelial cells.

Bempedoic acid

  • A prodrug transforms into its active state, bempedoic acid-CoA, which competitively blocks ATP Citrate Lyase, diminishing the production of hepatic cholesterol synthesis by limiting the flow of acetyl-CoA to HMG-CoA reductase.

questions.text:
Match the following coronary arteries with the areas of the heart they predominantly supply:


	
		
			
			Coronary Arteries
			
			
			Supplied Areas
			
		
		
			
			1) Right conus artery
			
			
			a) Anterior 2/3 of interventricular septum
			
		
		
			
			2) Left anterior descending artery (LAD)
			
			
			b) Infundibulum of right ventricle
			
		
		
			
			3) Left circumflex artery (LCX)
			
			
			c) Posterior interventricular septum
			
		
		
			
			4) Posterior descending artery (PDA)
			
			
			d) Lateral wall of the left ventricle
			
		
		
			 
			
			e) Apex of the heart
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1- b, 2- a, 3- d, 4- c

Explanation:

Artery

Supplied Region

Right Conus Artery (RCA)

Infundibulum of the right ventricle

Left Anterior Descending (LAD)

Anterior 2/3 of the interventricular septum

Left Circumflex Artery (LCX)

Lateral wall of the left ventricle

Posterior Descending Artery (PDA)

Posterior interventricular septum

 

Arterial Supply of the Heart:

  • The arterial supply to the heart is primarily provided by two main coronary arteries: the right coronary artery (RCA) and the left coronary artery (LCA).
  • These arteries originate from the aortic sinus.

 

Artery

Right Coronary Artery (RCA)

Left Coronary Artery (LCA)

Origin

Arises from the right aortic sinus.

Arises from the left aortic sinus.

Course

Moves forward between the pulmonary trunk and right auricle, descending in the right atrioventricular groove.

Passes forward between the pulmonary trunk and the left auricle, and then splits into two main branches.

Branches

Right Conus Artery:

  • Supplies the pulmonary conus (infundibulum) and the upper right ventricle.
 

Anterior Ventricular Branches:

  • 2 or 3 in number - supply the anterior surface of the right ventricle.
 

Right Marginal Artery:

  • Largest of anterior ventricular branches - runs along the right margin of the heart towards the apex.
 

Posterior Descending Artery (PDA) or the posterior interventricular artery:

  • Travels in the posterior interventricular groove, supplying the inferior wall of both ventricles and the posterior part of the interventricular septum.
  • This artery often arises from the RCA but can also originate from the LCA in some individuals.
 

Atrial Branches:

  • Supply the right atrium and contribute to the SA node in some individuals.

Left Anterior Descending Artery (LAD):

  • Travels down the anterior interventricular groove to the heart’s apex.
  • It supplies both ventricles and the anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum.
 

Left Circumflex Artery (LCX): Circles around the left margin of the heart in the atrioventricular groove, giving off:

 
  • Left Marginal Artery: Supplies the left margin of the left ventricle.
  • Anterior and Posterior Ventricular Branches: Supply the left ventricle.
  • Atrial Branches: Supply the left atrium.
 

Lateral or diagonal artery - larger ventricular branch - may arise directly from the trunk of the left coronary artery.

  • A small left conus artery supplies the pulmonary conus.

questions.text: An infant was brought in due to concerns from her parents about her poor response to loud sounds and reduced reaction to environmental noises compared to her peers. The BERA test shows issues with wave V within the first 10 milliseconds. What site of pathology might this indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lateral lemniscus

 

Explanation:

  • The wave V in BERA (Brainstem evoked response audiometry) represents lateral lemniscus.
  • BERA (brainstem-evoked response audiometry) also known as Auditory brainstem response (ABR) is a non-invasive technique to assess the auditory pathway from the cochlea through the 8th cranial nerve to the brain stem.

  • Electrical potentials are generated in response to several click stimuli or tone bursts and picked up from the vertex by surface electrodes. It measures hearing sensitivity in the range of 1000-4000 Hz.
  • In a normal person, 7 waves are produced in the first 10 ms indicating respective anatomical site as,

    Wave I

    Distal part of CN VIII

    Wave II

    Proximal part of CN VIII near the brainstem

    Wave III

    Cochlear nucleus (Option A)

    Wave IV

    Superior olivary complex (Option B)

    Wave V

    Lateral lemniscus (Option C)

    Wave VI and VII

    Inferior Colliculus (Option D)

     

  • Uses of BERA:
    • As a screening procedure for infants.
    • To determine the threshold of hearing in infants (also in children and adults who do not cooperate) and in malingerers.
    • To diagnose and differentiate retro cochlear pathology (acoustic neuroma) from cochlear.
    • Best audiometric test for acoustic neuroma (delay in wave 5 is suggestive of acoustic neuroma).
    • To diagnose brainstem pathology.
    • To monitor CN VIII intraoperatively during surgery for acoustic neuromas.
  •

questions.text: A 28 y/o woman at 38 weeks pregnant presents with fatigue, shortness of breath, pale appearance, and tongue ulcers. Lab tests show Hb is 8g/dl, Hct is 24%, peripheral smear shows macrocytosis, nucleated RBCs & hyper-segmented neutrophils.. Which investigation result is NOT true of folate deficiency anaemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) MCHC decreased

Explanation:

MCHC measures the concentration of haemoglobin in red blood cells. In folate deficiency, MCHC is typically normal because the concentration of haemoglobin per cell is not affected; rather, it is the size of the cells (MCV) that is increased due to impaired maturation of red blood cells.

Laboratory Investigations in Folic Acid Deficiency

  • Increased homocysteine
  • Normal methylmalonate
  • Haemoglobin level consistently below 10 g% (Option D ruled out)
  • Stained blood film shows:
    • Hypersegmentation of neutrophils (5 or more lobes)
    • Macrocytosis and anisocytosis
    • Giant polymorphs
    • Megaloblasts
    • Howell-Jolly bodies (often in buffy coat preparations)
  • Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) > 100 µ³ (Option B ruled out)
  • Mean corpuscular haemoglobin (MCH) > 33 pg, but MCHC is normal
  • Associated with leukopenia and thrombocytopenia
  • Serum iron levels are normal or high; iron binding capacity is low
  • Red cell folate < 2 ng/mL (normal:2.8-8 ng/mL) (Option A ruled out)
  • Serum vitamin B12 < 90 pg/mL (normal: 300 pg/mL)
  • Serum bilirubin may be elevated
  • Bone marrow examination shows megaloblastic erythropoiesis

questions.text: A patient experiences persistent shoulder pain and weakness after a fall. An MRI reveals a full-thickness rotator cuff tear. Which statement correctly describes the classification of rotator cuff tears?

choices.text: Full-thickness tears involve bursal side tear, within tendon substance
Partial-thickness tears can occur on the articular side or bursal side
Full-thickness tears are typically caused by overuse and repetitive stress
Partial-thickness tears develop gradually due to impingement

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Partial-thickness tears can occur on the articular side or bursal side.

 

Explanation:

 

 

Rotator Cuff Anatomy and Tear Classification

Anatomy of the Rotator Cuff

  • Muscles Involved:
    • Supraspinatus
    • Infraspinatus
    • Teres minor
    • Subscapularis (collectively known as SITS)

Anterior view:

Posterior view:

  • Functions:
    • Stabilizes the shoulder joint
    • Assists in arm rotation and lifting
    • Controls shoulder blade movement

Role of Specific Muscles

  • Supraspinatus & Infraspinatus:
    • Keep the humeral head secure in the glenoid during arm abduction.
  • Subscapularis:
    • Stabilizes the front of the shoulder joint.
    • Prevents anterior dislocation of the humeral head.

Classification of Rotator Cuff Tears

Type

Description

Common Causes

Partial-Thickness Tears

Involve damage to some fibers of the tendon; can occur on:

Bursal side (top)

Articular side (bottom)

Within tendon substance (Option A ruled out) (Option B)

Overuse, repetitive stress (Option C ruled out)

Full-Thickness Tears

Complete rupture of the tendon; not attached to the bone

Sudden injuries (e.g., falls), gradual development due to stress or impingement (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution: Option A can be explained by malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins (vitamin K) in stool due to lack of pancreatic lipase in CF. option C is earliest manifestation of CF. Option D is sinonasal manifestation of CF.

questions.text:
A 35 y/o female presents with recurrent urinary tract infections and mild flank pain. An ultrasound reveals a cystic dilation near the lower ureter, and an IVU is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Ureterocele

 

Explanation:

The given IVU shows- a smooth, rounded structure with a radiolucent halo at the ureterovesical junction, also known as the "cobra head" appearance, which is a hallmark of a ureterocele. It results from cystic dilation of the distal ureter, which can cause recurrent infections, as seen in this case.

 

  • A ureterocele is a congenital dilation of the terminal part of the ureter where it enters the bladder. It consists of layers of ureteric and bladder epithelium.
  • Cobraneck appearance on IVU is a hallmark feature where a dilated contrast-filled ureter is surrounded by a thin rim of the ureteric wall and bladder mucosa, typically measuring less than 2 mm in diameter.

 

Ureterocele

 

 

 

 

Note: 

  • Maiden waist deformity is a term given to describe the medial deviation of both ureters. 
  • Commonly seen in retroperitoneal fibrosis or unilateral cases of retrocaval ureter.
  • The ureters take a narrow, waist-like shape, resembling the waist of a maiden, usually at the level of the lumbosacral junction.

 

Vesicoureteral reflux (Option B): While reflux can lead to recurrent UTIs, it does not present with the cobra head appearance described on imaging. 

 

Hydronephrosis (Option C): This condition results from obstruction, leading to dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces. However, it does not produce the specific cobra head appearance at the ureterovesical junction.

 

Renal calculi (Option D): While stones can cause flank pain and UTIs, they appear as radiopaque densities on imaging and do not have the cobra head sign seen with a ureterocele.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old man presents to the emergency department with high fever, chills, and a painful swelling in his axillary region. He reports that he recently returned from a trip to Himachal Pradesh. On physical examination, a large, tender lymph node is noted in the axillary region. Aspirate when stained with methylene blue is shown in the image below.



Which of the following organisms does not show a similar typical appearance as seen in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Clostridium tetani

Explanation:

  • The clinical picture (high fever, chills, tender axillary lymph node) and morphological appearance on staining with new methylene blue (Waysons stain) points to the case of Bubonic plague, caused by Yersinia pestis.
  • Yersinia pestis characteristically shows safety pin appearance.

Safety pin appearance is shown by the following organisms:

  • Yersinia pestis
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus (Option B)
  • Burkholderia mallei
  • Burkholderia pseudomallei (Option A)
  • Haemophilus ducreyi
  • Klebsiella granulomatis (Option D)

Clostridium tetani is a Gram-positive, spore-forming anaerobic bacillus. It typically appears as a "drumstick" or "tennis racket" shape under the microscope due to the terminal spores.

 

Plague (Yersinia pestis)

Endemic Foci
  • Kolar (Tamil Nadu),
  • Beed Latur (Maharashtra)
  • Rhoru (Himachal)

Reservoir

Wild rodents

Vector

Rat flea (Xenopsylla cheopis, Xenopsylla astia)

Types of Plague
  • Bubonic Plague: 2-7 days incubation period; Lymph node painful enlargement and fever
  • Pneumonic Plague: 1-3 days incubation period; Respiratory symptoms; Associated with bio-terrorism
  • Septicemic Plague: 2-7 days incubation period; A/k/a Black death; DIC, shock and multi-organ failure

Microscopic Findings

Safety pin appearance (Bipolar staining) using Wayson stain, Wright stain, Giemsa stain

Culture
  • Nutrient broth with oil/ghee (Ghee broth): Stalactite growth (hanging from the top)
  • Selective CIN agar: Bullseye colonies

 

Biochemical Reactions
  • Fermentation [+ve acid production -ve gas production]
  • Catalase positive
  • Oxidase negative
  • IMViC = - - + -

Vaccine

  • Recombinant R1F1v Vaccine: Pre-exposure Prophylaxis
  • Sokhey's Modification of Haffkine Vaccine- Protects only against bubonic plague,

Treatment

  • Streptomycin
  • Fluoroquinolones: For CNS and cardiovascular involvement

questions.text: Patient who is a known case of alcoholic liver disease is being planned for a dental extraction procedure. Which of the following local anesthetic can be safely administered in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Articaine

 

Explanation:

  • All the following drugs (in options) belong to Aminoamides group of local anesthetics.
  • All aminoamides undergo Enzymatic degradation in Liver except Articaine - undergoes metabolism by Plasma cholinesterase.
  • In a patient with Liver disease, aminoamide that can be safely administered is Articaine, which is also usually preferred for short dental procedures.

 

Aminoesters & Aminoamides:

 

Aminoesters

(1 “i” in names)

Aminoamides

(2 “i” in names)

Drugs
  • Procaine
  • Chloroprocaine
  • Tetracaine
  • Cocaine
  • Lidocaine
  • Mepivacaine
  • Prilocaine
  • Bupivacaine
  • Ropivacaine

Duration of action & stability
  • Short; stable
  • Long; unstable in solution

Metabolism
  • Plasma cholinesterase
  • Exception: Cocaine (metabolized in liver)
  • Enzymatic degradation in Liver
  • Exception: Articaine (undergoes metabolism by plasma cholinesterase)

Metabolism rate
  • Rapidly metabolized: Chloroprocaine
  • Rapidly metabolized rate: Lignocaine > Mepivacaine > Bupivacaine

Allergic potential
  • Maximum with Prilocaine and Benzocaine

questions.text: A 5-month-old male infant with a history of vomiting, irritability, and developmental delay. The onset of symptoms coincided with the introduction of formula feed. Physical examination revealed hepatomegaly and signs of encephalopathy. Blood tests revealed elevated ammonia levels and high glutamine, uracil, and orotic acid concentrations. Citrulline levels were normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Type 2 Hyperammonemia

 

Explanation:

The infant's symptoms and laboratory findings with the timing of symptom onset after the introduction of the formula are highly suggestive of Type 2 Hyperammonemia.

 

Feature

Type 1 Hyperammonemia

Type 2 Hyperammonemia

Defective Enzyme

Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase I (CPS1)

Ornithine Transcarbamylase (OTC)

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

X-linked recessive

Mechanism

The inability to synthesize carbamoyl phosphate blocks the urea cycle.

Accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate in the mitochondria, which then spills over into the cytoplasm.

Metabolic Consequences
  • Elevated ammonia and glutamate
  • Normal orotic acid and uracil
  • Low citrulline. (Option A)
  • Elevated ammonia, glutamate, and glutamine.
  • High uracil and orotic acid (excess carbamoyl phosphate enters pyrimidine synthesis).
  • Normal citrulline.

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms coincide with increased protein intake.
  • CNS: Lethargy, drowsiness, coma, Convulsions, vomiting, respiratory stimulation, hyperventilation.
  • Similar to Type 1.
  • Hepatomegaly.


 

Citrullinemia and Argininosuccinate aciduria (Option C and D) would result in elevated citrulline levels, contradicting the normal citrulline finding in this scenario.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient undergoes emergency abdominal surgery for a perforated sigmoid diverticulitis with peritonitis. The surgeon decides to create a stoma as part of the management plan. Which of the following stomas is most appropriate for diverting fecal content and allowing distal bowel healing while planning for potential future reconnection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Loop ileostomy

 

Explanation:

A loop ileostomy is commonly used to divert fecal content in emergency situations and allows for the distal bowel to heal, making it ideal for temporary diversion. It provides an easy way to reverse the stoma when the patient is stable and reconnection is feasible.

 

Types of Stomas

Rarely used; can be for cases requiring both resection and exteriorization, offering mucous fistula
