questions.text:
Match bacterial uveitis in column A with corresponding clinical manifestation in column B


 


	
		
			
			Bacterial uveitis
			
			
			Clinical features
			
		
		
			
			1. Tubercular uveitis
			
			
			a. Iris pearls
			
		
		
			
			2. Leprotic uveitis
			
			
			b. Iris roceola
			
		
		
			
			3. Spirochetal uveitis
			
			
			c. Headlight in fog appearance
			
		
		
			
			d. Koeppe’s nodules
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-d, 2-a, 3-b

Explanation:

 

Bacterial uveitis

Clinical features

1. Tubercular uveitis

d. Koeppe’s nodules

2. Leprotic uveitis

a. Iris pearls

3. Spirochetal uveitis

b. Iris roceola

 

Bacterial uveitis:

  • Tuberculosis
  • Syphilis
  • Leprosy

 

Tubercular uveitis:

  • Causes both anterior, intermediate, posterior, and panuveitis
  • Occurs as acute non-granulomatous iridocyclitis or granulomatous anterior uveitis
  • Granulomatous inflammation causes iris nodules in the pupillary margin (Koeppe nodule) or anterior mid-iris (Busacca nodule)
  • Exudative non-granulomatous type of iritis is probably allergic or immunoinflammatory in nature

Koeppe nodule

 

 

Treatment: Rifampicin, isoniazid, ethambutol and pyrazinamide

 

Spirochetal uveitis:

  • Organism: Treponema pallidum
  • Anterior uveitis:
    • It can present as granulomatous or non-granulomatous iritis typically in the secondary syphilis stage
    • Iris roseola - dilated iris vessels that develop into nodules
    • ‘Plastic’ iritis occurs in congenital syphilis and Jarisch–Herxheimer reaction


  • Posterior uveitis:
    • It occurs as disseminated, peripheral, or diffuse choroiditis.
  • Treatment: Systemic penicillin

 

Leprotic uveitis:

  • Organism-Mycobacterium leprae
  • It occurs as acute non granulomatous iritis or chronic granulomatous iritis
  • Chronic granulomatous iritis occurs due to direct invasion of the organismal and is characterized by 'iris pearls' near the pupillary margin in a necklace form.

  • Small pearls enlarge and coalesce to form large pearls
  • Other ocular manifestations: Conjunctivitis, episcleritis, exposure keratopathy because of involvement of the facial nerve, and neurotrophic keratopathy due to involvement of the trigeminal nerve
  • Treatment:
    • Dapsone
    • Rifampicin, ofloxacin, clofazimine and minocycline in combination with dapsone

questions.text:
Match the following


	
		
			
			1. Leishman Donovan bodies
			
			
			a)

			
			
		
		
			
			2. Dohle bodies
			
			
			b)

			
			
		
		
			
			3. Henderson Petersen bodies
			
			
			c)

			
			
		
		
			
			4. Cowdry Type A bodies
			
			
			d)
questions.solution:
Histopathological Bodies in Microbiology

Leishman Donovan (LD) bodies

  • Found in untreated leishmaniasis.
  • They are light blue, ellipsoid structures measuring 2-4 μm in length.
  • LD bodies have an eccentric nucleus and a smaller kinetosome at the opposite pole.
  • These bodies are located within large macrophages (also known as Wright's cells).

Dohle bodies

  • Light blue-grey, oval, basophilic staining inclusions were found in the cytoplasm of neutrophils in the peripheral smear.
  • Seen in bacterial infections like tuberculosis, diphtheria, and typhoid,
  • Indicate defective neutrophil production and maturation.

Hendersen Petersen bodies

  • Molluscum contagiosum, caused by a poxvirus, is characterised by the presence of large, ellipsoid intracytoplasmic inclusions in the stratum spinosum and corneum of infected skin known as Henderson-Peterson bodies.
  • They are made up of nuclear and cytoplasmic protein aggregates and mark the site of viral replication.

Councilman Bodies

  • Acidophilic inclusion bodies are found in the cytoplasm of hepatocytes in viral infections like hepatitis and yellow fever.
  • These bodies result from hepatocyte apoptosis and are associated with ballooning degeneration of liver cells.

Cowdry Type A bodies

  • Cowdry bodies are eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions made of nucleic acid and protein, seen in infections like herpes, yellow fever, polio, and adenovirus.
  • Type A (found in herpes and yellow fever) appears as droplet-like masses with clear halos and chromatin margination around the nucleus.
  • Type B (associated with polio and adenovirus) lacks nuclear changes.

Negri bodies

  • Negri bodies are eosinophilic, cytoplasmic inclusion bodies found in neurons, primarily in rabies infection.
  • They represent sites of viral replication and are considered a hallmark of rabies in histopathological examination.

Torres bodies

The intranuclear inclusion body seen in liver cells infected with the yellow fever virus is composed of host proteins.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with acute lower abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She has a history of amenorrhea for the past 7 weeks and reports dizziness and lightheadedness. Her vitals indicate hypotension with a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg and a heart rate of 110 bpm. Transvaginal ultrasound is unavailable at the facility. The physician decides to perform a culdocentesis to aid in the diagnosis.
Which of the following findings from the culdocentesis would suggest a ruptured ectopic pregnancy?

choices.text: Clear fluid aspirated from the pouch of Douglas
Clotting blood with a hematocrit greater than 15%
Non-clotting blood with a hematocrit greater than 15%
Purulent fluid aspirated from the pouch of Douglas

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Non-clotting blood with a hematocrit greater than 15%

Explanation:
Culdocentesis is a diagnostic procedure that involves the aspiration of fluid from the pouch of Douglas (the rectouterine pouch) through the posterior fornix of the vagina using an 18-gauge lumbar puncture needle fitted with a syringe.

  • This procedure is useful for diagnosing ruptured ectopic when diagnostic tools such as transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) or laparoscopy are not available.
  • Non-clotting blood with a hematocrit greater than 15% in the aspirate suggests a ruptured ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text:
Match the following cytotoxic drugs with their primary uses:


	
		
			
			Cytotoxic Drugs
			
			
			Primary Use
			
		
		
			
			1. Temozolomide
			
			
			A. Treatment of Hodgkin's lymphoma
			
		
		
			
			2. Dacarbazine
			
			
			B. DOC of glioma tumors
			
		
		
			
			3. Trabectedin
			
			
			C. Organophosphate used in myeloablative procedures
			
		
		
			
			4. Thiotepa
			
			
			D. Used in cisplatin-resistant ovarian cancer cases
			
		
		
			
			5. Altretamine
			
			
			E. Treatment of leiomyosarcoma
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-B, 2-A, 3-E, 4-C, 5-D

Explanation:

Miscellaneous Alkylating agents used as Cytotoxic drugs

Alkylating agents are chemotherapy drugs that attach alkyl groups to DNA, causing cross-linking, disrupting replication, and leading to cell death.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman with fair skin and a history of teenage sunburns presents with a mole on her upper back that has become larger and darker over the past few months. The lesion is pigmented with irregular borders, color variation, asymmetry, slight elevation, and measures 1.5 cm in diameter. She reports occasional itching and tenderness but denies bleeding or ulceration. Identify the true statements regarding this condition.


	The most common type is nodular melanoma.
	CDKN2A mutation is most commonly involved in sporadic melanoma.
	Depth > 6 mm is suggestive of melanoma.
	Clark’s classification is used in malignant melanoma.
	Interferon-𝛼 can be used for the prevention of metastasis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 4,5

Explanation:

1. Nodular melanoma (False): Superficial spreading is the most common type.

2. CDKN2A (False): BRAF mutation is more common in sporadic melanoma.

3. Depth >6 mm (False): >6 mm size raises suspicion, but Breslow depth is for staging.

4. Clark’s classification (True): Used for assessing melanoma invasion depth.

5. Interferon-α (True): Used as adjuvant therapy to prevent metastasis in high-risk melanoma.

Types of melanoma:

Type

Site

Description

Superficial spreading (M/C type)

Any (more common on the upper back and, in women, lower legs)

Brown mixed with bluish-red, bluish-black, reddish brown,

and often whitish pink. The lesion border is often visibly

and/or palpably raised

Lentigo maligna

Sun-exposed surfaces, particularly malar region and temple

In flat portions, brown and tan predominate, but whitish

grey sometimes present; in nodules, reddish brown, bluish grey, bluish-black.

Acral lentiginous

Palm, sole, nail bed, mucous membrane

In flat portions, dark brown; in raised lesions (plaques),

brown-black or blue-black.

Nodular

Any

Reddish blue, purple, or bluish-black; can be uniform or mixed with brown and black.

 

 

 

Investigations:

  • Clinical examination.
  • Genetics: Mutations in genes such as BRAF, NRAS, and NF1 are common in sporadic melanoma, driving tumor progression through the MAPK pathway
  • Dermoscopy.
  • Biopsy.
  • Immunohistochemistry: The markers are S-100, HMB-45 (the most specific), Melan-A (MART-1), and MITF.
  • CT scan.

 

Breslow’s and Clarke’s Classifications of Malignant Melanoma:

 

Stage

Classification

Clarke

Breslow

I

Involvement of epidermis

≤ 0.75 mm

II

Involvement of epidermis + dermis

0.76-1.5 mm

III

Involvement of dermal papillae

1.5-4 mm

IV

Involvement of reticular dermis

>4 mm

V

Involvement of subcutaneous tissue

-

 

 

Management:

  • Wide local excision (with margins measured before excision and determined by Breslow depth, sentinel lymph node biopsy indicated for tumours with a depth of >1.0 mm).
  • If the tumour is aggressive:
    • Immunotherapy.
    • Chemotherapy.
    • Targeted therapy.
  • Interferon-𝛼 is the only adjuvant treatment that has documented beneficial effects on overall survival.

questions.text: Following an RTA, a structure passing through the marked foramen was injured. Which of the following defects is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Loss of sensation over cheek

 

Explanation:

  • Image shows Sphenoid bone with lesser wing and the opening marked is foramen rotundum.
  • Maxillary division of Trigeminal nerve (V2) and emissary vein passes through foramen rotundum and hence loss of sensations of cheek would be the defect seen in this patient.

Superior view:
  • Optic canal
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Foramen rotundum
  • Foramen spinosum

Posterior view - Greater wing:
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Scaphoid fossa
  • Pterygoid fossa

Posterior view - Lesser wing:
  • Optic canal
  • Opening of sphenoid sinus
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Foramen rotundum
  • Pterygoid canal

  • Loss of corneal reflex (Option A): Seen with injury to Ophthalmic division of trigeminal (V2), which passes through superior orbital fissure.
  • Loss of jaw jerk (Option B): Seen with injury to Mandibular division of trigeminal (V3), which passes through foramen spinosum.
  • Inability to abduct eye (Option C): Abduction of eye is done by lateral rectus, supplied by Abducens Nerve (VI) which passes through superior orbital fissure.

questions.text: A 32-year-old HIV-positive male presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of worsening shortness of breath, dry cough, and fever. He reports significant weight loss over the past month and has a CD4 count of 150 cells/mm³. HRCT Thorax shows ground-glass opacities. A bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) is performed, and a histological examination shows organisms with a characteristic appearance, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pneumocystis Carinii pneumonia (PCP)

Explanation:

Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia (PCP), now known as Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia, is a common opportunistic infection in immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with HIV/AIDS.

Pneumocystis jirovecii

Morphology
  1. Trophozoite - thin-walled, irregularly shaped, 1-5 µm in size
  2. Precyst - an intermediate stage of the sexual phase, 5-8 µm in size
  3. Cyst - thick-walled, spherical, containing up to 8 intracystic bodies and up to 8 µm in size

Risk factors
  • HIV: CD4 < 200
  • Primary immunodeficiency states
  • Transplant recipients
  • Hematological malignancies

Clinical features

transmitted by respiratory droplets and is asymptomatic in immunocompetent individuals. In immunocompromised patients, life-threatening pneumonia develops.

PCP - Pneumocystis Carinii pneumonia

  • Dyspnoea
  • Dry cough
  • Fever
  • Weight loss
  • B/L interstitial pneumonia

Diagnosis
  • GMS / Giemsa stain- mc used
  • Giemsa, toluidine blue, methenamine silver, and calcofluor white stains can demonstrate trophozoites - cyst wall is black with a methenamine silver stain.

Crushed Ping Pong ball (also called Helmet/Hat or Cup and Saucer appearance).

 

  • The β-d-glucan test has proven to be quite useful for rapid diagnosis of Pneumocystis pneumonia with a high degree of sensitivity and specificity.

Treatment
  • The cornerstone for both prevention and treatment is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.
 
  • Alternative therapies have been used in AIDS patients; they include pentamidine, trimethoprim-dapsone, clindamycin-primaquine, atovaquone, and trimetrexate.

 

Bacterial pneumonia (Option A): Is caused by various bacteria (e.g., Streptococcus pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus) and typically presents with symptoms such as productive cough, high fever, and localized crackles on auscultation. Chest X-rays often show lobar consolidation rather than the diffuse ground-glass opacities characteristic of PCP.

 

Tuberculosis (TB) (Option B): Is a chronic infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It usually presents with a persistent cough, night sweats, weight loss, and hemoptysis.

 

Fungal pneumonia (Option D): Can be caused by various fungi, such as Histoplasma, Coccidioides, or Cryptococcus. These infections typically present differently from PCP, often with more localized symptoms and findings on imaging

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and fever. Imaging reveals a gallstone eroding less than one-third of the circumference of the common bile duct. What is the management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Partial cholecystectomy with choledochoplasty

 

Explanation:

This patient’s presentation matches the features of Type II Mirizzi syndrome, characterized by a gallstone eroding less than one-third of the circumference of the common bile duct (CBD) or common hepatic duct (CHD). Type II Mirizzi syndrome is managed by partial cholecystectomy with choledochoplasty.

 

Csendes classification:

 

Mirizzi’s Type

Features

Treatment

Type I

Extrinsic compression of the CBD/CHD by a large impacted stone in Hartmann's pouch;

  • IA- the presence of cystic duct
  • IB- is obliterated cystic duct

Subtotal/Partial cholecystectomy + ERCP stenting
(Option C ruled out)

Type II

The stone has eroded the CBD/CHD less than 1/3rd circumference of the CBD/CHD forming a fistula

Partial cholecystectomy with choledochoplasty

Type III

Involving up to 2/3rd of the circumference of CBD/ CHO

Partial cholecystectomy with choledochoplasty

Type IV

Cholecystocholedochal fistula (>2/3rd) involving the entire circumference of the CBD/CHD

Bilio-enteric anastomosis
(Option A ruled out)

TypeV

Cholecystocholedochal fistula with cholecystoenteric fistula without gallstone ileus (VA) or with

gallstone ileus (VB)

Bilio-enteric anastomosis


 

 

Percutaneous cholecystostomy (Option B): Typically a temporary measure for critically ill patients who cannot undergo immediate surgery

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the median incubation period?

choices.text: Shortest time from exposure to symptom onset in 50% of cases
Longest time from exposure to symptom onset in 50% of cases
Average time from exposure to recovery in 50% of cases
Average time from exposure to symptom onset in 50% of cases

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Average time from exposure to symptom onset in 50% of cases

Explanation:

The median incubation period is the time for 50% of cases to show symptoms after exposure.

  • The incubation period is the time between infection and the first symptom appearance.
  • During incubation, the pathogen multiplies until it reaches a threshold to cause symptoms.
  • Most diseases aren't communicable during incubation, except for measles and chickenpox.
  • Incubation periods vary by disease and individual, ranging from hours to years.
  • Examples:
    • Short (hours to days): Food poisoning, cholera.
    • Medium (10 days to 3 weeks): Typhoid, COVID-19, measles.
    • Long (weeks to years): Hepatitis, Rabies, leprosy.
  • Non-infectious diseases like cancer also have incubation periods, often lasting months or years.

Shortest time from exposure to symptom onset in 50% of cases (Option A) describes the minimum incubation period, not the median.

Longest time from exposure to symptom onset in 50% of cases (Option B) describes the maximum incubation period, not the median.

Average time from exposure to recovery in 50% of cases (Option C) describes the average recovery time, not the incubation period.

questions.text:
Assertion: Eggplant deformity is a clinical manifestation observed in penile fracture cases.
Reason: It is caused by a tear in the corpus spongiosum layer of the penis.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are correct, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are correct, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The Assertion is correct, but the Reason is incorrect
The Assertion is incorrect, but the Reason is correct

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The Assertion is correct, but the Reason is incorrect.

 

Explanation:

  • Eggplant deformity, which is characterized by significant swelling and bruising of the penile shaft, is indeed a clinical sign of penile fracture.
  • The deformity occurs due to a tear in the tunica albuginea, the fibrous covering of the corpora cavernosa that maintains penile rigidity.
  • The tear leads to the leakage of blood and accumulation in the surrounding tissue.

 

Penile Fracture (Fracture of the Shaft of the Penis)

Definition

Rupture of the tunica albuginea surrounding the corpora cavernosa, typically due to blunt trauma to an erect penis.

Clinical Features

Triad Symptoms:

  • Audible Pop or Crack: Reported during trauma.
  • Pain: Severe at the time of injury.
  • Swelling and Bruising: Noticeable swelling and discoloration.
 

Eggplant Deformity:

  • Characteristic appearance due to extensive swelling and hematoma, associated with significant pain and discoloration.
 

Blood at Urethral Meatus: Indicates possible urethral injury.

Investigations
  • Physical Examination: Initial assessment.
  • Ultrasound: Evaluates injury extent and hematomas.
  • Retrograde Urethrogram (RGU): Checks for urethral injury.

Management

Immediate Care:

  • Ice packs to reduce swelling
  • Pain management with analgesics

Surgical Intervention:

  • Repair of the ruptured tunica albuginea and any urethral injury

Postoperative Care:

  • Antibiotics to prevent infection

Complications
  • Penile Deformity: Possible curvature or fibrosis.
  • Erectile Dysfunction: Potential if injury or repair is inadequate.

questions.text:
Match the following images with appropriate tests.

 


	
		
			
			 

			1. 
			
			
			a) Dugas test
			
		
		
			
			2. 
			
			
			b) Callaway test
			
		
		
			
			3. 
			
			
			c) Hamilton ruler test
			
		
		
			
			4. 
			
			
			d) Regimen batch sign
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b

 

Explanation:

 

Tests of Shoulder dislocation

Hamilton's ruler test

Measures the distance from the acromion to the lateral epicondyle with the arm in a neutral position. A lack of gap between the arm and the ruler indicates dislocation.

Dugas test

The inability to touch the opposite shoulder with a shoulder dislocation is typically observed in anterior dislocations.

 

Callaway test

The circumference of the axilla is checked bilaterally using a measuring tape. An increased circumference on the affected side is diagnostic of dislocation.

Bryants test

It involves observing the anterior axillary fold, displaced inferiorly on the affected side in shoulder dislocation.

Regimen batch sign

Loss of sensation over the deltoid on the affected side due to axillary nerve damage.

questions.text:
Match the type of cyst with the correct description of it.


	
		
			
			Types of Cysts
			
			
			Description
			
		
		
			
			1. Functional cyst
			
			
			A. A mucus-filled cyst on the cervix
			
		
		
			
			2. Gartner’s cyst
			
			
			B. Forms due to remnants of the Wolffian duct
			
		
		
			
			3. Skene’s cyst
			
			
			C. Located near the urethra in females
			
		
		
			
			4. Nabothian cyst
			
			
			D. Commonly occurs in the ovaries
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-D, 2-B, 3-C, 4-A

 

Explanation:

Type of Cyst

Description

Details

Functional Cyst

Fluid-filled sacs that form on the ovaries, typically during the menstrual cycle.
  •  2 Types:
    1. Follicular cysts form due to hormonal dysfunction prior to ovulation, leading to expansion of the follicular antrum with serous fluid.
    2. Corpus luteum cysts form due to excessive hemorrhage from the vascular corpus luteum following ovulation.
  • High-dose combination oral contraceptives (COCs) suppress ovarian activity and protect against cyst development.
  • Surgical excision is considered for large, persistent cysts or smaller ones causing persistent symptoms. Usually benign and not cancerous.

Gartner’s Cyst

Forms from remnants of the Wolffian duct
  • Located along vaginal walls
  • Can cause discomfort, urinary issues, or dyspareunia if large
  • Treatment may involve surgical removal if symptomatic

Skene’s Cyst

Located near the urethra in females, formed from the Skene’s glands.
  • Involved in lubrication of the urethral opening. Usually presents as a urethral diverticulum.
  • Cysts here can cause urinary problems, pain, or discomfort.
  • Treatment may include antibiotics for infection or surgical drainage/removal if necessary.

Nabothian Cyst

Mucus-filled cysts that occur on the cervix.
  • Form when mucus-producing glands in the cervix are covered by skin cells, trapping the mucus.
  • Generally harmless, asymptomatic and often found during routine pelvic exams.
  • No treatment is typically required unless they cause significant symptoms, in which case they can be drained or removed.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a chronic cough and shortness of breath. Upon further inquiry, it is revealed that he has been a smoker for 20 years, averaging a pack a day. His doctor discusses the risks of smoking and recommends nicotine cessation drugs to help him quit. Which of the following may be prescribed first-line?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Bupropion

Explanation: 

Bupropion is a first-line drug used for smoking cessation.

Smoking de-addiction drugs:

 

Mechanism of Action

Effect on Smoking Cessation

First-Line Drugs

    

Bupropion
(Option D)

Blocks reuptake of dopamine and norepinephrine in the brain

Reduces nicotine withdrawal symptoms and cravings

Nicotine Replacement Therapy (NRT)

Provides controlled nicotine dose (patches, gum, lozenges, inhalers). Never given orally, sublingual due to its fast absorption

Alleviates withdrawal symptoms and cravings, gradually reducing nicotine dependence

Varenicline

Binds to nicotine receptors in the brain, partially stimulating them.

Most effective drug.

Reduces cravings and pleasurable effects of smoking.

Used in tobacco chewing.
S/E: Depression (suicides)

All first-line drugs are C/I in seizures and heart diseases (MI, angina, hypertension)

Second-Line Drugs

    

Clonidine
(Option B)

Alpha-2 adrenergic agonist, reduces sympathetic nervous system activity

Alleviates withdrawal symptoms such as anxiety, irritability, and restlessness.
Safe in patients with heart disease/seizure.

Nortriptyline

(Option C)

Tricyclic antidepressant, affecting norepinephrine and serotonin levels

Reduces withdrawal symptoms and cravings

Topiramate

(Option A)

Blocks glutamate receptors and facilitates GABA neurotransmission

Potentially facilitates smoking cessation

Mecamylamine

Blocks nicotine receptors in the brain

Reduces the rewarding effects of nicotine, making smoking less appealing.

Used in nicotine poisoning.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false ?

choices.text: The best way to dispose of sputum is incineration
Inertization includes mixing waste with cement and other substances before disposal
Contents of red bag should be incinerated
Screw Feed Technique is contraindicated for radiological waste

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Contents of the red bag should be incinerated.

 

Explanation:

The contents of red bags should not be incinerated as they contain cadmium which is explosive.

 

Inertization:

  • Mainly used for Pharmaceutical waste.
  • Mixing waste with cement and other substances before disposal. (Option B)
  • Mixture includes:
    • 65% pharmaceutical work.
    • 15% lime.
    • 15% cement.
    • 5% water.

 

Screw feed technique:

  • Biomedical waste + Auger + Heat + Rotate.
  • Weight reduced by 20-25%.
  • Volume reduced by 80%.
  • Used for infectious waste and sharp waste.
  • Contraindicated for radiological waste, cytological waste and pathological waste. (Option D)

 

Incineration:

  • High-temperature, dry oxidation process that reduces organic and combustible waste to inorganic, incombustible matter.
  • Reduction of waste volume (85 - 95%) and weight (30%).
  • The best way to dispose of sputum is incineration as it falls under infectious bodily waste. (Option A)
  • Incineration is not suitable for
    • Pressurized gas containers.
    • Reactive chemicals
    • Halogenated plastics (PVC).
    • Waste with high mercury (eg thermometer)
    • Sealed ampoules containing heavy metals and sharps.
    • Contents of the red bag, as they contain cadmium which is explosive. (Option C)

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			Disease
			
			
			Mammography features
			
		
		
			
			a. Fibroadenoma
			
			
			(i) Eggshell calcification
			
		
		
			
			b. Fat Necrosis
			
			
			(ii) Broken-needle appearance
			
		
		
			
			c. Duct ectasia
			
			
			(iii) Teacup calcification
			
		
		
			
			d. Fibrocystic disease
			
			
			(iv) Popcorn calcifications
questions.solution:
Answer: A) a-iv, b-i, c-ii, d-iii

 

Explanation:

Findings of various conditions on mammography

Condition

Mammographic Findings

Fibroadenoma

Round, well-circumscribed mass with smooth borders; "popcorn" calcifications in older lesions. Benign.

Fat Necrosis

Irregular, spiculated mass with calcifications; central fat density - Eggshell calcification. Often mimics malignancy.

Ductal Carcinoma in Situ (DCIS)

Microcalcifications (Segmental distribution of pleomorphic microcalcifications), often linear or branching, are associated with malignancy.

Invasive Ductal Carcinoma

Irregular, spiculated mass with poorly defined margins. Microcalcifications and architectural distortion.

Fibrocystic disease

Teacup calcification represents the layering out of calcific material in the dependent portion of microcysts on a lateral magnification view.

Duct ectasia

Broken-needle appearance, typical of duct ectasia. Sometimes thicker, more localized calcifications can be seen, giving a ‘lead-pipe’ appearance.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male is scheduled for a neck dissection due to metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the oral cavity. Which incision will the surgeon choose to provide optimal access to all cervical lymph node levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Modified Schobinger incision

 

Explanation:

  • Modified Schobinger Incision is the most preferred incision for adequate access to all levels of the neck lymph nodes.

 

Types of Incisions in Neck Dissection

 

1. Macfee Incision:

  • Two horizontal parallel incisions.
  • Provide the best scar cosmesis.
  • Limited access to deeper structures.

 

 

2. Modified Macfee Incision:

  • Improves access to all neck node levels and a narrow bridge, thus facilitating an easier dissection of the spinal accessory nerve.

 

3. Reversed Hockey Stick Incision:

  • Long anterior skin flap, superior access to all five lymph node levels.

questions.text: Young lady comes with complaints of difficulty in swallowing food, skin tightening of fingers and finger-tip discoloration on putting hands in cold water. Face shows telangiectasias. Work up show ANA positive and following IF pattern is present. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: The clinical features are diagnostic of CREST syndrome which is diagnosed by anti-centromere antibodies. The pattern in image shown is nucleolar pattern.

questions.text:
A patient with a longstanding history of alcoholism is admitted with jaundice, abdominal distension & weight loss. A liver biopsy done during his previous admission showed the following changes, and suspicion of malignant transformation is raised now. Elevation of which of the following markers will support the differential?


	HepPar-1
	Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)
	Glypican-3 (GPC3)
	CA 15-3
	Tissue polypeptide antigen
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1,2 and 3

Explanation :

The following markers will be elevated in case of hepatocellular carcinoma :

  • HepPar-1 (Statement 1)
  • Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) (Statement 2)
  • Glypican-3 (GPC3) (Statement 3)
  • Neurotensin
  • Arginase-1
  • CA-19-9

 

Chronic liver disease with cirrhosis is the major cause of transformation into hepatocellular carcinoma, and some of the common causes are listed below :

  • Alcohol (as given in the above scenario)
  • Chronic hepatitis B & C
  • Metabolic diseases
  • Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis
  • Aflatoxins from Aspergillus

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with severe shortness of breath, cough, and fever after recent bacterial pneumonia. Physical examination shows tachypnea, hypoxia, and diffuse crackles on chest auscultation. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral opacities suggestive of pulmonary oedema. Histopathological examination of lung biopsy shows congested, edematous lungs with inflammation. Which histopathological finding is characteristic of the acute exudative stage in this patient's lung injury?

choices.text: Formation of fibrotic thickening in the alveolar septa
Presence of waxy hyaline membranes lining the alveolar walls
Resolution of granulation tissue in the alveolar spaces

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Presence of waxy hyaline membranes lining the alveolar walls

 

Explanation:

  • In the acute exudative stage of lung injury, such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) triggered by bacterial pneumonia, lungs exhibit characteristic waxy hyaline membranes lining the alveolar walls.
  • These membranes comprise fibrin-rich oedema fluid mixed with remnants of necrotic epithelial cells, representing a hallmark feature of acute lung injury and ARDS.

 

Pathological changes seen in acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)

 

Stage

Features

1. Acute Exudative Stage
  • Lungs appear heavy, firm, red, and boggy.
  • Manifestations include congestion, interstitial and intra-alveolar oedema, inflammation, fibrin deposition, and diffuse alveolar damage.
  • Alveolar walls are lined with “waxy hyaline membranes” composed of fibrin-rich oedema fluid mixed with remnants of necrotic epithelial cells.

2. Proliferative or Organizing Stage
  • Proliferation of Type II pneumocytes.
  • Granulation tissue forms in the alveolar walls and spaces.

3. Late Fibrotic Stage
  • Fibrotic thickening of alveolar septa indicates persistent fibrosis and scarring that may develop in some cases of lung injury.

questions.text: A 22-year-old college student is brought to the emergency department by his friends after exhibiting bizarre behavior at a party. He appears disoriented, has dilated pupils, and reports seeing vivid colors and patterns. His vital signs show tachycardia and mild hypertension. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) intoxication

Explanation:
The patient's symptoms, including disorientation, dilated pupils, visual hallucinations (seeing vivid colors and patterns), tachycardia, and mild hypertension, are consistent with LSD intoxication.

Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD)

Chemical nature

Synthetic base derived from lysergic acid nucleus from ergot alkaloids

Common forms

Tablets, liquid, blotter paper ("blotter acid")

Potency

100 µg of LSD ≈ 10-15 mg of psilocybin ≈ 300-400 mg of mescaline

Onset and duration

Onset within an hour, peaks in 2-4 hours, lasts 8-12 hours

Common physiologic symptoms

• Dilated pupils

• Increased deep tendon motor reflexes

• Muscle tension

• Mild motor incoordination

• Ataxia

Occasional physiologic symptoms

• Increased heart rate

• Increased respiration

• Hypertension

• Nausea

• Decreased appetite

• Salivation

• Sweating

• Blurred vision

Psychological effects

• Visual and perceptual changes

• Altered sense of time

• Mood changes

• Possible anxiety or paranoia

• Possible feelings of insight or creativity

Associated phenomenon

• Flashback phenomenon

• Badtrip (also seen with cannabis)

• Reflex hallucination/ morbid synesthesia (may occur with other hallucinogens)

Tolerance

Develops quickly (2-3 days of repeated use), lost after 4-6 days of abstinence

Potential risks

• Accidents due to impaired judgment

• Rarely, a syndrome similar to neuroleptic malignant syndrome

• Possible triggering of anxiety or depression in some users

 

Date Rape Drugs:

Substances used to incapacitate victims, facilitating sexual assault by impairing memory and consciousness.

Common drugs include:

  1. Flunitrazepam (Rohypnol): A benzodiazepine causing deep sedation, muscle relaxation, and amnesia. Known for inducing memory loss, it is undetected due to its rapid action and dissociative effects.
  2. Gamma-Hydroxybutyric Acid (GHB): A CNS depressant causing euphoria, sedation, and amnesia. High doses lead to unconsciousness and respiratory depression. It is colorless and odorless, making it easy to mix into drinks.
  3. Gamma-Butyrolactone (GBL): A prodrug of GHB, converted in the body to produce similar sedative and amnesic effects.
  4. Ketamine: A dissociative anesthetic causing detachment, memory loss, and unconsciousness at higher doses.

While PCP can cause disorientation and altered perceptions, it typically presents with more severe symptoms such as aggressive behavior, nystagmus, and a more pronounced hypertension. The vivid visual hallucinations described are more characteristic of LSD (Option A)

Methamphetamine intoxication would typically present with more severe sympathomimetic effects, including significant hypertension, hyperthermia, and agitation. The visual hallucinations described are not typical of methamphetamine use (Option C)

While cannabis can cause anxiety and paranoia, the vivid visual hallucinations and dilated pupils are not typical. Cannabis-induced psychosis would more likely present with paranoid delusions rather than visual distortions (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of the Saint-Clair Thompson Adenoidectomy Curette?

choices.text: It is held like a dagger in the dominant hand
It is used with limited direct visualization, often blind
It is used without the cage for larger pieces of adenoid tissue
The curette is inserted under the soft palate to remove tissue using an inferior to superior motion.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It is used without the cage for larger pieces of adenoid tissue

 

Explanation:

The Saint-Clair Thompson Adenoidectomy Curette is used with a cage to capture and remove adenoid tissue effectively.

Instruments used in Adenoid/ Tonsillectomy

Saint-Clair Thompson Adenoidectomy Curette with Cage

Purpose: Specialized instrument for adenoidectomy to remove adenoid tissue while minimizing trauma.

  • Design:
    • Held like a dagger in the dominant hand. (Option A ruled out)
    • Features a cage to capture adenoid tissue, preventing aspiration into the lungs.
    • Cage can be dismantled for use without it.
  • Types:
    • With Cage: Useful for larger pieces of adenoid tissue. (Option C)
    • Without Cage: Standard version without tissue-holding feature.
  • Technique:
    • Performed blind, with limited direct visualization.(Option B ruled out)
    • A dental mirror or wide-angled rigid endoscope may assist with visibility.
    • Curette inserted under the soft palate, tissue removed using an inferior to superior motion. (Option D ruled out)

Mollison's Tonsillar Dissector and Anterior Pillar Retractor

Purpose: Specialized instrument used in tonsillectomy procedures for enhanced visibility and separation of tonsil tissue.

  • Tonsillar Dissector:
    • Used to separate the tonsil from its surrounding capsule.
    • Facilitates the removal of the tonsil from the tonsillar bed.
  • Anterior Pillar Retraction:
    • Retracts the anterior pillar to improve visibility of the tonsillar fossa.
    • Essential for examining the area for bleeding or remaining tissue post-removal.
  • Additional Uses:
    • Can retract the soft palate and uvula.
    • Aids in overall surgical access and visibility.

Eve's Tonsillar Snare

Purpose: Specialized instrument used in tonsillectomy to remove tonsils and minimize bleeding.

  • Crushing the Tonsil Pedicle:
    • Wire loop tightens around the tonsil's pedicle to crush it.
    • Reduces bleeding by compressing blood vessels.
  • Releasing Coagulation Factors:
    • Crushed tissue releases factors that accelerate coagulation.
    • Further aids in reducing bleeding.
  • Improved Visibility:
    • Enhances visibility of the surgical site by crushing the pedicle.
    • Facilitates complete removal and inspection for remaining tissue or bleeding.

questions.text: A 65 y/o male with a 30-year history in brake pad manufacturing presents with dyspnea, chest discomfort, and cough. Imaging shows pleural thickening and nodules. Biopsy confirms early-stage malignant mesothelioma. Which IHC markers and treatments are most consistent with this diagnosis?

choices.text: Positive CEA, negative vimentin, treated with radiation therapy alone
Negative CEA, positive vimentin, treated with Extended Pleurectomy and Decortication (EPD) combined with chemotherapy
Positive CEA, negative cytokeratins, treated with chemotherapy only
Negative vimentin, positive cytokeratins, treated with Extrapleural Pneumonectomy (EPP) alone

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Negative CEA, positive vimentin, treated with Extended Pleurectomy and Decortication (EPD) combined with chemotherapy.

 

Explanation:

This IHC profile is consistent with malignant mesothelioma. The combination of EPD, a lung-preserving surgery, with chemotherapy is an appropriate and effective treatment approach, aiming to achieve complete macroscopic resection and improve survival.


 

MALIGNANT MESOTHELIOMA

About
  • Highly aggressive malignancy originating from pleural mesothelial cells, strongly linked to asbestos.
  • The most common primary pleural tumour.

Diagnosis
  • Imaging:
    • CXR, CT, MRI, FDG-PET: Assess tumour invasion and metastasis
    • ECG: Checks for cardiac involvement
  • Biopsy: Pleural Biopsy: Via thoracoscopy, thoracentesis, or open techniques.
  • Immunohistochemistry findings:

Diagnosis

Mesothelioma

Adenocarcinoma

Carcinoembryonic Antigen (CEA)

Negative

Positive

Vimentin

Positive

Negative

Low Molecular Weight Cytokines

Positive

Negative

Electron Microscopy

Long, sinuous villi

Short, straight villi with fuzzy glycocalyx
 
  • Staging: Based on tumour invasion (T), lymph node involvement (N), and metastasis (M).

Treatment

Multimodality Therapy:

  • Early-stage: Surgery (EPP or EPD) with cisplatin-based chemotherapy and radiotherapy.
  • Advanced Disease: Chemotherapy may extend survival but not cure.
  • Palliative Care: Pleural catheters, pleurodesis.

Surgical Options:

  • Extrapleural Pneumonectomy (EPP): Complete lung resection; higher risk but more extensive.
  • Extended Pleurectomy and Decortication (EPD): Lung-preserving, safer, preferred in many centres.

Prognosis

Median survival is 24–36 months depending on stage and treatment.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with a history of recurrent abortion undergoes an ultrasound at 8 weeks of gestation and is found to have an abnormality in the fetus as shown below (arrow). The doctor reassures her that this condition typically resolves on its own. When should she schedule a follow-up ultrasound to monitor the resolution of the abnormality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 12 weeks

Explanation:

Ultrasound shows physiological umbilical hernia.

A physiological umbilical hernia is a normal developmental process where the intestines temporarily protrude into the base of the umbilical cord during early pregnancy. This occurs as the fetal abdomen is too small to accommodate the rapidly growing intestines. By around 12 weeks of gestation, the intestines typically return to the abdominal cavity, and the umbilical hernia resolves on its own. A follow-up ultrasound around 12 weeks is recommended to ensure proper closure and development.

 

Physiological Umbilical Hernia (PUH):

 

Occurs during early embryogenesis due to rapid growth of the midgut and liver, temporarily exceeding the size of the abdominal cavity.

 

  • Midgut Herniation (6th Week): The midgut herniates into the umbilical cord as the abdominal cavity is too small. It undergoes a 90-degree counterclockwise rotation around the superior mesenteric artery.
  • Midgut Retraction (10th-12th Week): The abdominal cavity expands, allowing the midgut to return. During retraction, an additional 180-degree counterclockwise rotation completes the 270-degree total, positioning the intestines.

 

Failure to Regress: Omphalocele: If the midgut doesn't return, omphalocele occurs, where organs remain herniated through the umbilical ring, covered by a membrane. It differs from Gastroschisis, where the organs protrude without a membrane.

questions.text: 6-month child is noted to have polyuria and failure to thrive. On assessment child is found to have severe hearing loss. Vitals Pulse: 80/min, BP 60/40 mm Hg with signs of dehydration. Work up shows metabolic alkalosis with hypokalaemia. Diagnosis is
questions.solution: Key words are polyuria and dehydration indicating tubular disease of kidney. Barrter has a defect of Chloride channel in kidney that also is present in inner ear hair cells and explains SN hearing loss. Loss-of-function mutations in BSND, which encodes an essential beta subunit for chloride channels. The defect in TAL explains the hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis. Option C is ruled out as it has hypertension. Option D has increased urinary calcium causing nephrocalcinosis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient presents with right-sided visual field loss in both eyes, resulting in a homonymous hemianopic defect. Neuroimaging and clinical examination suggest a lesion affecting the visual pathway. Based on the above findings, which anatomical location is most likely implicated in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Left optic tract

 

Explanation:

  • A lesion in the left optic tract would cause right (contralateral) homonymous hemianopia, where the right visual field is lost in both eyes.

 

Location of the lesion

Characteristic features

Optic nerve
  • Marked loss of vision or complete blindness on the affected side associated.
  • Near (accommodation) reflex is present.

Optic chiasma
  • Bitemporal hemianopia

Optic tract
  • Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
  • Contralateral hemianopic pupillary responses, i.e. Wernicke's reaction.

Optic radiations
  • Superior quadrantic hemianopia (pie in the sky)
    • Produced when the inferior fibres (Meyer’s loop) are involved in temporal lobe lesions)
  • Inferior quadrantic hemianopia (pie on the floor)
    • Produced when superior fibres (Baum’s loop) are involved in parietal lobe lesions.

Visual cortex
  • Homonymous hemianopia, often with macular sparing

questions.text:
You are drawing blood sample for serum calcium. Which of the following is to be avoided to prevent false error in evaluating calcium values:

a. Narrow bore needle

b. Forearm exercise and fist clenching

c. Prolonged immobilization of patient

d. Rapid removal of torniquet
questions.solution:
• For calcium sampling, good practice is use of torniquet should be avoided or rapidly removed as soon as blood flows into hub of hypodermic needle. Prolonged use of torniquet will cause venous stasis and will cause false elevation.
  • Option A will cause hemolysis and release phosphate that will chelate calcium. Option B will cause lactic acidosis. This will cause calcium bound to albumin to dissociate and change ionized calcium values. Option C causes osteoclastic activity and increased serum calcium values. All the top three are bad practices and option D is good practice for calcium sampling.

questions.text:
A 1-day-old newborn presents with respiratory distress. A chest X-ray is performed and is given below.



Based on the findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (Bochdalek type)

Explanation:

The given chest x-ray shows loops of bowel in the right thoracic cavity, mediastinal shift to the left, and decreased right lung aeration, which is consistent with Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia.

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (CDH):

  1. CDH is the intrathoracic herniation of abdominal contents due to congenital defects in the diaphragm.
  2. Types of CDH:
    • Bochdalek Hernia: Occurs through the posterolateral pleuroperitoneal canal, most commonly on the left side.
    • Morgagni Hernia: Anterior hernia located at the right cardiophrenic angle.

Fig. Schematic representation of CDH

  1. Radiologic Features:
    • Chest Radiograph (CXR):
      • Bochdalek hernia: Dome-shaped soft tissue opacity in the posterolateral thorax, often left-sided.
      • May show gas-filled bowel loops or fat content in the thoracic cavity.
      • Mediastinal shift away from the herniation due to mass effect.
      • On the lateral view, hernias appear above the posterior costophrenic recess.
    • CT/MRI:
      • Visualizes herniation of fat, bowel, spleen, or kidney through a diaphragmatic defect.
      • Important for distinguishing from other masses like cystic adenomatoid malformation or pericardial cyst.
      • CT provides clearer differentiation of soft-tissue or fatty mass protruding through the diaphragm.
  2. Complications:
    • Associated with hypoplasia of the ipsilateral lung, leading to respiratory distress, especially in neonates.
    • Neonates may present with respiratory distress and mediastinal deviation.

 

Esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula (Option B):

  • The primary abnormality may show air in the esophagus or stomach (if a fistula is present) and sometimes an absence of gas in the abdomen if there is no fistula.
  • This condition doesn't present with bowel loops in the thorax or a large diaphragmatic defect.

 

Pulmonary sequestration (Option C):

  • It presents as a mass in the lower lobe of the lung, often with an abnormal vascular supply seen on advanced imaging like CT angiography.
  • No bowel loops or significant mediastinal shift would be seen.

 

Congenital pulmonary airway malformation (CPAM) (Option D) appears as cystic masses within the lung, but the cysts are within the lung parenchyma, not abdominal contents in the thorax.

questions.text: A 12-year-old female patient with cystic fibrosis (CF) presents to the clinic with increased cough and thick sputum production, causing shortness of breath and fatigue. Which of the following medications would be the most effective for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Dornase alfa

Explanation:

Dornase alfa is an enzyme that reduces mucus viscosity by cleaving extracellular DNA in the airway secretions.

Management of Cystic fibrosis:

Symptom

Treatment

Dry eyes, mouth (Xerophthalmia, xerostomia)
  • Pilocarpine
  • Cevimeline (Option C)

Hard mucus
  • Mucolytics -
    • N acetylcysteine
    • Erdosteine
    • Carbocysteine
    • Dornase alpha (Degrades DNA)
    • Hypertonic saline

Recurrent pneumonia (Pseudomonas)
  • Inhalational antibiotics -
    • Tobramycin
    • Amikacin
    • Colistin
    • Aztreonam

Chronic pancreatitis

Pancreatic enzyme replacement (Pancrezyme)

Disease-modifying therapy
  • Lumacaftor (Option D)
  • Ivacaftor
  • Elexacaftor

 Pancrelipase (Option A)is a pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy to aid digestion.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with fatigue, bruising, and intermittent fevers for the past few weeks. Physical examination reveals the following findings. Immunophenotyping of the biopsy specimen shows CD43 and MPO positivity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) AML with maturation

 Explanation:

This young child with nonspecific systemic symptoms, MPO positivity, and an image showing orbital swelling and proptosis suggests chloroma associated with AML with maturation (AML-M2).

Chloroma:

  • A.k.a Myeloblastoma/Granulocytic Sarcoma.
  • It is not a benign tumour, but it has a greenish colour.
  • Site: Soft tissue involvement in orbit leads to proptosis.
  • Associated with AML M2 and M5.
  • Peripheral smear findings:
    • Myeloblasts.
    • Arbiskov cells: Atypical monocytes/macrophages.
  • Markers: MPO (green colour), CD 43, CD 45 and Lysozyme.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old farmer presents with a persistent, scaly lesion on his ear. The lesion has irregular, everted edges and has been gradually growing as shown below. 



Which of the following is the most common causative factor for his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Sunlight Exposure

 

Explanation:

  • Sunlight exposure is the most common and significant cause of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin.
  • UV radiation from the sun causes direct DNA damage to skin cells, leading to mutations and increased risk of developing SCC.

Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC)

  • The most commonly involved areas are (parts exposed to sunlight):  Ears, Cheeks, Lower lip, and back of hands.
  • Predisposing Factors:
    • Actinic keratosis (senile keratosis)
    • Prolonged sunlight exposure
    • Radiation exposure (Option D ruled out)
    • Infection with Human Papillomavirus (HPV)
    • Immunosuppression or HIV
    • Exposure to arsenic (Option B ruled out)
    • Bowen’s disease
    • Tobacco use (Option A ruled out)
    • Xeroderma pigmentosa

questions.text: A 3-day-old infant has cyanosis shortly after birth.The mother has a history of Bipolar disorder. On examination, the infant has a prominent pansystolic murmur best heard along the left lower sternal border. The infant's ECG image is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Atrialization of the Right ventricle

 

Explanation:

The clinical presentation of cyanosis at birth, pansystolic murmur due to tricuspid regurgitation, mother’s history of Bipolar (Lithium exposed pregnancy), and the characteristic Himalayan P wave on ECG is most consistent with Atrialization of the right ventricle.

  • This condition is also known as Ebstein's Anomaly.

Ebstein's Anomaly:

  • Associated with Lithium exposure during pregnancy.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Downward displacement/prolapse of the tricuspid valve.
    • Part of the right ventricular volume becomes part of the right atrium (atrialization of the right ventricle).
  • Consequences:
    • Tricuspid Regurgitation: Prolapsed valve → Blood from the right ventricle regurgitates into the right atrium.
    • RVOT (Right Ventricular Outflow Tract) Obstruction: Prolapsed valve partly occludes blood flow towards the pulmonary artery → Cyanosis.
  • Features:
    • Cyanosis at birth or during the neonatal period.
    • Pansystolic murmur: Due to tricuspid regurgitation.
    • Quadruple Rhythm: Irregular blood flow in the right heart, RVOT obstruction, and tricuspid regurgitation → Multiple added sounds and ejection clicks.
  • X-Ray Findings:
    • Right atrial enlargement due to regurgitation from the right ventricle and atrialization of the right ventricle.
    • RA forms the right heart border, which displaces laterally and appears on X-ray as a box-shaped heart.

  • ECG: Himalayan P Waves

 

Tetralogy of Fallot (Option A):

  • Characterized by cyanosis, a systolic ejection murmur, and right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. X-ray typically shows a boot-shaped heart.

Transposition of the Great Arteries (Option C):

  • Presents with severe cyanosis, often with a systolic murmur if there is associated outflow obstruction.
  • X-ray findings usually show an "egg-on-a-string" appearance.

Ventricular Septal Defect (Option D):

  • Presents with a pansystolic murmur and may cause pulmonary overcirculation, but the X-ray findings would generally show an enlarged heart with increased pulmonary markings.

questions.text: Which section of the BNS involves life imprisonment for causing a miscarriage without the woman’s consent?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) 89

 

Explanation:

 

Criminal Abortion - Legal Aspects

BNS

(Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023)

IPC Section

(Indian Penal Code, 1860)

Definition

88

(Option A ruled out)

312

Voluntary criminal abortion by anyone, including the pregnant woman, can lead to up to 3 years imprisonment and/or fine.

If the woman is "quick with child" (fetal movement felt), the punishment can extend up to 7 years and a fine.

89

(Option B)

313

Causing a miscarriage without the woman’s consent is punishable by life imprisonment or up to 10 years in prison, with a fine.

90

(Option C ruled out)

314

If a miscarriage attempt leads to the woman’s death, the responsible person faces up to 10 years in prison and a fine.

If done without her consent, the punishment can be life imprisonment or up to 10 years.

91

(Option D ruled out)

315

Actions to prevent a child from being born alive or causing death after birth can result in up to 10 years imprisonment, fine, or both.

92

316

Causing the death of a "quick unborn child" (after fetal movement) is considered culpable homicide, punishable by up to 10 years imprisonment and a fine.

 

Criminal Abortion Methods

  • Upto end of 1st month: Violent exercises
  • Upto end of 2nd month: Abortifacient drugs
  • 3rd or 4th month: Mechanical interference

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with worsening headaches, focal neurological deficits, and personality changes. MRI imaging reveals a ring-enhancing lesion surrounded by significant oedema. Based on these imaging characteristics, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis and management in recurrent cases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Glioblastoma Multiforme, Temozolomide

Explanation:

  • The imaging findings of a ring-enhancing lesion with significant surrounding oedema are characteristic of Glioblastoma Multiforme (GBM), AKA Grade 4 Astrocytoma.
  • It is a Grade IV glioma characterised by ring-enhancing lesions on MRI with surrounding oedema and is associated with poor prognosis.
  • It is highly aggressive and presents with necrosis and microvascular proliferation.
  • Temozolomide is the current chemotherapy drug of choice for GBM.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the mini-pill (progestin-only pill, POP) is true regarding its use in lactating women?

choices.text: Early return of fertility once discontinued
It is the contraception of choice in breastfeeding women
Associated with a higher risk of blood clots compared to COCPs

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It is the contraception of choice in breastfeeding women.

 

Explanation:

  • Progestin-only pills (POP) are generally preferred for breastfeeding women because they do not significantly affect milk production. In contrast, estrogen-containing contraceptives can sometimes decrease milk supply.
  • It has to be taken at the same time daily from the first day of the cycle.

Disadvantages of POP:

  • The mini-pill (POP) causes delayed return of fertility after Discontinuation (Option A ruled out)
  • POP causes Bone loss (Option C ruled out)

 

Progestin only pills(POP)

Dose

Window Period

Minipill [Levonorgestrel]

35 mcg

3hrs

Cerazette [Desogestrel]

75 mcg

12hrs

 

Associated with a higher risk of blood clots compared to COCPs (Option D): Progestin-only pills (POP) are associated with a lower risk of blood clots compared to combined oral contraceptives that contain estrogen. Therefore, they are often preferred for women at higher risk of clotting disorders.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman was presented with chronic cough, weight loss, and night sweats, and was initially diagnosed as pulmonary tuberculosis. She now complains of menstrual irregularities and infertility. Upon further investigation, the following radiograph is observed. What is the most likely explanation for her current condition?

choices.text: Direct extension of pulmonary TB to the uterus
Secondary genital TB due to hematogenous spread from pulmonary TB
Reactivation of latent TB in the uterus
Direct extension from peritoneum to the uterus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Secondary genital TB due to hematogenous spread from pulmonary TB

Explanation:
This clinical scenario describes primary pulmonary TB leading secondarily to genital TB which causes complications such as Asherman’s syndrome.

  • Asherman's Syndrome is characterized by the formation of fibrous bands within the uterine cavity.
  • Endometrial ulceration due to TB uterus may lead to such adhesion or synechiae formation.
  • This may cause complications such as infertility, recurrent abortions, and secondary amenorrhea.

  • Genital TB usually spreads to the genital tract hematogenously from a primary focus, often the lungs.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Predominantly affects women of reproductive age group.
  • Primary or secondary infertility in 70-80% of cases of pelvic tuberculosis.
    • This may be due to tubal blockage/adhesions, endometrial destruction/synechiae formation, and implantation failure.
  • Menstrual abnormalities such as menorrhagia or oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea. Secondary amenorrhea is the most common presenting symptom.
  • Chronic pelvic pain
  • Tubo-ovarian mass
  • Constitutional symptoms like fever, loss of weight, malaise, anemia.

questions.text:
Which of the following features correctly describes the conditions depicted in images 1 and 2?



 

a) Severe wasting

b) Flaky paint dermatitis

c) Baggy pants

d) Skin and bone appearance

e) Nutritional anaemia

f) Sugar baby

g) Flag sign

h) Monkey facies
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1- a,c,d,h; 2- b,e,f,g

 

Explanation:
 

MARASMUS

KWASHIORKOR
  • Severe wasting of fat and muscle.
  • Often due to acute starvation or illness secondary to poor nutritional status.
  • Severe marasmus is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM).
  • Skin-and-bones appearance.
  • Monkey facies due to the loss of buccal fat pads.
  • Baggy pants appearance- due to loose skin hanging from the buttocks.
  • Loss of axillary fat pad.
  • Despite the severe wasting, affected children may appear alert.
  • No oedema.
  • Pitting oedema present.
  • “Well-fed” / “Sugar baby” appearance of the child d/t oedema.
  • Oedema can be mild to severe, representing 5-20% of body weight.
  • Muscle wasting is present.
  • Flaky pain dermatitis present (peeling skin).
  • Mucous membrane lesions- smooth tongue, cheilosis, angular stomatitis.
  • Flag sign in hair- alternating pigmented bands. Hair is sparse.
  • Unhappiness, apathy, irritability, and feeding difficulties.
  • Anorexia, vomiting, abdominal distension, and diarrhoea.
  • Nutritional anaemia is typically present.
  • Cardiovascular issues include cold, pale extremities, prolonged circulation time, bradycardia, and hypotension.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease presents with worsening shortness of breath and orthopnea. Chest X-ray reveals pulmonary congestion. Bronchoalveolar lavage shows hemosiderin-laden macrophages, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Left-sided heart failure

 

Explanation:

The patient's symptoms and the histopathological findings of hemosiderin-laden macrophages known as ‘Heart failure cells’ are consistent with Left-sided heart failure.

  • This condition is characterized by the heart's inability to pump blood effectively, causing backflow of blood, leading to pulmonary congestion and oedema.
  • In pulmonary edema, the lungs appear wet and boggy, and chest X-ray shows characteristic Kerley B lines.
  • Chronic congestion and microhemorrhages in the lungs result in the accumulation of hemosiderin-laden macrophages (Heart failure cells).
  • These cells can be identified using special stains such as Perl's or Prussian blue, which detect hemosiderin's presence.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male traveller presents to the clinic for malaria prophylaxis before his trip to a region where Plasmodium vivax is endemic. He has a history of G6PD deficiency. Which of the following antimalarial medications is safe in individuals with G6PD deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Mefloquine

Explanation:

Mefloquine is safe to use in G6PD deficiency. Its other side effects include severe neurological and psychiatric side effects such as vivid dreams, psychosis, and seizures. It is metabolised by CYP3A4, which is induced by drugs like rifampin.

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency impairs RBCs' ability to withstand oxidative stress. Certain medications, like antimalarials, can trigger hemolysis in individuals with G6PD deficiency by inducing oxidative stress within rRBCs.

Antimalarials safe in G6PD deficiency

Antimalarials NOT safe in G6PD deficiency
  • Mefloquine (safest)(Option D)
  • Chloroquine
  • Quinine (Option A ruled out)
  • Primaquine (Option B ruled out)
  • Proguanil (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 60-year-old hypertensive patient has muscle weakness, low potassium, and a plasma aldosterone-renin ratio (ARR) >30. What’s the next best step?
questions.solution: Hypertension with hypokalemic alkalosis and elevated aldosterone indicates conn syndrome. CT abdomen will identify macroadenoma. If it is micro-adenoma, adrenal venous sampling would be required. Option B and D are ruled out as they are used for Cushing syndrome diagnosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is being treated with theophylline. He is prescribed erythromycin for a respiratory tract infection. Which of the following outcomes is most likely due to the interaction between these two drugs?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Increased risk of theophylline toxicity

 

Explanation:

  • Erythromycin is an inhibitor of the cytochrome P450 enzyme CYP1A2, which metabolises theophylline.
  • Inhibition of this enzyme leads to higher plasma levels of theophylline, increasing the risk of toxicity.

Theophylline toxicity:

  • It has a narrow margin of safety, and dose-dependent toxicity starts from the upper half of the therapeutic concentration range.
  • The image below shows the effects of theophylline toxicity.

 

Enzyme inhibitors: (leads to drug toxicity)

Drugs (Mnemonic- COKE in Gallon Contain Artificial Preservatives):

Cimetidine.

Grapefruit juice (Furano coumarins).

Omeprazole.

Clarithromycin & Ciprofloxacin.

Ketoconazole.

Acute alcoholism.

Erythromycin.

Protease inhibitor (Ritonavir).

Isoniazid (inhibits all CYP enzymes except CYP2E1).

Valproate.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male has a painless, slowly enlarging mass in the left parotid gland over several years. Examination reveals a firm, mobile, non-tender mass. Histological findings confirm pleomorphic adenoma. Which factor is associated with an increased risk of malignant transformation in pleomorphic adenomas?

choices.text: Presence of hyalinized stroma within the tumour

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Increased age of the lesion.

 

Explanation:

Rates of malignant transformation in pleomorphic adenoma correlate with the age of the lesion

  • When the age of pleomorphic adenoma's lesion exceeds 15-20 years, the chances of malignant transformations increase: Carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma (Carcinoma has originated inside a pre-existing pleomorphic adenoma).

Pleomorphic adenoma

  • It is a benign mixed tumor
  • Most common salivary gland tumor and most commonly occurs in the parotid.
  • Mostly seen in females.
  • On FNAC or biopsy: It shows epithelial and mesenchymal cells (mixed tumor)
    • Epithelial components: Epithelia, myoepithelial and ductal cells
    • Mesenchymal tissue comprise of chondromyxoid stroma

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient has been complaining of persistent sadness, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating over the past few months. Upon examination, you notice several physical signs on her face, which are shown below (asterisk). Identify the sign shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Omega Sign

 

Explanation: The omega sign, an omega-shaped fold on the forehead from excessive use of the corrugator muscle, reflects emotional stress and is indicative of depressive disorders.

Physical Signs of Depression:

Veraguth's Fold (Option A)

Omega Sign (Option B)

A triangular fold in the inner corner of the upper eyelid due to changes in the corrugator and zygomatic muscles from prolonged muscle tension associated with depression.

 


 

An omega-shaped fold on the forehead reflecting excessive use of the corrugator muscle, indicative of emotional stress related to depressive disorders.


 

Chandler’s Sign (Option C): Not relevant to psychiatry; refers to eyelid swelling, proptosis, and restricted eye movement, seen in orbital infections like cellulitis.

 

Dennie-Morgan Lines (Option D): These are associated with allergic conditions, particularly atopic dermatitis, and are characterized by extra folds of skin beneath the eyes. They are not indicative of depressive disorders.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl presents with fever, sore throat, and a red, finely papular rash that started on her neck and spread to her body. The rash is more pronounced in the skin creases, and her examination reveals the findings in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Scarlet fever

 

Explanation:

The clinical features mentioned most likely indicates Scarlet fever

Scarlet Fever

Group A Streptococcus (GAS) pharyngitis is associated with a characteristic rash caused due to a pyrogenic exotoxin (erythrogenic toxin) produced by GAS in individuals lacking antitoxin antibodies.

Caused By

Group A Streptococcus (GAS)

Incidence and Virulence

Less common and less virulent now compared to the past, with incidence depending on toxin strains and the population's immunity.

Clinical Features
  • Rash appears within 24-48 hours, starting around the neck and spreading to the trunk and extremities.
  • Rash is a diffuse, finely papular, erythematous eruption causing bright-red discoloration, which blanches on pressure.
  • Rash is accentuated in the creases of the elbow, axilla, and groin (Pastia lines) and gives the skin a goose-pimple appearance.
  • Erythematous cheeks with pallor around the mouth.
  • After 3-4 days, the rash fades, followed by desquamation starting on the face and progressing downward.
  • Desquamation may occur around fingernails, palms, and soles.
  • Tongue is coated with swollen papillae, which later give a "strawberry tongue" appearance after desquamation.
  • Pharyngitis.

Diagnosis
  • Classic scarlet fever is typically straightforward to diagnose.
  • A history of recent exposure to GAS is helpful.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying GAS in the pharynx.

Treatment

  • Antibiotic therapy should be started immediately.
  • Drug of choice: Penicillin or amoxicillin for 10 days.
  • Alternative for Penicillin Allergy: Oral cephalosporins, clindamycin, Macrolides (erythromycin, clarithromycin) for 10 days or azalide (azithromycin) for 5 days.
  • Injection: Benzathine penicillin G single dose intramuscular injection for those unlikely to complete oral therapy.

Complication

  • Suppurative Complications:
    • Cervical lymphadenitis
    • Peritonsillar abscess
    • Retropharyngeal abscess
    • Otitis media
    • Mastoiditis
    • Sinusitis
    • Group A Streptococcus (GAS) pneumonia
  • Nonsuppurative Complications:
    • Acute rheumatic fever
    • Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Image

White strawberry tongue (first day)

Red strawberry tongue (third day)



 

Symptoms/ Signs

Measles

(Option A)

Scarlet Fever

Kawasaki Disease

(Option B)

Fever

+

With prodromal symptoms

+

+

Rash

Maculopapular

Maculopapular

Maculopapular

Distribution of rash

Cephalocaudal and centrifugal spread, may become confluent

Begins in the axillary and inguinal region, spreading throughout. Linear petechiae in antecubital and axilary folds (Lines of Pastia)

Erythematous and polymorphous rash. Commonly on hands and feet

Desaquamation

Dry desquamation

Desquamative rash begins 1 week after onset

Periungual desquamation

Eye involvement

Conjunctivitis

-

Non-exudative conjunctivitis

Mucosal Involvement

Koplik's spots

Pharyngitis, strawberry tongue

Strawberry tongue, fissured or erythematous lips

Adenopathy

±

±

Cervical Lymphadenopathy

Oedema

-

-

Oedema of hands and feet

Image


 

Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) (Option D) presents with low-grade fever, sore throat, followed by oral ulcers or blisters in the oral cavity, and a papulovesicular rash on the palms and soles, which are not mentioned in the scenario.

questions.text: Which of the following is the comprehensive program the Ministry of Women and Child Development launched to combat trafficking?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ujjawala scheme

 

Explanation:

 

The Ujjawala scheme

The Ujjawala scheme, launched in India on December 4, 2007, by the Ministry of Women and Child Development, is a comprehensive program to combat trafficking. The scheme is primarily implemented through NGOs.

Objectives/Goals

Strategies to Achieve Goals

Prevention

  • Formation of community vigilance and adolescent groups, awareness creation
  • preparation of IEC (Information, Education, Communication) material, organization of workshops.

Rescue
  • Safe withdrawal of victims from the place of exploitation.

Rehabilitation
  • Providing safe shelter, basic amenities, medical care, legal aid, vocational training, and employment opportunities to victims.

Reintegration
  • Supporting victims in their reintegration into society.

Repatriation

  • Providing support to cross-border victims for their safe return to their home countries.

 

The Pradhan Mantri Ujjwala Yojana (PMUY) (Option B) is a key initiative to provide rural and underprivileged households with access to clean cooking fuels like LPG, replacing traditional cooking fuels. It comes under the Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas (MOPNG)

The UJALA (Unnat Jyoti by Affordable LEDs for All) scheme (Option C) aims to promote energy efficiency by distributing LED bulbs at affordable prices. This initiative reduces energy consumption and lowers household electricity bills. It also contributes to environmental sustainability by cutting down carbon emissions. The Ministry of Power administers it.

The PM Sahaj Bijli Har Ghar Yojana (PM Saubhagya scheme)(Option D) was initiated in September 2017 to provide electricity to every household by December 2018. The Ministry of Power administers it.

questions.text:
Match the following pneumoconiosis conditions with their related industries:


	
		
			
			Pneumoconiosis
			
			
			Exposure Industry
			
		
		
			
			1. Silicosis
			
			
			a. Textile Manufacturing
			
		
		
			
			2. Asbestosis
			
			
			b. Mining and Quarrying
			
		
		
			
			3. Byssinosis
			
			
			c. Construction and Shipbuilding
			
		
		
			
			4. Anthracosis
			
			
			d. Coal Mining
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a, 4-d

Explanation: 

  1. Silicosis: Often occurs in workers exposed to silica dust in industries like mining and quarrying.
  2. Asbestosis: Typically found in workers who handle asbestos, prevalent in construction and shipbuilding industries.
  3. Byssinosis: Common among workers exposed to cotton, flax, or hemp dust, primarily in the textile manufacturing industry.
  4. Anthracosis or Coal Workers' Pneumoconiosis (aka "black lung disease" ): This condition affects workers in coal mining due to inhalation of coal dust.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with a history of untreated tuberculosis presents with mild throat discomfort and difficulty in swallowing. Examination reveals a central fluctuant swelling in the posterior pharyngeal wall, and X-rays confirm caries of the cervical spine. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Prevertebral abscess

 

Explanation:

Prevertebral abscess, which is formed as a complication of cervical spine caries due to TB, presents as a fluctuant swelling in the posterior pharyngeal wall centrally.

 

Prevertebral Abscess:

Prevertebral space
  • Extent: Base of skull to coccyx
  • Location: Between vertebrae on one side and prevertebral muscles and the prevertebral fascia on the other

Aetiology
  • Tubercular in nature, caused by:
    • Caries of the cervical spine (central abscess behind prevertebral fascia)
    • Tuberculous infection of retropharyngeal lymph nodes (unilateral abscess behind buccopharyngeal fascia)

Clinical Features
  • Throat discomfort
  • Mild dysphagia
  • Fluctuant swelling in posterior pharyngeal wall, either centrally or on one side of midline

Treatment
  • Incision and drainage
  • Antitubercular therapy

 

Comparison between retropharyngeal and prevertebral abscesses:

 

Retropharyngeal (Option B)

Prevertebral (Option A)

Location of the space

Behind the pharynx, between the buccopharyngeal fascia and prevertebral fascia, extending from the base of the skull to the bifurcation of the trachea.

Between vertebrae on one side and prevertebral muscles and the prevertebral fascia on the other, extenting from the base of skull to coccyx

Etiology

  • Children under 3 years (common)-suppuration of retropharyngeal lymph nodes
  • Adults-penetrating injuries to the posterior pharyngeal wall or cervical esophagus.

Tubercular in nature, caused by: Caries of the cervical spine or tuberculous infection of retropharyngeal lymph nodes

Clinical features

  • Dysphagia
  • Breathing difficulty
  • Stridor
  • Croupy cough
  • Torticollis
  • Unilateral bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall
  • Throat discomfort
  • Mild dysphagia
  • Fluctuant swelling in posterior pharyngeal wall, either centrally or on one side of midline

 

 

Parapharyngeal abscess (Option C): Incorrect as it causes lateral wall bulge, trismus, and more severe systemic symptoms.

Peritonsillar abscess (Option D): Incorrect since it is peritonsillar, not posterior pharyngeal, and presents with uvular deviation.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a history of fatigue, abdominal distension, and jaundice. He has a known diagnosis of liver cirrhosis secondary to chronic hepatitis B infection. Recently, he has developed a palpable liver mass, and imaging studies confirm the presence of hepatocellular carcinoma. Which of the following parameters is not typically used in the prognosis of his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Serum ammonia

Explanation:

  • The prognosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in patients with underlying liver cirrhosis is heavily influenced by liver function, which is often assessed using the Child-Pugh (CP) score.
  • Serum ammonia is typically associated with hepatic encephalopathy rather than being a direct measure used in the prognosis of HCC.
  • Therefore, it is not typically used in the prognosis of hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: A 38-year-old premenopausal woman is diagnosed with Lobular Carcinoma In Situ (LCIS) after a breast biopsy. She opts for chemoprevention as her management strategy. Her doctor discusses various medication options with her. Which of the following statements about chemoprevention for LCIS is correct?

choices.text: Chemoprevention eliminates the risk of developing breast cancer
Tamoxifen reduces breast cancer risk by 25% over 5 years
Chemoprevention is only effective for the ipsilateral breast
Tamoxifen reduces breast cancer risk by 56% over 5 years

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Tamoxifen reduces breast cancer risk by 56% over 5 years.

 

Explanation:

Lobular Carcinoma In Situ (LCIS)

Management

  • Close observation
  • Chemoprevention
    • Medications: Tamoxifen, Raloxifene, or Arimidex
    • Tamoxifen reduces risk by 56% over 5 years
  • Surgical: Bilateral mastectomy (if surgery chosen prophylactically)

questions.text: A public health department is implementing a new vaccination program to prevent the spread of a contagious disease in a community. After several years of the vaccination program, which of the following outcomes is most likely to occur due to the successful vaccination program?

choices.text: Decrease in the prevalence of the disease
Increase in the prevalence of the disease
Decrease in the incidence of the disease
Incidence of the disease remain the same

questions.solution:

Explanation:

A new vaccination program is implemented to prevent the spread of a contagious disease in a community, which decreases the incidence of the disease.

Relationship between prevalence and incidence:

Prevalence (P) ∝ Incidence (I) x Duration (D)
