questions.text:
Assertion: Patients with Common Variable Immunodeficiency (CVID) commonly present with recurrent respiratory infections, gastrointestinal issues, and autoimmune disorders.

Reason: Defects in the BTK gene lead to impaired B cell signaling, resulting in decreased maturation of B cells from pre-B-cells.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason is the correct explanation for Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but Reason is not the correct explanation for Assertion
Assertion is true, but Reason is false
Assertion is false, but Reason is true

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Both Assertion and Reason are true, but Reason is not the correct explanation for Assertion.

 

Explanation:

While the assertion about Common Variable Immunodeficiency (CVID) symptoms is correct, the reason is incorrect because defects in the BTK gene cause Bruton’s (X-Linked) agammaglobulinemia, not CVID.

The BTK gene converts immature B cells into mature B cells. The BAFF gene then produces plasma cells and antibodies from the mature B cells.

Differences between Bruton's hypogammaglobulinemia and CVID:

Bruton's hypogammaglobulinemia

CVID
  • BTK gene defect
  • Common in boys (X-linked)
  • Manifests after 6 months of age
  • B cell defect
  • Hypoplastic germinal centers
  • Patients are susceptible to infections by Haemophilus influenzae, Streptococcus pneumoniae, or Staphylococcus aureus.
  • BAFF gene defect
  • Occurs in both boys & girls
  • Manifests in childhood or adolescence
  • B cell and T cell defect
  • Hyperplastic germinal centers
  • Patients are susceptible to persistent diarrhoea caused by G. lamblia.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in the treatment of central diabetes insipidus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Indomethacin

 

Explanation :

Indomethacin, a prostaglandin synthase inhibitor, is used for the treatment of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, especially lithium-induced nephrogenic DI. It works by attenuating prostaglandin synthesis in the renal tubules, thereby potentiating the effects of antidiuretic hormone (ADH).

Oral carbamazepine (Option A) has shown antidiuretic activity in patients with neurohypophyseal diabetes insipidus. It is suggested for initial use in neurohypophyseal diabetes insipidus.

Desmopressin (Option B): A synthetic ADH hormone used as the drug of choice in central DI 

Chlorpropamide (Option C), an oral sulfonylurea, potentiates the action of small or residual amounts of circulating vasopressin and reduces urine volume in more than half of all patients with central DI.

questions.text: An embryo is observed to have 12 pairs of somites on ultrasound. Based on this, what is the most likely developmental age of the embryo?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 23 days

 

Explanation:

  • Somites begin forming around day 20, and new somites form at a rate of approximately three pairs per day.
  • By 23 days, an embryo typically has about 12 pairs of somites, making this the most likely developmental age.

 

Somite Formation:

  • First pair of somites arises in the occipital region at approximately the 20th day of development.
  • Somites appear in a craniocaudal sequence at a rate of 3 pairs/day.
  • At the end of the fifth week: 42 to 44 pairs of somites are present.
  • Distribution: Occipital - 4, cervical - 8, thoracic - 12, lumbar - 5, sacral - 5, coccygeal - 8 to 10
  • The first occipital and last 5-7 coccygeal somites eventually disappear.
  • Remaining Somites: Contribute to the formation of the axial skeleton.
  • Clinical Application (Age Estimation): The age of an embryo can be accurately determined during this period by counting the number of somites.

 

Number of Somites Correlated to Approximate Age in Days

questions.text: A 67-year-old male was having complaints of sudden onset of severe chest pain, which was radiating to his back, and suddenly, he went unconscious. He was chronically hypertensive, a drug defaulter, and was having weakness, dizziness and dyspnea for 1 day. His current BP is 90/50 mm Hg, and his Heart Rate is 140 bpm. What is the best investigation of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C)  Trans Esophageal Echocardiography

 

Explanation:

  • The above given scenario is an unstable case of Aortic dissection, and the investigation of choice is TEE (Trans Esophageal Echocardiography).

 

Aortic Dissection

It occurs when a defect or a flap occurs in the aorta, resulting in blood tracking into aortic tissues, splitting the medial layer, and creating a false lumen.

Investigations:

  • If the patient is stable, CT angiography is the standard investigation of choice. (Option A)
  • In the case of unstable patients (SBP<100 mm of HG, HR>100 bpm), the preferred investigation of choice will be TEE (TransEsophageal Echocardiography) 
  • MRI can also be done if CT is unequivocal.
  • Chest x-ray (Option D) reveals widening of the mediastinum along with left-sided pleural effusion.

TEE of an aortic dissection within the descending part

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about GBS?

choices.text: Cyto-albuminological dissociation in seen in CSF
Areflexia in weak limbs included in criteria
Plasmapheresis is not done in refractory GBS

questions.solution:
IVIG and plasmapheresis are equally effective and any one of these can be initiated. Option A is initial therapy. Option B and C are must have components of Brighton criteria for diagnosis of GBS

 

Brighton criteria for Diagnosis of Guillain-Barré Syndrome

Clinical case of diagnostic certainty

Bilateral AND Flaccid weakness of the limbs

AND

Decreased or absent deep tendon reflexes in weak limbs

AND

Monophasic illness pattern and interval between onset and nadir of weakness between 12 h and 28 days and subsequent clinical plateau

AND

Electrophysiologic findings consent with GBS

AND

Cytoalbuminologic dissociation (i.e., elevation of CSF protein level above level laboratory normal valve AND CSF total white cell count <50 cells/mL)

AND

Absence of an identified alternative diagnosis for weakness

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-iii, 2-iv, 3-ii, 4-i

Explanation:

  • Anaphylatoxins: C3a, C4a, and C5a.
  • Opsonins: C3b, C4b, and C5b.
    • Opsonins when coats the bacteria, makes it more tasty for phagocytosis.
    • Overall most important opsonin: IgG

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with regular menstrual cycles undergoes routine Pap smear screening, which reveals a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) of the cervix. Further testing confirms infection with high-risk HPV type 16. Which of the following mechanisms regarding the oncogenic activity of E6 and E7 of HPV is correct?

choices.text: E6 protein inhibits the degradation of p53.
E6 stimulates the expression of TERT.
E7 can inactivate cyclins A and E

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) E6 stimulates the expression of TERT.

 

Explanation:

E6 and E7 proteins from high-risk HPV types exhibit increased affinity for key cellular regulatory proteins (e.g., p53, RB) compared to low-risk HPV types.
 

Oncogenic Activities of E6 Protein

Oncogenic Activities of E7 Protein
  • Binds to and promotes degradation of p53 (policeman of the cell) → Impairs cell growth and apoptosis regulation (Option A ruled out).
  • Stimulates expression of TERT (telomerase reverse transcriptase) → Facilitates cellular immortalisation by maintaining telomere length.
  • Disrupts interaction between RB gene (governor of genome) and E2F transcription factors
  • Inactivates CDK inhibitors (e.g., p21 and p27) (Option C ruled out).
  • Activates cyclins A and E (Option D ruled out)
 

All these mechanisms enhance cell cycle progression and cellular proliferation in HPV infections.

Image

Description

Bacterial Keratitis:

Fungal Keratitis:

  • Seen in Herpes zoster

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-a, 2-d, 3-b, 4-c

 

Explanation:

Instrument

Description

1. Simpson Forceps
  • Long, curved blades.
  • Sliding lock mechanism.
  • Versatile - used for outlet and low-cavity applications.
  • Accommodates various fetal head sizes.
  • One of the most commonly used forceps.

2. Wrigley's Forceps
  • Short, slightly curved blades.
  • Fixed English-style lock.
  • Designed for low or outlet forceps deliveries.
  • It is easier to manoeuvre when the fetal head is very low or visible.

3. Kielland Forceps
  • Long, almost straight blades
  • Adjustable pivot.
  • Designed for rotation of the fetal head.
  • Useful for occiput transverse positions.
  • Can accommodate asynclitism (tilted fetal head).

4. Piper Forceps
  • Asymmetrical blades (one solid, one fenestrated)
  • Specifically for the after-coming head in breech deliveries.
  • Allows application when access to the fetal head is limited.
  • Designed for quick delivery of head-in breech births.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old female presents with difficulty seeing in low light and peripheral vision loss that has gradually worsened over several years. On fundoscopy, the following findings are noted.



Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Retinitis Pigmentosa

Explanation:

The image given above is retinitis pigmentosa fundoscopy findings showing a pale waxy disc, bony spicules, and attenuation of arteries.

The Triad of retinitis pigmentosa includes a pale waxy disc due to consecutive optic atrophy, attenuation of arteries, and pigmentation disturbance in the form of bony spicules.

  • Retinitis pigmentosa is a dystrophy of rods and cones, initially, rods are affected.
  • Most common hereditary fundus dystrophy.
  • It can be sporadic (40-50%) or hereditary.
  • If hereditary, autosomal dominant is the most common mode of inheritance followed by autosomal recessive (AR). X-linked recessive inheritance is the least severe form.

 

Clinical features:

Symptoms:

  • Nyctalopia (night blindness)
  • Peripheral visual field loss
  • Mid-peripheral superior scotoma leads to ring/ doughnut scotoma resulting in tubular/ tunnel vision

Signs:

  • Triad of a pale waxy disc due to consecutive optic atrophy, attenuation of arteries, and pigmentation disturbance in the form of bony spicules.
  • Tapetal reflex: shining reflex at macula - seen in female carriers of XLR inheritance.

 

Atypical Retinitis Pigmentosa

  • Atypical retinitis pigmentosa includes heterogeneous disorders that share clinical features with typical pigmentary retinal dystrophy.
  • Conditions included are:

RP sine pigmento - absence or paucity of pigment accumulation

 

 

  • Retinitis punctata albescens - scattered whitish-yellow spots with arteriolar attenuation, usually sparing the macula.

questions.text: A 58-year-old female with hypertension and heart failure is prescribed an ACE inhibitor for blood pressure control. What is the most significant drug interaction to be cautious about when prescribing ACE inhibitors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Potassium-sparing diuretics

 

Explanation:

When prescribing ACE inhibitors, certain drug interactions can pose significant risks, especially the interaction with potassium-sparing diuretics. Here are some key interactions and their clinical implications:

Drug Interaction

Mechanism

Clinical Implication

ACE Inhibitors + Potassium Supplements/K-sparing diuretics

Risk of hyperkalemia due to reduced aldosterone secretion by ACE inhibitors combined with potassium-retaining agents.

Monitoring serum potassium levels is crucial to avoid hyperkalemia, which can cause serious cardiac issues such as arrhythmias.

ACE Inhibitors + NSAIDs

NSAIDs can reduce the anti-hypertensive effects of ACE inhibitors and decrease renal blood flow, increasing the risk of acute renal failure (ARF) or oliguria.

Use caution when combining NSAIDs with ACE inhibitors, and closely monitor renal function, particularly in high-risk patients.

ACE Inhibitors + Lithium

ACE inhibitors can increase the reabsorption of lithium, potentially leading to lithium toxicity.

Monitor lithium levels carefully when starting or adjusting ACE inhibitors in patients taking lithium, and adjust the lithium dosage as needed.

ACE Inhibitors + Antacids

Reduced bioavailability of ACE inhibitors due to binding with antacids.

Administer ACE inhibitors at least two hours before or after antacids to maintain their efficacy.

ACE Inhibitors + Diuretics

Diuretics enhance the hypotensive effects of ACE inhibitors by depleting sodium and raising renin levels.

In patients already on diuretics, start ACE inhibitors at a low dose to minimise the risk of excessive blood pressure reduction initially.
